Quiz Results

Part 8 of 85 (Quiz Attempts 71-80)
← Prev Part 8 of 85 Next →

Quiz Attempt #118969

Total Questions: 45
Question 1
Which of the following managerial actions are followed to reduce resistance to change? (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2023)a. Education and communication are strong tools for resistance to changeb. Allows participation to those who oppose a change to participate in decision makingc. Negotiation may become vital when resistance comes from a powerful sourced. Employeecounselingdoes not serve the purposee. Coercion can be used to get support easilyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.B, C and E Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, B and C Only

Let us consider each option one by one.

 

a. Education and communication are strong tools for resistance to change: This is true. Providing education about the reasons for change and communicating effectively can help employees understand the need for change and reduce resistance.

b. Allows participation to those who oppose a change to participate in decision making: This is also true. Allowing participation gives employees a sense of involvement and ownership in the change process, reducing resistance.

c. Negotiation may become vital when resistance comes from a powerful source: This is true as well. Negotiation can help address concerns and find compromises, especially when resistance comes from influential individuals or groups.

d. Employee counseling does not serve the purpose: This statement is false. Employee counseling can be helpful in addressing individual concerns and fears related to change, thereby reducing resistance.

e. Coercion can be used to get support easily: This statement is false. Coercion may lead to compliance in the short term, but it does not necessarily reduce resistance and can lead to long-term negative consequences such as resentment and decreased morale.

Therefore, the correct answer is option A.

Question 2
Match List I with List II. (UGC NET Management Jun 2023)List I (Change Consultant Function)a. Transcendingb. Process-facilitatingc. Shock-absorbingd. Resource-sharingList II (Consultant Role)i. Uses latest knowledge and a wide variety of experiencesii. Helps the system to confront realityiii. Takes an independent overall viewiv. Is perceptive of the reality in the organisationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:Codes
  • A.a - iii, b - ii, c -i, d - iv
  • B.a – iv, b – iii, c –i, d - ii
  • C.a – iii, b - iv, c – ii, d -i
  • D.a – iii, b – ii, c – iv, d -i
Correct Answer: a – iii, b - iv, c – ii, d -i

The correct answer is (C).

 

a. Transcending — iii. Takes an independent overall view

In this role, the consultant steps beyond internal biases and takes a broad, objective perspective to understand the entire system and its needs.

 

b. Process-facilitating — iv. Is perceptive of the reality in the organisation

This function involves helping the organization become more aware of its current realities and internal dynamics, facilitating smoother processes and transitions.

 

c. Shock-absorbing — ii. Helps the system to confront reality

Here, the consultant helps the organization deal with challenging truths and changes, acting as a buffer to reduce the negative impact of shock.

 

d. Resource-sharing — i. Uses latest knowledge and a wide variety of experiences

This role involves providing the organization with new knowledge, tools, and best practices from diverse experiences to support change and development.

Question 3
Which one of the following is not an internal force for organizational change? (UGC NET Management Jun 2023)
  • A.Managerial Behaviour
  • B.Change in leadership
  • C.Workforce Diversity
  • D.Change in Employee and customer expectations
Correct Answer: Change in Employee and customer expectations

The correct answer is (D) Change in Employee and customer expectations.

 

Internal forces for organizational change arise from factors within the organization that affect its operations, structure, or culture. These forces are typically driven by internal dynamics such as leadership, management, and workforce characteristics.

 

A. Managerial Behaviour — Managers' actions, attitudes, and behaviors can drive change. If managers adopt new leadership styles, practices, or attitudes, it can push the organization to evolve and adapt.

 

B. Change in Leadership — A change in leadership, such as a new CEO or department head, often results in new strategies, vision, and practices, which require the organization to adapt.

 

C. Workforce Diversity — As the workforce becomes more diverse, organizations may need to adapt their policies, culture, and management styles to effectively manage this diversity.

 

D. Change in Employee and Customer Expectations is an external force. While changes in expectations are critical, they come from outside the organization (e.g., shifting customer demands or employee desires for better work-life balance), rather than from within the organization itself.

Question 4
Who has suggested the 7-S framework for organizational change? (UGC NET Management Jun 2024)
  • A.Mckinsey
  • B.Peter Drucker
  • C.Dale Yoder
  • D.Mintzberg
Correct Answer: Mckinsey

The correct answer is (A) McKinsey. The 7-S framework for organizational change was developed by the consulting firm McKinsey & Company. The framework consists of seven interdependent factors: Structure, Strategy, Systems, Shared Values, Skills, Style, and Staff.

Question 5
Arrange the following steps of organisational change in ascending order: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2023)A. Initiation and motivationB. DeliberationC. StabilisationD. Action proposal and implementationE. Information collection and diagnosisChoose the correct answer from the options given below.Codes
  • A.A, D, E, B, C
  • B.E, D, C, B, A
  • C.A, E, B, D, C
  • D.A, B, C, D, E
Correct Answer: A, E, B, D, C

Option C is the correct answer.

 

A. Initiation and motivation: This is the first step where the need for change is identified, and the organization becomes motivated to make changes to address a particular issue or improve performance.

 

E. Information collection and diagnosis: Once the need for change is recognized, the organization gathers information and data to diagnose the root causes of the problem or the areas that need improvement. This step helps in understanding the current state of affairs and what needs to be changed.

 

B. Deliberation: After diagnosing the issues, there is a process of deliberation where different potential solutions and strategies are discussed and evaluated. This step involves considering various options and their potential impact on the organization.

 

D. Action proposal and implementation: Once a suitable solution or strategy is selected through deliberation, an action proposal is developed. This proposal outlines the specific actions that will be taken to bring about the desired change. Implementation involves putting these actions into practice.

 

C. Stabilisation: After the changes have been implemented, there is a period of stabilization where the organization monitors the effects of the changes and ensures that the new processes, systems, or strategies are working effectively. This step aims to ensure that the organization adapts to the changes and that they become integrated into the regular functioning of the organization.

Question 6
Examine the formula of dynamics of change given below; where ‘C’ stands for change;‘A’ represents the level of dissatisfaction with the Status Quo; ‘B’ indicates the clear desired goal; D refers to the practical first step; and ‘X’ stands for cost of change.Formula C = (ABD) > XConsidering the formula, ifA andB have high values but D is zero, what would be the result? (UGC NET HRM Jul 2016)
  • A.Change will occur slowly.
  • B.Change will not occur as the product of ABD would be zero.
  • C.Change will occur as the cost of change will be less.
  • D.Change will not occur as the cost of change will be more.
Correct Answer: Change will not occur as the product of ABD would be zero.

Beckhard and Harris designed a formula for companies to make decisions if change is needed 

The change formula is C= [ABD] > X 

A = Level of dissatisfaction with the status quo (dissatisfied with present state)

B = Desirability of the prose change or end state (eager to achieve the end state)

C = Change

D = Practicality of the change (minimal risk and disruption)

X = ’Cost’ of changing (perceived cost)

 

Beckard and Harris states, in order for change ‘C’ to occur, A, B, D must be greater than X. If the cost ‘X’ is less for completing A, B, D then change can occur.

Question 7
As per the force field analysis, change will take place when: (UGC NET HRM Jul 2016)
  • A.Driving force equals the restraining force
  • B.Driving force and the restraining force correlate with one another
  • C.Driving force is stronger than restraining force
  • D.Restraining force is stronger than driving force
Correct Answer: Driving force is stronger than restraining force

As per Field Force analysis, (Kurt Lewin's model of Change management), there are forces driving change and then there are forces restraining it. Where there is equilibrium between the two sets of forces there will be no change. In order for change to occur the “Driving Force” must exceed the “Restraining Force”.

Question 8
Kanterand associates gave ten steps to implementing change. They are jumbled. Arranged them in the correct order: (UGC NET HRM Aug 2016)(a) Create a sense of urgency(b) Separate from the past(c) Analyse the organisation and its need for change(d) Support a strong leader role(e) Develop enabling structures(f) Line up political sponsorship(g) Communicate and involve people(h) Craft an implementation plan(i) Create a shared vision and common direction(j) Reinforce and institutionalize change
  • A.(c), (g), (b), (a), (d), (f), (h), (e), (i), (j)
  • B.(b), (d), (c), (g), (a), (h), (f), (e), (i), (j)
  • C.(c), (d), (a), (g), (h), (b), (e), (j), (i), (f)
  • D.(c), (i), (b), (a), (d), (f), (h), (e), (g), (j)
Correct Answer: (c), (i), (b), (a), (d), (f), (h), (e), (g), (j)

Kanter and associates gave 10 step change management model:

1. Analyse the organisation & its need for change - Managers should understand an organization’s operations, how it functions in its environment, what its strengths and weaknesses are, and how it will be affected by proposed changes in order to craft an effective implementation plan.

2. Create a shared vision & common directive - One of the first steps in engineering change is to unite an organization behind a central vision. This vision should reflect the philosophy and values of the organization, and should help it to articulate what it hopes to become. A successful vision serves to guide behavior, and to aid an organization in achieving its goals.

3. Separate from past - Disengaging from the past is critical to awakening to a new reality. It is difficult for an organization to embrace a new vision of the future until it has isolated the structures and routines that no longer work, and vowed to move beyond them.

4. Create a sense of urgency - Convincing an organization that change is necessary isn’t that difficult when a company is teetering on the brink of bankruptcy, or foundering in the marketplace. But when the need for action is not generally understood, a change leader should generate a sense of urgency without appearing to be fabricating an emergency, or “crying wolf.” This sense of urgency is essential to rallying an organization behind change.

5. Support a strong leader role - An organization should not undertake something as challenging as large scale change without a leader to guide, drive, and inspire it. This change advocate plays a critical role in creating a company vision, motivating company employees to embrace that vision, and crafting an organizational structure that consistently rewards those who strive toward the realization of the vision.

6. Line up political sponsorship - Leadership, alone, cannot bring about large scale change. In order to succeed, a change effort must have broad based support throughout an organization. This support should include not only the managers, or change implementors, but also the recipients of change, whose acceptance of any program is necessary for its success.

7. Craft an implementation plan - While a vision may guide and inspire during the change process, an organization also needs more nuts and bolts advice on what to do, and when and how to do it. This change plan maps out the effort, specifying everything from where the first meetings should be held, to the date by which the company hopes to achieve its change goals.

8. Develop enabling structures - Altering the status quo and creating new mechanisms for implementing change can be a critical precursor to any organizational transformation. These mechanisms may be part of the existing corporate structure, or may be established as a freestanding organization. Enabling structures designed to facilitate and spotlight change range from the practical – such as setting up pilot tests, off site workshops, training programs, and new reward systems – to the symbolic – such as rearranging the organization’s physical space.

9. Communicate, involve people & be honest - When possible, change leaders should communicate openly, and seek out the involvement and trust of people throughout their organizations. Full involvement, communication, and disclosure are not called for in every change situation, but these approaches can be potent tools for overcoming resistance, and giving employees a personal stake in the outcome of a transformation.

10. Reinforce & institutionalise change - Throughout the pursuit of change, managers and leaders should make it a top priority to prove their commitment to the transformation process, reward risk taking, and incorporate new behaviours into the day to day operations of the organization. By reinforcing the new culture, they affirm its importance and hasten it’s acceptance.

Question 9
In explaining the dynamic of change who has given the formula “C = (ABD) > X”? (UGC NET HRM Aug 2016)
  • A.NoelTichyand MaryanneDevanna.
  • B.RichardBeckhardand Reuben Harris.
  • C.David Nadler and MichaelTushman.
  • D.RosabethMossKanterand ToddJick.
Correct Answer: RichardBeckhardand Reuben Harris.

Beckhard and Harris designed a formula for companies to make decisions if change is needed. 

The formula is:  C= [ABD] > X 

A = Level of dissatisfaction with the status quo (dissatisfied with present state)

B = Desirability of the prose change or end state (eager to achieve the end state)

C = Change

D = Practicality of the change (minimal risk and disruption)

X = ’Cost’ of changing (perceived cost)

 

Beckard and Harris states, in order for change ‘C’ to occur, A, B, D must be greater than X. If the cost ‘X’ is less for completing A, B, D  then change can occur.

Question 10
Consider the following. (UGC NET HRM Jul 2016)Assertion “A”:From its inception, the study of organisational change has noted the fact that many participants respond with dogged resistance to altering the status quo. Since the industrial revolution began, workers have at times sought, occasionally in extremely violent fashion, to block the introduction of new technology.Reason “R”:Such behaviour may be either overt or covert. Overt resistance may take the form of employees deliberately failing to do the things necessary for successful change or simply being unenthusiastic about the change. Covert resistance can be more detrimental to change than open resistance because it is harder to identify and eliminate.
  • A.A is true, R is false.
  • B.A is true, R explains A.
  • C.A and R both are false.
  • D.A is true, R does not explain A.
Correct Answer: A is true, R explains A.

The assertion claims the long-standing observation in organizational change, pointing out how participants habitually resist altering the status quo. This resistance dates back to the industrial revolution, where workers sometimes vehemently opposed the adoption of new technology. Resistance isn't confined to lower-level roles; even managers and employees have opposed substantial change initiatives, reflecting a systemic resistance.

 

The reason provided sheds light on the nature of such resistance, categorizing it into overt and covert behaviors. Overt resistance could manifest as deliberately neglecting tasks essential for change or displaying general disinterest. Covert resistance, while harder to identify, poses a greater challenge for change initiatives as it remains concealed. This distinction between overt and covert resistance underscores the complexity of identifying and addressing resistance within organizations.

 

Watson (1966) elaborates on two factors explaining resistance: personality-related and social system-related. Personality factors encompass homeostasis, habit, selective perception, dependence, super ego, and more, illustrating individual tendencies to resist change. On the other hand, resistance in the social system emerges from conformity to norms, systemic coherence, vested interests, and the sanctity of certain beliefs, depicting resistance stemming from various facets within the social structure.

Question 11
Match the sources of resistance (List – A) and the steps that can be taken to deal with such resistance (List – B): (UGC NET HRM Jan 2017)List – A (Sources of Resistance)a. Complacency and Inertiab. Fear of large-scale disturbancec. Perception of Impositiond. Fear of Obsolescencee. Fear of loss of powerList – B (Coping Mechanisms)i. Development of skillsii. Participation and Involvementiii. Phasing of changeiv. Fait accompliv. Role re-definition and re-orientation
  • A.a-v, b-iv, c-iii, d-ii, e-i
  • B.a-i, b-iii, c-ii, d-iv, e-v
  • C.a-ii, b-iv, c-v, d-iii, e-i
  • D.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i, e-v
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i, e-v

The various sources of resistance and the coping mechanisms include the following.

 

i) Perceived Peripherality of Change: Implementation of change can be effective if the introduced change is seen as critical and useful, which can be achieved by the participation of the concerned people in the diagnosis of the issues or problems.

ii) Perception of Imposition: When people see the change as being imposed, they tend to resist it. The resistance can be overcome by involving people in the introduction of change at several stages.

 

iii) Indifference of the Top Management: The mangers are the role models. If their attitude shows indifference, people also tend to resist change. The best way to overcome resistance is by the commitment of the leader and by his/her active support for change management.

 

iv) Vested Interests: The vested interests of people cause resistance to change. Once people experience the change, they often enjoy it and may see its positive aspects.

 

v) Complacency and Inertia: As change produces discomfort, it is resisted. The solution to the problem is to introduce the change and help people experience new conditions.

 

vi) Fear of Large Scale Disturbance: The fear that the proposed change is likely to lead to some other changes with unpredictable consequences might result in resistance. Phasing out the change could help overcome the resistance.

 

vii) Fear of Inadequate Resources: Whenever the change requires additional resources in the form of new skills, additional manpower, or budget, resistance is likely to be greater. Genuine need for the resources needs to be supported by the top management for overcoming resistance.

 

viii) Fear of Obsolescence: People resist change as they fear that they may become obsolete as they lack those skills which are required for coping with the change. Organizations should provide opportunities to those people in the development of the required skills, which could help to overcome resistance.

 

ix) Fear of Loss of Power: Any change would result in some roles in the organization to lose power. This feeling of loss of power could lead to resistance. In order to overcome this resistance, there is a need to redefine and redesign the roles.

 

x) Fear of Overload: If the change is perceived to increase the work load of people, they tend to resist the change. There is a need to bring in more of role clarity to overcome the resistance.

Question 12
Which of the following is not an action of classical change programme? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2013)
  • A.Refreezing
  • B.Removing
  • C.Changing
  • D.Unfreezing
Correct Answer: Removing

The classical change program involves three stages elucidated by Kurt Lewin: Unfreezing, Moving, and Refreezing.

1. Unfreezing: This stage requires enabling individuals to release old counterproductive patterns. It addresses individual resistance and group conformity by augmenting driving forces away from the existing situation and reducing restraining forces opposing the change.

2. Moving or Changing: It marks the transition phase where thoughts, feelings, or behaviors shift towards a more productive or liberating state.

3. Refreezing: This stage solidifies change into a new standard operating procedure, ensuring that the change becomes an established habit. Without this phase, there's a risk of reverting to old practices.

 

The action not associated with the classical change program is 'Removing.' Classical change programs, as defined by Lewin, involve Unfreezing, Moving, and Refreezing stages, aiming to address resistance, transition, and the establishment of change as a new norm, rather than simply removing aspects or elements.

Question 13
Which one of the following can be the coping mechanism if the source of resistance to change is the fear of loss of power? (UGC NET Management Dec 2022)
  • A.Active support from the top.
  • B.Participation and involvement.
  • C.Role clarity and definition.
  • D.Role redefinition and re-orientation.
Correct Answer: Role redefinition and re-orientation.

Option D is the correct answer.

 

The various sources of resistance and the coping mechanisms include the following.

 

i) Perceived Peripherality of Change: Implementation of change can be effective if the introduced change is seen as critical and useful, which can be achieved by the participation of the concerned people in the diagnosis of the issues or problems.

 

ii) Perception of Imposition: When people see the change as being imposed, they tend to resist it. Resistance can be overcome by involving people in the introduction of change at several stages.

 

iii) Indifference of the Top Management: The managers are the role models. If their attitude shows indifference, people also tend to resist change. The best way to overcome resistance is by the commitment of the leader and by his/her active support for change Management.

 

iv) Vested Interests: The vested interests of people cause resistance to change. Once people experience the change, they often enjoy it and may see its positive aspects.

 

v) Complacency and Inertia: As change produces discomfort, it is resisted. The solution to the problem is to introduce change and help people experience new conditions.

 

vi) Fear of Large-Scale Disturbance: The fear that the proposed change is likely to lead to some other changes with unpredictable consequences might result in resistance. Phasing out the change could help overcome the resistance.

 

vii) Fear of Inadequate Resources: Whenever the change requires additional resources in the form of new skills, additional manpower, or budget, resistance is likely to be greater. The genuine need for the resources needs to be supported by the top Management for overcoming resistance.

 

viii) Fear of Obsolescence: People resist change as they fear that they may become obsolete as they lack those skills which are required for coping with the change. Organizations should provide opportunities to those people in the development of the required skills, which could help to overcome resistance.

 

ix) Fear of Loss of Power: Any change would result in some roles in the organization losing power. This feeling of loss of power could lead to resistance. In order to overcome this resistance, there is a need to redefine and redesign the roles.

 

x) Fear of Overload: If the change is perceived to increase the workload of people, they tend to resist the change. There is a need to bring in more role clarity to overcome the resistance.

Question 14
Consider the following. (UGC NET HRM Dec 2015)Assertion “A”: Resistance to change is the ability to avoid what one does not want from the environment/is a behaviour designed to discredit, delay or prevent the implementation of a change.Reason “R”:According to Newton's third law of motion "to every action there is an equal and opposite reaction". Resistance to change, is therefore, bound to be there. Real change will be effective only when Driving Forces > Restraining Forces.
  • A.A and R both are not correct.
  • B.A is right and R is wrong.
  • C.A and R both are correct and R explains A.
  • D.A and R both are correct and R does not explain A.
Correct Answer: A and R both are correct and R explains A.

Resistance to change involves the capability to evade undesired elements from the environment or behaviors intended to undermine, postpone, or hinder change implementation. This resistance aligns with Newton's third law of motion, which suggests that every action incites an equal and opposing reaction. Change is only successful when the forces propelling change surpass those inhibiting it. According to Kurt Lewin's Field Force analysis, equilibrium between driving and restraining forces halts change, necessitating the dominance of driving forces for change to occur. Thus, both Assertion (A) and Reason (R) are accurate, with Reason (R) explaining Assertion (A) by emphasizing the necessity for the dominance of driving forces over restraining forces to effectuate change.

Question 15
Alpha, Beta, Gamma A and Gamma B changes are related to which change? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2015)(a) Structural change(b) System change(c) Process change(d) Cognitive change
  • A.(a) and (b)
  • B.(b) only
  • C.(d) only
  • D.(c) and (d)
Correct Answer: (d) only

Golembiewski et. al. (1976) is responsible for giving terms Alpha, Beta, Gamma A and Gamma B. Porras and Silvers gave a change management model using work of Golembiewski. There are 4 types of Cognitive Changes. Alpha, Beta, Gamma A and Gamma B.

The types of change are as follows:  

Alpha change refers to change in the perceived levels of variables within a paradigm without altering their configuration.  

Beta change refers to change in people’s view about the meaning of the value of any variable within an existing paradigm without altering their configuration.  

Gamma A refers to change in the configuration of an existing paradigm without the addition of new variables.  

Gamma B refers to the replacement of one paradigm with another that contains some or all new variables.

Question 16
In Lewin's three step model of successful change in organisation, the stage which refers to "for making any change same thing has to be done in a planned way to disturb the status quo", is known as: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2015)
  • A.Moving
  • B.Unfreezing
  • C.Refreezing
  • D.Intervening
Correct Answer: Unfreezing

The stage in Lewin's three-step change model that pertains to disrupting the status quo in a planned manner to facilitate change is known as "Unfreezing." This initial stage in the change process aims to create an awareness of how the current status quo hinders the organization. By unfreezing the existing state, individuals become receptive to change. Once this stage is completed, the organization progresses towards the actual implementation of change, signifying the transitional or 'moving' phase. Finally, the model concludes with what Lewin termed as freezing, or refreezing, where the new state after change is reinforced, stabilized, and consolidated.

Question 17
The ‘force-field analysis’ model of organisational change resistance was advanced by: (UGC NET HRM Sep 2013)
  • A.Abraham Maslow
  • B.Douglas McGregor
  • C.Kurt Lewin
  • D.ChrisArgyris
Correct Answer: Kurt Lewin

The 'force-field analysis' model, which is employed for assessing organizational change resistance, was introduced by Kurt Lewin. Developed in the 1940s, this model serves as a valuable decision-making tool by evaluating the factors that support and oppose change. It aids in determining whether to proceed with a change initiative and assists in enhancing the likelihood of success by bolstering the supporting forces and mitigating those opposing the change.

Question 18
Organisational change is a complex phenomenon. In the process organisations have to deal with resistance from different stakeholders. (UGC NET HRM Jun 2015)Consider the following:(a) Perception of imposition(b) Role redefinition and re-orientation(c) Participation in Diagnosis(d) Vested interests
  • A.(a) and (b) are sources of resistance and (c) and (d) are coping mechanisms
  • B.(b) and (c) are sources of resistance and (a) and (d) are coping mechanisms
  • C.(a) and (b) are coping mechanisms and (c) and (d) are sources of resistance
  • D.(b) and (c) are coping mechanisms and (a) and (d) are sources of resistance
Correct Answer: (b) and (c) are coping mechanisms and (a) and (d) are sources of resistance

Sources of resistance and coping mechanisms in organizational change can be delineated as follows:

 

(a) Perception of imposition and (d) Vested interests - These factors often act as sources of resistance in organizational change. The perception of change being imposed without involvement or consent can generate resistance, as can vested interests that are threatened by the proposed changes.

 

(b) Role redefinition and re-orientation and (c) Participation in Diagnosis - These aspects are often coping mechanisms during organizational change. Redefining roles and orienting individuals toward new responsibilities can help them adapt to change. Additionally, involving stakeholders in the diagnosis and decision-making process can mitigate resistance by fostering a sense of ownership and understanding of the change process.

Question 19
If the change is plotted on two axis of ‘Time and difficulty involved in change‘ then which of the following would be the correct sequence of change taking place in shortest time and difficulty to maximum period and difficulty? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2009)(i) Group Behaviour(ii) Individual Behaviour(iii) Organisational Behaviour(iv) Knowledge(v) Attitude
  • A.(iv), (v), (iii), (ii), (i)
  • B.(i), (ii), (iv), (iii), (v)
  • C.(ii), (iii), (i), (v), (iv)
  • D.(iv), (v), (ii), (i), (iii)
Correct Answer: (iv), (v), (ii), (i), (iii)

If the change is plotted on two axis of ‘Time and difficulty involved in change‘ then the sequence will be: knowledge , attitude, individual behavior, group behavior and organizational behavior. Mayo's Four Levels of Change are (a) Knowledge, (b) Attitude, (c)  Individual Behavior, (d) Group Behavior 

1. Knowledge is Easiest change to bring as it is the result of reading an article or hearing something

2. Attitude is Emotional part of the change -- reactions to what is happening 

3. Individual Behaviour is Teaching an old dog new tricks -- changing a specific individuals old habits 

4. Group Behaviour is “We've always done it this way” -- changing a groups habits

Question 20
The eight step plan for implementing change was given by
  • A.Kurt Lewin
  • B.Johnkotter
  • C.Jack Welch
  • D.Peter F. Drucker
Correct Answer: Johnkotter

John Kotter (1996) describes the eight step change process:

1) Establishing a Sense of Urgency: examining the realities; identifying and discussing crises, potential crises, or major opportunities

2) Creating the Guiding Coalition: putting together a group with enough power to lead the change; getting the group to work together like a team

3) Developing a Vision and Strategy: creating a vision to help direct the change effort; developing strategies for achieving that vision

4) Communicating the Change Vision: using every vehicle possible to constantly communicate the new vision and strategies; having the guiding coalition role model the behaviour expected

5) Empowering Broad-Based Action: getting rid of obstacles; changing systems or structures undermining the change vision; encouraging risk taking and non-traditional ideas, activities and actions

6) Generating Short-Term Wins: planning for visible improvements in performance; creating those “wins”; visibly recognizing and rewarding people who make the “wins” possible

7) Consolidating Gains and Producing More Change: using increased credibility to change all systems, structures, and policies that don’t fit together and don’t fit the transformation vision; hiring, promoting and developing people who can implement the change vision; reinvigorating the process with new projects, themes, and change agents

8) Anchoring New Approaches in the Culture: creating better performance through customer-and productivity-oriented behavior, more and better leadership and more effective management; articulating the connections between new behavior and organizational success; developing means to ensure leadership development and succession

Question 21
Match phases of change process (List - I) with their propagators (List - II). (UGC NET HRM Nov 2017)List I(a) Unfreezing, Changing, Freezing(b) Awakening, Mobilizing, Reinforcing(c) Energizing, Envisioning, and Enabling(D) Dissatisfaction with the status quo, clear goal, awareness of practical first stepsList II(i) Nadler andTushman(ii)BeckhardandRenbernHarris(iii) Kurt Lewin(iv)NeolTirchy&DevannaSelect the correct answer using the codes given below:
  • A.(a)-(iii) (b)-(ii) (c)-(i) (d)-(iv)
  • B.(a)-(iii) (b)-(iv) (c)-(i) (d)-(ii)
  • C.(a)-(iii) (b)-(i) (c)-(iv) (d)-(ii)
  • D.(a)-(iii) (b)-(ii) (c)-(iv) (d)-(i)
Correct Answer: (a)-(iii) (b)-(iv) (c)-(i) (d)-(ii)

The phases of the change process in List I match with their respective propagators in List II as follows:

(a) Unfreezing, Changing, Freezing - Kurt Lewin (iii)

(b) Awakening, Mobilizing, Reinforcing - Neol Tirchy & Devanna (iv)

(c) Energizing, Envisioning, and Enabling - Nadler and Tushman (i)

(d) Dissatisfaction with the status quo, clear goal, awareness of practical first steps - Beckhard and Renbern Harris (ii)

Question 22
Where do the following activities fall in Kurt Lewin’s model of change process? (UGC NT HRM Dec 2009)a) Reinforcing the newly learnedbehaviorb) Finding ‘fits’ between organizational componentsc) Maintaining ‘fits’ between organizational components
  • A.Unfreezing
  • B.Moving
  • C.Refreezing
  • D.None of the above
Correct Answer: Refreezing

In Kurt Lewin's change theory model, the stage where activities such as reinforcing newly learned behavior, finding 'fits' between organizational components, and maintaining these 'fits' aligns with the concept of 'Refreezing.' Refreezing is the phase where the change becomes ingrained and accepted within the organization, establishing it as the new norm. It involves embracing the acquired values, behaviors, and structures, completely discarding old ideas, and fully embracing the new ones. This phase emphasizes solidifying the new strategies to make employee behaviors aligned with the change as a natural course of action.

Question 23
Arrange the following steps of organisational change in the correct sequence from the first to the last: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2022)(a) Action Proposal(b) Implementation(c) Initiation(d) Deliberation(e) DiagnosisChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.(e), (b), (c), (d), (a)
  • B.(b), (c), (d), (e), (a)
  • C.(c), (e), (d), (a), (b)
  • D.(a), (b), (e), (d), (c)
Correct Answer: (c), (e), (d), (a), (b)

Option C is the correct answer.

 

Organizational Change is a continuous process involving several stages. People who accomplish successful change go through a number of sequential stages in reaching their goal. The various stages through which a change goes through are:

1. Initiation (Dissatisfaction with the present state)

2. Motivation (Seeing or hearing about change)

3. Diagnosis (Gathering information and data)

4. Information Collection (Collecting more relevant data)

5. Deliberation (Discussing and planning)

6. Proposal (Presenting with pay-off)

7. Implementation (Extended use of change)

8. Stabilization (Attitude change and acceptance)

Question 24
The change procedure of unfreezing, moving and refreezing was given by: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2011)
  • A.Kurt Lewin
  • B.P.F. Drucker
  • C.French and Bell
  • D.Katz and Kahn
Correct Answer: Kurt Lewin

Kurt Lewin developed the change model that encompasses the three stages: unfreezing, changing, and refreezing. This model offers a straightforward and effective approach to comprehending the change process. Lewin's concept involves initially establishing the need for change, transitioning towards the desired new behavior, and ultimately solidifying this behavior as the new standard or norm.

Question 25
A conscious change that occurs as a result of logic is called: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2018)
  • A.Subsystem change
  • B.Planned change
  • C.Emergent change
  • D.Remedial change
Correct Answer: Planned change

Planned change refers to a deliberate, conscious, and systematic alteration within an organization that occurs as a result of logical reasoning and a proactive approach by the leadership. This type of change is methodically organized in response to recognized needs or identified areas for improvement within the organization. Leaders or management actively plan and execute a structured strategy to implement the change, aiming for specific objectives or improvements.

 

Subsystem Change: This type of change involves modifications or adjustments made within specific parts or subsystems of the organization, such as altering a product/service, implementing a new process, or making localized changes without affecting the entire organization.

 

Emergent Change: Emergent change occurs when an organization responds to an urgent need or unforeseen circumstances that require immediate attention, often diverging from the standard processes or plans due to the pressing nature of the situation.

 

Remedial Change: Remedial change is introduced in response to deviations or discrepancies from established standards or performance benchmarks. It involves corrective actions taken to align organizational performance with predefined standards.

 

Planned change stands out among these options as it specifically represents a consciously organized transformation initiated by the leadership based on logical reasoning and a predetermined strategy to bring about deliberate improvements within the organization.

Question 26
Which of the following is a force that acts as stimulant for organizational change? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)
  • A.Nature of the workforce
  • B.Technology
  • C.Economic Shock
  • D.All the above
Correct Answer: All the above

Change in organizations is often a response to various internal and external factors. These factors include the nature of the workforce, technological advancements, and economic shocks among others. External influences encompass the dynamic interactions between an organization and its environment, such as technological advancements leading to decreased cost-effectiveness and increased competition, altering the organization's equilibrium. Changes in marketing conditions, societal norms, and political and legal factors also necessitate adjustments within organizations to maintain their competitive edge and adapt to societal shifts. Internally, managerial changes, deficiencies in existing organizational structures or practices, and shifts in the workforce's nature, values, and behavior can drive the need for organizational change. Moreover, changes may be undertaken proactively to prevent stagnation or inflexibility within the organization.

Question 27
Which of the following is not a method of dealing with resistance to change? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)
  • A.Education and Communication
  • B.Participation
  • C.Facilitation and Support
  • D.Coercion and Punishment
Correct Answer: Coercion and Punishment

When addressing resistance to change, various approaches can be employed to facilitate a smoother transition. These methods include education and communication, participation and involvement, facilitation and support, negotiation, co-optation and manipulation, and explicit or implicit coercion. Education and communication involve informing and training employees to gain their understanding and cooperation in the change process. Participation and involvement encourage active engagement to reduce resistance. Facilitation and support provide assistance to employees facing adjustment challenges during transitions. Negotiation offers incentives or alternatives to motivate employees affected by change. Co-optation and manipulation involve involving influential individuals to support the change through communication and symbolic roles. Lastly, explicit or implicit coercion is used sparingly and involves drastic measures like job loss or reassignments, typically when urgency overrides employee interests. However, coercion and punishment (option D) are not considered viable or recommended methods to handle resistance to change.

Question 28
Consider the following. (UGC NET HRM Jun 2013)Assertion “A”:Structural inertia is an organisational resistance process to change because organisations have built in mechanism to produce stability.Reason “R”:People with a high need for security are likely to resist change because it threatens their feeling of safety.
  • A.A is right and R is a correct explanation of A.
  • B.Both A and R are right, but the R does not explain the A.
  • C.Both A and R are wrong.
  • D.A is wrong and R is right.
Correct Answer: Both A and R are right, but the R does not explain the A.

"Structural inertia" refers to an organization's resistance to change due to its inherent mechanisms geared toward stability. This resistance is a result of established structural elements that maintain the status quo within the organization. Meanwhile, individuals with a high need for security are inclined to resist change because it poses a threat to their sense of safety and stability. However, while both assertions are accurate, the reason (R) focusing on individual resistance due to a need for security doesn't explicitly explain why organizations exhibit structural inertia (assertion A). Therefore, both assertions are correct, but the reason doesn't entirely clarify the organizational aspect of resistance described in assertion A.

Question 29
The process of change namely coercive, mimetic and normativeisomorphismsare associated with which of the following perspectives on organizational change? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2019)
  • A.Resource dependence perspective
  • B.Contingency perspective
  • C.Population-ecology perspective
  • D.Institutional perspective
Correct Answer: Institutional perspective

The process of change, coercive, mimetic, and normative isomorphisms, aligns with the Institutional perspective.

 

Isomorphism theory, introduced by DiMaggio and Powell, sheds light on the forces that drive organizations toward uniformity in forms and practices. Institutional isomorphism explains how external pressures compel organizations to adopt similar institutional practices. These pressures stem from factors like government regulations and industry competition, dictating how organizations in a field should operate to gain legitimacy. Isomorphism emphasizes organizational homogenization for legitimacy attainment. Failure to comply with prevailing rules leads to organizational deviance and potential damage to reputation in competitive markets.

 

DiMaggio and Powell's typology defines three forces driving institutional change:

 

(a) Coercive isomorphism: It's the pressure on organizations, formal and informal, to align with societal and external cultural norms and regulations. Organizational compliance is essential for legitimacy. Legislation creates expectations and compels conformity, even if it impacts operational efficiency.

 

(b) Normative isomorphism: This arises from strict adherence to professional conventions and standards within a profession. Professionalization enforces uniformity in actions across borders, binding professionals to ethical codes and standards through training, conferences, and ongoing professional networks.

 

(c) Mimetic isomorphism: Organizations mimic existing models, especially in uncertain situations, where managers emulate successful models due to a lack of direction. Mimicking other organizations' successful qualities is a strategy adopted when facing ambiguity or adversity.

Question 30
The change related phenomenon resisted by the organisation in order to maintain an equilibrium, is known as: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2014)
  • A.Conformity to Norms
  • B.Homoeostasis
  • C.Self-distrust
  • D.Insecurity and regression
Correct Answer: Homoeostasis

The phenomenon resisted by organizations to maintain an equilibrium, known as "homoeostasis," embodies the tendency of an organization to uphold stability. This inclination toward equilibrium leads to resistance against any change-related events or processes. Homoeostasis forms part of the personality-related factors contributing to resistance to change, as proposed by Watson (1966). It aligns with other factors such as established habits, selective perception, dependence, and super ego, all of which contribute to an aversion to change and a preference for maintaining the status quo. In the social system, factors like conformity to norms, systemic coherence, vested interests, reverence for sacred beliefs, and rejection of "outsiders" further add to the resistance faced by organizations when attempting to introduce changes.

Question 31
Which of the following are the syndromes of organisational maladjustment? (UGC NET HRM Dec 2014)a. Rigor Mortisb. Young Turkc. Anarchyd. Smoothinge. Rat race
  • A.a, b and c
  • B.a, c and e
  • C.b, d and e
  • D.a, d and e
Correct Answer: a, c and e

This list of syndromes of organisational maladjustment, which can be reasons of failure of change management are:

Myopia: No future orientation. Little thought to strategy, sense of direction and advance planning. Live day to day, week to week.

Rat-race: Toxic climate coming from oppressive, primitive, slave-driving policy.

Remote Control: Too much administrative or executive control from the parent body. Decision making autonomy is seriously impaired.

Rigor Mortis: Conditions of inertia and constricted activity prevail. Primary organisation value is structure and order. 

Amoeba: Lack of strong direction from top executives. Not enough structure, order or guidance leading to activity trap, i.e. doing things without knowing where one is heading to.

Anarchy: A situational upheaval where leadership, responsibilities, functions and resources are in dispute.

Buggywhip: Clinging to obsolete products, services and practices which no longer have potential for sustaining livelihood.

Deadlock: Standoff condition between management and leader of workforce leading to toxic antagonistic relations between the factions.

Question 32
Arrange the following key roles in the inverse order of their involvement in the process of organizational change.1. Chief implementer2. Task forces3. Corporate management4. Implementation team5. ConsultantChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.1, 5, 3, 2, 4
  • B.3, 5, 1, 4, 2
  • C.3, 1, 5, 4, 2
  • D.5, 1, 3, 2, 4
Correct Answer: 3, 5, 1, 4, 2

The term ‘organisational change’ implies the creation of imbalances in the existing pattern of situation. In other words, organisation members evolve a tentative set of relations with the environment. They have an adjustment with their job, working conditions, friends and colleagues etc. 

 

Change management is a systematic approach to dealing with the transition or transformation of an organization's goals, processes or technologies. The purpose is to implement strategies for effecting change, controlling change and helping people to adapt to change.

 

The key roles in the inverse order of their involvement in the process of organizational change are given below:

1. Corporate management

2. Consultant

3. Chief implementer

4. Implementation team

5. Task forces

Question 33
Who propounded the ‘Force-Field theory’ of change process?(UGC NET Management Dec 2019)
  • A.Kurt Lewin
  • B.Peter Drucker
  • C.Joseph A. Schumpeter
  • D.David C. McClelland
Correct Answer: Kurt Lewin

Kurt Lewin is credited with the development of the 'Force Field Theory' in change management. This model involves evaluating the driving forces pushing for change against the restraining forces resisting change within organizations. The interplay between these opposing forces determines the possibility and success of change initiatives, with driving forces seeking change and restraining forces maintaining the status quo. Achieving equilibrium between these forces becomes a key objective in implementing successful organizational change.

Question 34
Organisations encounter many different forces for change which may be external or internal. Which among the following does NOT come under the external forces of change?[UGC NET Management June 2019]
  • A.Technological advancement
  • B.Workforce diversity
  • C.Change in leadership
  • D.Competition in the market
Correct Answer: Change in leadership

The correct answer is (C) Change in leadership. While changes in leadership can indeed have a significant impact on an organization's direction and culture, they are often considered an internal force for change rather than an external one. External forces usually stem from outside the organization, such as technological advancements, global market competition, changes in legal or political environments, and shifts in workforce demographics.

Question 35
Which one of the following is the most suitable coping mechanism if ‘fear of overload’ is the source of resistance to change? (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)
  • A.Participation and involvement
  • B.Support of resources
  • C.Role redefinition and re‐orientation
  • D.Role clarity and definition
Correct Answer: Role clarity and definition

Option D is the correct answer.

 

Fear of Overload: If the change is perceived to increase the workload of people, they tend to resist the change. There is a need to bring in more of role clarity to overcome the resistance.

Question 36
Arrange the following stages of the process of organizational change in the sequential order: (UGC NET Commerce Jun 2021)1. Detailed consideration of the proposed change.2. Collection of detailed information and development of alternative approaches in relation to the problem or issues.3. Evaluation of various alternatives and framing a proposal.4. Vocalization of the need to change.5. Search for the main cause underlying the symptoms encountered.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.4, 5, 2, 1, 3
  • B.4, 1, 5, 2, 3
  • C.1, 5, 4, 3, 2
  • D.2, 5, 4, 1, 3
Correct Answer: 4, 1, 5, 2, 3

Correct answer is option B.

 

Management of Change (MOC) is a systematic approach to organizational changes with the aim of ensuring the continued safety of the workforce throughout the process. These systematic processes ensures that the change is dealt with in a proactive fashion.

 

Correct order for the stages of the process of organizational change is given below:

1. Vocalization of the need to change.

2. Detailed consideration of the proposed change.

3. Search for the main cause underlying the symptoms encountered.

4. Collection of detailed information and development of alternative approaches in relation to the problem or issues.

5. Evaluation of various alternatives and framing a proposal.

Question 37
Given below are two statements, one is labelled as Assertion A and the other is labelled as Reason R (UGC NET HRM Jun 2021)Assertion ‘A’:Structural inertia is an organizational resistance process to change because organizations have a built-in mechanism to produce stability.Reason ‘R’:People with a high need for security are likely to resist change because it threatens their feeling of safety.In light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A is correct but R is not correct
  • B.A is not correct but R is correct
  • C.Both A and R are correct and R is the correct explanation of A
  • D.Both A and R are correct but R is NOT the correct explanation of A
Correct Answer: Both A and R are correct but R is NOT the correct explanation of A

The assertion states that structural inertia within organizations serves as a resistance mechanism to change by inherently promoting stability. This aligns with the idea that organizations have mechanisms embedded in their structures that tend to maintain the status quo. So, Assertion A is indeed correct.

 

Meanwhile, the reason provided suggests that individuals with a strong need for security are likely to resist change as it threatens their sense of safety. While this is a valid point, it doesn't directly explain the organizational aspect of structural inertia, which is about the systemic resistance within the organization itself. Thus, Reason R is correct but doesn't serve as a direct explanation for Assertion A. Hence, the correct choice is (D) Both A and R are correct, but R is NOT the correct explanation of A.

Question 38
Some of the areas relating to organizational change are given below: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2019)(a) Marketing(b) Technology(c) Quality(d) Structure(e) Strategy(f) Managing peopleChoose your answer from the given below options, which gives the list relating to content of change:
  • A.(a), (b), (e) and (f)
  • B.(a), (b) and (c)
  • C.(c), (d) and (e)
  • D.(b), (c), (d) and (f)
Correct Answer: (a), (b) and (c)

The organizational change process involves growth, decline, and transformation within the organization. According to Nilakant and Ramnarayan, four primary areas constitute the content of change: technology, marketing, quality, and costs. To drive changes in these areas, organizations must also alter three other aspects: strategy, structure, and people management practices. These three elements play a crucial role in shaping the change process. Ultimately, effective change requires leadership that is grounded in values.

Question 39
Appreciate Inquiry process was developed by DavidCooperriderand SureshShrivastavagiving four phases. Arrange four phrases from one to four: (UGC NET HRM Jun 2020)A. DreamB. DesignC. DiscoveryD. DeliveryChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C, A, D
  • B.C, A, B, D
  • C.B, A, D, C
  • D.D, A, C, D
Correct Answer: C, A, B, D

The Appreciative Inquiry (AI) process, developed by David Cooperrider and Suresh Shrivastava, consists of four phases: Discovery, Dream, Design, and Delivery. These phases represent the stages of the change process within an organization.

 

Here's a breakdown of each phase in the Appreciative Inquiry process:

 

1. Discovery (C): This phase involves asking the question "What might be?" It focuses on interviewing individuals within the organization to discover the positive aspects that contribute to the organization's success. Stories and insights are gathered to understand what works well and what contributes to excellence within the organization.

 

2. Dream (A): In this phase, participants collectively imagine and create a vision for the future. They articulate ideal outcomes and develop provocative propositions that define the shared vision for the organization's future. This phase taps into innovative capacities and envisions the desired future state.

 

3. Design (B): The Design phase addresses the question "How can it be?" Participants select design elements that will support the realization of the envisioned future. Roles and projects are identified, empowering participants to contribute to the detailed planning and implementation of the desired changes.

 

4. Delivery (D): The final phase involves putting the envisioned changes into action. It focuses on sustaining momentum and ensuring that the organization continues to embrace the positive changes. This phase aims to embed the appreciative mindset and practices within the organization's systems and procedures.

 

The correct sequence is C (Discovery), A (Dream), B (Design), and D (Delivery), which corresponds to option (B).

Question 40
The dynamic balance of the driving force and restraining force of change is associated with which of the following? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2019)
  • A.Force field analysis model
  • B.Force analytical model
  • C.Force field balancing model
  • D.Force field contingent model
Correct Answer: Force field analysis model

The dynamic balance of driving forces and restraining forces within organizational change is indeed associated with the Force Field Analysis model, as proposed by Kurt Lewin. This model illustrates the equilibrium between these forces and explains how change occurs in three distinct stages: Unfreezing, Moving, and Refreezing.

 

The core concepts within this model involve:

1. Driving Forces: These are the factors or influences that push for change within an organization. They facilitate change by directing behavior towards the desired outcome, causing a shift in equilibrium towards change.

2. Restraining Forces: In contrast, restraining forces are elements that resist or counteract the driving forces. They hinder change by pushing against the desired direction, causing resistance and opposition to change.

3. Equilibrium: Equilibrium represents a state where the driving forces and restraining forces are balanced, leading to a lack of change. Alterations in the balance between these forces can either facilitate or impede change within an organization.

 

The stages of change management within Lewin's model are as follows:

1. Unfreezing: This stage involves the process of letting go of old patterns or behaviors that are counterproductive. Unfreezing is crucial to overcoming individual resistance and group conformity. It's achieved by increasing driving forces away from the status quo or reducing restraining forces, or a combination of both.

2. Moving or Change: This phase focuses on implementing the actual change in thoughts, behaviors, or feelings, aiming for a more productive or liberating state.

3. Refreezing: This final stage solidifies the change as the new norm or standard procedure within the organization. Without refreezing, there's a risk of reverting to the previous state.

 

So, the dynamic balance of driving and restraining forces within the Force Field Analysis model is integral to understanding how change occurs and progresses within an organizational context.

Question 41
Arrange the given stages of process of organizational change in the correct sequence.(I) Information collection(II) Diagnosis(III) Motivation(IV) Action proposal(V) StabilizationChoose the correct answer from the options given below: [UGC NET Management June 2022]
  • A.III, II, I, IV, V
  • B.I, III, IV, V, II
  • C.IV, I, III, II, V
  • D.I, II, III, IV, V
Correct Answer: III, II, I, IV, V

The correct sequence for the stages of the process of organizational change is:

 

(III) Motivation - Engaging and motivating stakeholders for change.

(II) Diagnosis - Identifying and understanding the need for change.

(I) Information collection - Gathering relevant information.

(IV) Action proposal - Formulating a plan or proposal for implementing change.

(V) Stabilization - Ensuring the change is stabilized and integrated successfully.

 

Therefore, the correct sequence is III, II, I, IV, V, which corresponds to option (A).

Question 42
According to the book ‘The Third Wave’ which one of the following is related to third wave? (UGC NET HRM Jun 2021)
  • A.The Agricultural revolution that transformed the human history
  • B.The Industrial revolution that transformed the society
  • C.The Technological and social change that transformed organisations, societies and economies
  • D.The Environmental change that transformed the entire business world and market
Correct Answer: The Technological and social change that transformed organisations, societies and economies

The Third Wave is a 1980 book by Alvin Toffler. It is the sequel to Future Shock (1970). The book describes the transition in developed countries from Industrial Age society, which he calls the "Second Wave", to Information Age "Third Wave" society.

 

The Third Wave is the post-industrial society. Toffler says that since the late 1950s most countries have been transitioning from a Second Wave society into a Third Wave society. He coined many words to describe it and mentions names invented by others, such as the Information Age.

 

Hence, he is referring to the technological and social change that transformed organizations, societies, and economies as the ‘Third Wave’.

Question 43
One of the objectives of organizational change is: (UGC NET Commerce Dec 2014)
  • A.Increased motivation
  • B.Greater innovation
  • C.Solving inter-group problems
  • D.Changes in an organization’s level of adaptation to its environment
Correct Answer: Changes in an organization’s level of adaptation to its environment

The objective of organizational change encompasses enhancing an organization's level of adaptation to its environment. This adaptation is crucial for maintaining equilibrium amid controllable and uncontrollable forces. Organizations often undergo change due to various reasons: addressing performance gaps, adopting new technology for efficiency, identifying market opportunities for competitiveness, responding to internal and external pressures, managing mergers or acquisitions, implementing change under new leadership, following trends from other organizations, and strategic resource allocation by abandoning declining segments to focus on innovation and new prospects.

Question 44
As per Lewin's Three - Step Change Model, changing to overcome the pressures of both individual resistance and group conformity is termed as: (UGC NET Management Jun 2015)
  • A.Movement
  • B.Refreezing
  • C.Restraining
  • D.Unfreezing
Correct Answer: Unfreezing

In Lewin's Three-Step Change Model, the stage that deals with overcoming individual resistance and group conformity pressures is termed "Unfreezing." This initial step is crucial to create awareness of how the current status quo hinders the organization. Unfreezing prepares individuals for change by breaking down existing mindsets and fostering receptiveness to a new state. Following unfreezing, the change is implemented, marked by movement or transitioning into the new state. Finally, refreezing solidifies and stabilizes the new state, reinforcing the change within the organization. Lewin's model emphasizes the necessity of preparing for change, implementing it effectively, and then stabilizing the new status.

Question 45
Match the items of List-II with the items of List-I and suggest the correct code: (UGC NET Management Jul 2018)List-I (Source of resistance)(a) Perceivedperipheralityof change(b) Fear of loss of power(c) Fear of obsolescence(d) Fear of impositionList-II (Coping mechanisms)(i) Role redefinition and re-orientation(ii) Participation and involvement(iii) Participation in diagnosis(iv) Development of skills
  • A.a-(iv), b-(i), c-(iii), d-(ii)
  • B.a-(ii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(iii)
  • C.a-(iii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(ii)
  • D.a-(i), b-(iii), c-(iv), d-(ii)
Correct Answer: a-(iii), b-(i), c-(iv), d-(ii)

The various sources of resistance and the coping mechanisms include the following.

 

i) Perceived Peripherality of Change: Implementation of change can be effective if the introduced change is seen as critical and useful, which can be achieved by the participation of the concerned people in the diagnosis of the issues or problems.

ii) Perception of Imposition: When people see the change as being imposed, they tend to resist it. The resistance can be overcome by involving people in the introduction of change at several stages.

 

iii) Indifference of the Top Management: The mangers are the role models. If their attitude shows indifference, people also tend to resist change. The best way to overcome resistance is by the commitment of the leader and by his/her active support for change management.

 

iv) Vested Interests: The vested interests of people cause resistance to change. Once people experience the change, they often enjoy it and may see its positive aspects.

 

v) Complacency and Inertia: As change produces discomfort, it is resisted. The solution to the problem is to introduce the change and help people experience new conditions.

 

vi) Fear of Large Scale Disturbance: The fear that the proposed change is likely to lead to some other changes with unpredictable consequences might result in resistance. Phasing out the change could help overcome the resistance.

 

vii) Fear of Inadequate Resources: Whenever the change requires additional resources in the form of new skills, additional manpower, or budget, resistance is likely to be greater. Genuine need for the resources needs to be supported by the top management for overcoming resistance.

 

viii) Fear of Obsolescence: People resist change as they fear that they may become obsolete as they lack those skills which are required for coping with the change. Organizations should provide opportunities to those people in the development of the required skills, which could help to overcome resistance.

 

ix) Fear of Loss of Power: Any change would result in some roles in the organization to lose power. This feeling of loss of power could lead to resistance. In order to overcome this resistance, there is a need to redefine and redesign the roles.

 

x) Fear of Overload: If the change is perceived to increase the work load of people, they tend to resist the change. There is a need to bring in more of role clarity to overcome the resistance.

Quiz Attempt #118970

Total Questions: 35
Question 1
Which of the following focus of OD interventions are relevant if the nature of intervention is unstructured? (UGC NET Management Jun 2023)a. Role negotiationb. Development of internal facilitatorsc. Counsellingd. Work reviewe. Team developmentChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, c only
  • B.b, c, e only
  • C.b, c, d only
  • D.a, d, e only
Correct Answer: b, c, e only

The focus of the intervention may be on the statics (structure) or on the dynamics (process) of the organisation, or it may be on both. The nature of the intervention may be either structured or unstructured, or it may be a mixture of both. With a combination of these 3 different ways of looking at the two dimensions, we have a 3 × 3 classification table.

 

 

Development of internal facilitators: This intervention involves nurturing individuals within the organization to serve as facilitators of change and development. An unstructured approach can allow for the organic growth of these facilitators based on emerging needs.

 

Counselling: Unstructured interventions can accommodate individualized counselling sessions that address personal and professional concerns of employees in a more flexible manner.

 

Team development: Unstructured interventions can provide the necessary freedom to tailor team development activities according to the unique dynamics and needs of each team.

 

Options a and d (Role negotiation and Work review) are more structured approaches that might require specific frameworks or procedures, which might not align with an unstructured intervention approach. Therefore, the correct answer is option B i.e., b, c, e only.

Question 2
Given below are two statements: (UGC NET Management Dec 2023)Statement (I):Organisation Development Interventions are sets structured activities in which selected organisational units engage in a sequence of tasks that will lead to organisational improvement.Statement (II):The range of Organisation Development interventions is quite extensive. Interventions have been developed to solve most problems related to the human side of organisations.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both Statement I and Statement II are correct
  • B.Both Statement I and Statement II are incorrect
  • C.Statement I iscorrectbut Statement II is incorrect
  • D.Statement I isincorrectbut Statement II is correct
Correct Answer: Both Statement I and Statement II are correct

The most appropriate answer is (A) Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

 

Statement I: Organisation Development (OD) interventions indeed involve structured activities aimed at improving organizational effectiveness and performance. These interventions typically target specific organizational units or processes and are designed to bring about positive change.

 

Statement II: The range of Organisation Development interventions is indeed extensive, covering a wide array of techniques and approaches aimed at addressing various organizational issues. These interventions encompass areas such as team building, leadership development, conflict resolution, change management, and organizational culture enhancement.

 

Both statements accurately describe the nature and scope of Organisation Development interventions, highlighting their structured nature and wide applicability in addressing organizational challenges. Therefore, the correct answer is (A) Both Statement I and Statement II are correct.

Question 3
Arrange the Model of Organizational Development Process of H.M.F Rush in proper sequence from beginning to end. (UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. Problem RecognitionB. Organization diagnosisC. Feedback for change strategyD. InterventionsE. Measurement and EvaluationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.A, B, C, E, D
  • C.B, A, C, D, E
  • D.C, A, D, B, E
Correct Answer: A, B, C, E, D

The correct answer is (B) A, B, C, E, D.

A. Problem Recognition: The process begins with identifying the issues or problems that need to be addressed within the organization.

B. Organization Diagnosis: After recognizing the problem, a thorough diagnosis of the organization is conducted to understand the underlying causes and dynamics.

C. Feedback for Change Strategy: Once the diagnosis is complete, feedback is gathered to develop an appropriate change strategy.

E. Measurement and Evaluation: Following the implementation of the strategy, the next step is to measure and evaluate the effectiveness of the interventions.

D. Interventions: Finally, interventions are executed based on the feedback and evaluation, aimed at effecting the desired changes in the organization.

Question 4
Arrange the major steps ofLuthan’sO. B. Mod approach to behavioural performance management from earlier to later. (UGC NET Management Jun 2024)A. MeasureB. IdentityC. InterveneD. AnalyseE. EvaluateChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.B, C, D, E, A
  • C.A, C, B, E, D
  • D.B, A, D, C, E
Correct Answer: B, A, D, C, E

The correct sequence of the major steps in Luthan’s O.B. Mod (Organizational Behavior Modification) approach to behavioral performance management is:

B. Identify: Identify the critical behaviors that need to be changed or reinforced.

A. Measure: Measure the current frequency of these behaviors to establish a baseline.

D. Analyze: Analyze the antecedents and consequences of these behaviors to understand what influences them.

C. Intervene: Implement interventions to modify the behavior, such as reinforcement or punishment.

E. Evaluate: Evaluate the effectiveness of the intervention by measuring changes in behavior.

 

So, the correct answer is (D) B, A, D, C, E.

Question 5
Arrange the following steps of OB modification in the right sequence starting from the beginning. (UGC NET HRM Dec 2023)A. Identification of critical behavioursB. Measurement of the behavioursC. Evaluation to ensure performance improvementD. Functional analysis of the behaviourE. Development of an intervention strategyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, E, D, C
  • B.A, D, B, C, E
  • C.A, B, D, E, C
  • D.A, B, C, D, E
Correct Answer: A, B, D, E, C

The correct sequence of steps of OB modification are as follows.

 

A brief explanation of each step in the Organizational Behaviour (OB) modification process:

 

1. Identification of Critical Behaviours: This initial step involves pinpointing the specific behaviors that need to be changed or reinforced. These behaviours are typically those that significantly impact performance or outcomes within the organization.

 

2. Measurement of Behaviours: Once critical behaviours are identified, the next step is to measure them. This involves collecting data on how often these behaviours occur, their intensity, and their duration. Accurate measurement is crucial for understanding the current state and for evaluating changes over time.

 

3. Functional Analysis of Behaviours: In this step, the identified behaviours are analyzed to understand their underlying causes and effects. This involves examining the antecedents (what happens before the behaviour) and the consequences (what happens after the behaviour) to identify what triggers and reinforces these behaviours.

 

4. Development of an Intervention Strategy: Based on the functional analysis, a strategy is developed to modify the behaviours. This may include introducing new antecedents to trigger desired behaviours, providing positive reinforcement to encourage these behaviours, or implementing consequences to reduce undesired behaviours.

 

5. Evaluation: The final step involves evaluating the effectiveness of the intervention strategy. This includes monitoring changes in the targeted behaviors and assessing whether performance improvements have been achieved. Adjustments to the strategy may be made based on the evaluation results to ensure optimal outcomes.

Question 6
An Organisation Development (OD) approach that seeks to identify the unique qualities and special strengths of an organisation, which can then be built on to improve performance is called as: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2024)
  • A.Appreciative Inquiry
  • B.Process consultation
  • C.Survey Feedback
  • D.Team Building
Correct Answer: Appreciative Inquiry

The correct answer is (A) Appreciative Inquiry.

 

Appreciative Inquiry (AI) is an Organization Development (OD) approach that focuses on identifying and building upon the unique qualities, strengths, and positive aspects of an organization. Instead of focusing on problems or weaknesses, AI emphasizes exploring what works well within the organization and leveraging these strengths to improve overall performance and achieve organizational goals.

 

This approach involves engaging members of the organization in conversations that highlight past successes and areas of potential, aiming to create a positive vision for the future.

(B) Process consultation focuses on helping an organization understand and improve its processes and interactions but doesn’t specifically focus on identifying strengths.

(C) Survey Feedback is an OD method that collects feedback from employees through surveys to identify areas of improvement, but it’s more diagnostic and less focused on strengths.

(D) Team Building involves activities and exercises to improve communication, collaboration, and trust within teams but is not centered around identifying and leveraging strengths for broader organizational improvement.

 

 

Thus, Appreciative Inquiry is the OD approach that specifically seeks to identify and build on the organization’s strengths.

Question 7
Arrange the following steps in OB Mod in their right sequence: (UGC NET HRM Sep 2013)a. Identification of behavioural contingenciesb. Measurement of the behavioursc. Identification of performance related behavioursd. Evaluation of performance improvemente. Development and implementation of intervention strategy
  • A.a, c, b, e, d
  • B.c, a, b, d, e
  • C.a, d, c, b, e
  • D.c, b, a, e, d
Correct Answer: c, b, a, e, d

Reinforcement principles are applied in managerial settings through the Organizational Behavior Modification (OB Mod) process, which typically involves a structured five-step problem-solving model:

 

1. Identifying critical behaviors: Not all employee actions have an equal impact on job performance. Hence, it's crucial to identify behaviors that significantly influence job performance.

 

2. Establishing baseline data: This step involves managers determining how frequently the identified behavior occurs under existing conditions.

 

3. Recognizing behavioral consequences: Conducting a functional analysis helps pinpoint the contingencies or outcomes associated with performance. This analysis reveals the cues prompting the behavior and the current consequences maintaining it.

 

4. Creating and executing an intervention strategy: Implementing an appropriate intervention strategy aims to alter aspects of the performance-reward system, making high-level performance more rewarding.

 

5. Assessing performance improvement: Evaluating the observed behavioral changes ensures that learning has taken place and measures the effectiveness of the interventions implemented.

 

The correct sequence of steps in OB Mod is as follows:

c. Identification of performance-related behaviors

b. Measurement of the behaviors

a. Identification of behavioral contingencies

e. Development and implementation of intervention strategy

d. Evaluation of performance improvement

Question 8
Match the following Behavioural Scientists with their areas of contribution: (UGC NET HRM Dec 2009)Scientists(i) Charles L. Hulin and Milton R. Blood(ii) Blake and Mouton(iii) Eric Berne(iv)BeckhardRAreas of Contribution(a) Transactional Analysis(b) Organisational Development(c) Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scale (BARS)(d) Managerial Grid
  • A.i-(c), ii-(d), iii-(a), iv-(b)
  • B.i-(c), ii-(a), iii-(b), iv-(d)
  • C.i-(a), ii-(c), iii-(b), iv-(d)
  • D.i-(d), ii-(b), iii-(a), iv-(c)
Correct Answer: i-(c), ii-(d), iii-(a), iv-(b)

(i) Charles L. Hulin and Milton R. Blood - Behaviourally Anchored Rating Scale (BARS)

The BARS (behaviorally anchored rating scales) by Charles L. Hulin and Milton R. Blood,  method of evaluating employees carries typical job appraisals one step further. Instead of relying on behaviors that can be appraised in any position in a company, the BARS method bases evaluations on specific behaviors required for each individual position in an individual company.  

 

(ii) Blake and Mouton - Managerial Grid

Managerial Grid: Robert Blake and Jane Mouton (1960s) proposed a graphic portrayal of leadership styles through a managerial grid (sometimes called leadership grid). The grid depicted two dimensions of leader behavior, “concern for people” (accommodating people’s needs and giving them priority) on y-axis and “concern for production” (keeping tight schedules) on x-axis, with each dimension ranging from low (1) to high (9), thus creating 81 different positions in which the leader’s style may fall. 

 

(iii) Eric Berne - Transactional Analysis
