Correct Answer: Resident but not ordinarily resident in India

Basic Conditions to test as to when an individual is resident in India:

An individual is said to be a resident in India in any previous year, if he fulfils at least one of the following 2 basic conditions [Section 6(1)]:

Basic condition (a): He is in India in the previous year for a period of 182 days or more.

OR

Basic condition (b): He is in India for a period of 60 days or more during the previous year AND 365 days or more during the 4 years immediately preceding the previous year.

 

Bret Lee satisfies the second basic condition because he is in India for more than 60 days during the relevant previous year and for 400 days during four years preceding the relevant previous year. Therefore, he is a resident.

 

Additional Conditions to test as to when a resident individual is Ordinarily Resident in India:

A resident individual is treated as resident and ordinarily resident in India if he satisfies both of the 2 additional conditions:

Additional Condition 1: He has been resident in India in at least 2 out of 10 previous years immediately preceding the relevant previous year;

AND

Additional Condition 2: He has been in India for a period of 730 days or more during the 7 years immediately preceding the relevant previous year.

 

Therefore, it can be said that an individual becomes resident and ordinarily resident in India, if he satisfies at least one of the basic conditions (i.e. (a) or (b)) and the two additional conditions (i.e., 1 and 2). In case resident satisfies any one of the above conditions, he is said to be a resident but not ordinarily resident in India (RNOR).

 

In the given case of Bret Lee, although he satisfies the first additional condition of being resident for at least 2 out of 10 preceding previous years but he does not satisfy the second additional condition as during 7 years preceding the previous year, he is in India for only 700 days. He shall, therefore, be a resident but not ordinarily resident in India (RNOR).

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 67
Which one of the following sections of the Income Tax Act, 1961 defines method for computing Arm’s Length Price?
  • A.90C
  • B.91C
  • C.92C
  • D.93C
Correct Answer: 92C

Section 92C of the Income Tax Act, 1961 deals with the method for determining arm’s length price and the factors which are to be considered for applicability or non-applicability of a particular method to a given situation.

Question 68
Which of the following statements are correct?A. Call-in-advance is the amount paid by the shareholdersin excess ofthe amount due from them.B. When the number of shares applied is more than the number of shares offered to the public for subscription, the issue is termed asunder-subscription.C. Section 49 of the Companies Act prohibits the issue of shares other than sweat equity shares at a discount.D. Unless or until the forfeited shares are re-issued, the balance on the shares forfeited account will be deducted from the paid-up capital.E. The securities premium is an amountin excess ofthe nominal value of the face value of the securities.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and E Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.A, B and C Only
  • D.A, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A and E Only

Explanation of Each Statement:

 

A. Call-in-advance is the amount paid by the shareholders in excess of the amount due from them. ✅ (Correct)

If shareholders pay more than the required amount before it is called, it is recorded as Call-in-Advance in the company's books.

 

B. When the number of shares applied is more than the number of shares offered to the public for subscription, the issue is termed as under-subscription. ❌ (Incorrect)

Over-subscription occurs when the number of shares applied is more than the shares offered.

Under-subscription happens when the number of shares applied is less than the shares issued.

 

C. Section 49 of the Companies Act prohibits the issue of shares other than sweat equity shares at a discount. ❌ (Incorrect)

Section 53 of the Companies Act, 2013 prohibits issuing shares at a discount, except for sweat equity shares.

 

D. Unless or until the forfeited shares are re-issued, the balance on the shares forfeited account will be deducted from the paid-up capital. ❌ (Incorrect)

The amount from forfeited shares is recorded as a liability until re-issued, but it is not deducted from paid-up capital.

 

E. The securities premium is an amount in excess of the nominal value of the face value of the securities. ✅ (Correct)

Securities Premium is the amount charged above the face value when shares are issued at a premium.

Question 69
When the price of good X rises, the demand for substitute good Y will:
  • A.Rise
  • B.Fall
  • C.Remain unchanged
  • D.Falls initially and then rises
Correct Answer: Rise

When the price of Good X rises, consumers tend to reduce their consumption of Good X and look for substitutes, such as Good Y. Since Good Y is a substitute, more consumers will switch to buying Good Y instead of Good X. This results in an increase in the demand for Good Y.

Question 70
Determine the P/V ratio from the following particulars:Total Fixed Cost = Rs 12,000Actual Sales = Rs 48,000Margin of Safety = Rs 8,000
  • A.20%
  • B.25%
  • C.30%
  • D.40%
Correct Answer: 30%

Breakeven sales = Sales – Margin of safety = 48000-8000 = Rs 40,000

Fixed Costs = Rs 12000

P/V Ratio = Fixed Costs / Breakeven sales = 12,000/40,000 = 30%

Question 71
Which of the following are the features of F.E.M.A?A. Central government can regulate payments to and from a person situated outside the country.B. Holding of immovable property outside India is restricted.C. R.B.I can restrict the transaction from capital account even if it is done by an authorized person.D. All foreign financial transactions are to bedonethrough F.E.M.A authorized person.E. F.E.M.A applies to Indian citizens living abroad.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C Only
  • B.B, D, E Only
  • C.A, B, E Only
  • D.A, C, D Only
Correct Answer: A, C, D Only

Statement B is wrong because, according to section 6(4) of the FEMA, a person resident in India can hold, own, transfer or invest in any immovable property situated outside India if such property was acquired, held or owned by him/ her when he/ she was resident outside India or inherited from a person resident outside India.

 

Statement E is wrong because FEMA (Foreign Exchange Management Act) is applicable to the whole of India and equally applicable to the agencies and offices located outside India (which are owned or managed by an Indian Citizen).

Question 72
Which of the following statements are true regarding the buying dynamics of individual consumers?(A) To successfully compete in the market and create customer value, managers must fully understand the reality rather than the theory of consumer behavior.(B) In marketing, perceptions are more important than reality because they affect consumers' actual behavior.(C) People emerge with the same perceptions of the same object.(D) Consumers are constructive decision-makers and are subject to many contextual influences.(E) A consumer's buying behavior is influenced by cultural, social, and personal tactics. Among these, personal factors exert the broadest and deepest influence on people's perception and desires.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, D Only
  • B.A, B, D Only
  • C.A, C, E Only
  • D.B, C, D, E Only
Correct Answer: B, D Only

Consumer behavior is influenced by psychological, social, cultural, and personal factors that determine how individuals make purchasing decisions. Let's analyze each statement:

 

(A) To successfully compete in the market and create customer value, managers must fully understand the reality rather than the theory of consumer behavior. ❌ (Incorrect)

While understanding consumer behavior is essential, both theory and practical reality matter in marketing decisions. Marketing strategies are based on behavioral theories, research, and real-world insights.

 

(B) In marketing, perceptions are more important than reality because they affect consumers' actual behavior. ✅ (Correct)

Consumer perception drives decision-making more than actual product quality. A consumer's perception of value, brand image, and experience influences their purchase decisions.

 

(C) People emerge with the same perceptions of the same object. ❌ (Incorrect)

Perception varies from person to person based on experiences, beliefs, and cultural influences. Consumers interpret the same product differently.

 

(D) Consumers are constructive decision-makers and are subject to many contextual influences. ✅ (Correct)

Contextual influences such as social norms, marketing messages, economic conditions, and peer pressure shape purchasing behavior.

 

(E) A consumer's buying behavior is influenced by cultural, social, and personal factors. Among these, personal factors exert the broadest and deepest influence on people's perception and desires. ❌ (Incorrect)

Cultural factors (such as values, traditions, and societal norms) have a broader and deeper influence on consumer behavior than personal factors.

Question 73
Which of the following research designs is the most precise one?
  • A.Experimental
  • B.Exploratory
  • C.Diagnostic
  • D.Descriptive
Correct Answer: Experimental

Among the different research designs, Experimental Research is the most precise because it establishes causal relationships through controlled conditions.

 

Experimental research involves manipulating variables and observing the effects under controlled conditions. It provides high accuracy and reliability because of the ability to control extraneous variables and establish cause-and-effect relationships.

Question 74
Which one of the following is not the behavioral factor of the customer profile involved in tactical targeting?
  • A.Purchase Frequency
  • B.Income
  • C.Purchase Quantity
  • D.Price Sensitivity
Correct Answer: Income

Tactical Targeting involves segmenting customers based on their behavioral factors, which refer to how consumers interact with a product or service. These include purchase patterns, price sensitivity, and usage behavior.

 

(A) Purchase Frequency ✅ (Behavioral Factor)

How often a customer buys a product is a key behavioral factor in targeting.

 

(B) Income ❌ (Not a Behavioral Factor – Correct Answer)

Income is a demographic factor, not a behavioral one. It affects purchasing power but does not indicate behavior directly.

 

(C) Purchase Quantity ✅ (Behavioral Factor)

The volume of purchases made by a customer reflects their buying behavior.

 

(D) Price Sensitivity ✅ (Behavioral Factor)

How a customer responds to price changes is a behavioral characteristic influencing purchasing decisions.

Question 75
Which one of the following refers to the composition of long-term funds such as debentures, long-term borrowing, preference shares, and equity shares in the capitalization of a company?
  • A.Cost of Capital
  • B.Capital Budgeting
  • C.Working Capital
  • D.Capital Structure
Correct Answer: Capital Structure

The composition of long-term funds such as debentures, long-term borrowing, preference shares, and equity shares in a company’s capitalization is referred to as the Capital Structure.

Question 76
Which of the following is not a monetary measure for correcting disequilibrium in the Balance of Payment?
  • A.Monetary Contraction
  • B.Devaluation
  • C.Exchange Control
  • D.Abolition of Export Duties
Correct Answer: Abolition of Export Duties

To correct disequilibrium in the Balance of Payments (BoP), governments and central banks use monetary measures and non-monetary measures.

 

(A) Monetary Contraction ✅ (Monetary Measure)

Reducing money supply and credit availability helps control inflation and improves the BoP.

 

(B) Devaluation ✅ (Monetary Measure)

Devaluation reduces the value of the domestic currency, making exports cheaper and imports more expensive, which helps improve the BoP.

 

(C) Exchange Control ✅ (Monetary Measure)

Governments regulate foreign exchange transactions to control the outflow of foreign currency and manage BoP deficits.

 

Non-Monetary Measure:

(D) Abolition of Export Duties ❌ (Not a Monetary Measure – Correct Answer)

This is a trade policy, not a monetary measure.

Export duties are a part of fiscal policy, and their removal encourages exports but does not directly affect money supply or credit control.

Question 77
A contract of indemnity is a:
  • A.Wagering Agreement
  • B.Quasi Contract
  • C.Void Contract
  • D.Contingent Contract
Correct Answer: Contingent Contract

A contract of indemnity is a contract in which one party promises to compensate the other for loss suffered due to the conduct of the promisor or a third party.

 

According to Section 124 of the Indian Contract Act, 1872, a contract of indemnity is a contingent contract because the obligation to indemnify arises only upon the happening of a specific event (i.e., a loss or damage).

Question 78
Which one of the following structures of the marketing department will be most suitable for companies that produce many products for many markets?
  • A.Geographic Organization
  • B.Product or Brand Organization
  • C.Functional Organization
  • D.Matrix Organization
Correct Answer: Matrix Organization

When a company produces many products for many markets, it requires a flexible and multidimensional organizational structure that can efficiently manage both product lines and market segments.

 

 

(A) Geographic Organization ❌ (Incorrect)

This structure is based on regional divisions, useful for companies operating in different geographical locations but not necessarily managing multiple products.

 

(B) Product or Brand Organization ❌ (Incorrect)

This structure is suitable for companies with diverse product lines, but it does not effectively address the complexity of serving multiple markets.

 

(C) Functional Organization ❌ (Incorrect)

This structure is based on specialized functions (e.g., sales, advertising, product development) and is more suitable for companies with fewer products.

 

(D) Matrix Organization ✅ (Correct)

Matrix structure is the best for companies producing many products for many markets because it integrates product management with regional or market-based strategies.

It allows dual reporting where employees report to both product managers and market (geographic or customer segment) managers.

Question 79
Which one of the following conditions is not true in case of marketing skimming as the pricing objective?
  • A.The market is highly price-sensitive
  • B.A sufficient number ofbuyerssignala high demand
  • C.The high initial price does not attract more competitors to the market
  • D.The high price communicates the image of a superior product
Correct Answer: The market is highly price-sensitive

Market Skimming Pricing is a strategy where a company sets a high initial price for a new or innovative product and gradually lowers it over time. This approach helps maximize early profits from customers willing to pay a premium before attracting more price-sensitive buyers.

Question 80
Arrange the following points step by step regarding the computation of Gross Total Income.(A) Computation of Gross Total Income(B) Set off and carry forward of Losses(C) Clubbing of Income of spouse, minor child, etc.(D) Computation of Income under each head of Income(E) Determination of Residential StatusChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, D, C, B, A
  • B.A, B, C, D, E
  • C.C, D, E, A, B
  • D.B, C, D, E, A
Correct Answer: E, D, C, B, A

The correct order of steps to compute Gross Total Income is as follows:

1. Determination of Residential Status

2. Computation of Income under each head of Income

3. Clubbing of Income of spouse, minor child, etc.

4. Set off and carry forward of Losses

5. Computation of Gross Total Income

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 81
Match the LIST-I with LIST-IILIST-I (Direct Material cost variance)A. Direct material cost varianceB. Direct material price varianceC. Direct material usage varianceD. Direct material mix varianceLIST-II (Formula)I. Standard price × (Revised standard quantity-Actual Quantity)II. Standard price × (Standard Quantity for actual output quantity-Actual Quantity)III. Actual Quantity × (Standard Price-Actual Price)IV. Standard cost for actual output-actual costChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • B.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
  • C.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • D.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I

Direct Material Cost Variance (MCV) is the difference between the standard cost of materials for actual output and the actual cost incurred. It can be further divided into price variance, usage variance, and mix variance.

 

A. Direct Material Cost Variance → (IV)

Formula: Standard cost for actual output − Actual cost

This calculates the total difference between expected and actual material costs.

 

B. Direct Material Price Variance → (III)

Formula:

Actual Quantity × (Standard Price − Actual Price)

This shows the impact of price changes on material cost.

 

C. Direct Material Usage Variance → (II)

Formula:

Standard Price × (Standard Quantity for actual output − Actual Quantity)

This measures how efficiently materials are used.

 

D. Direct Material Mix Variance → (I)

Formula:

Standard Price × (Revised Standard Quantity − Actual Quantity)

This evaluates the effect of changes in material composition.

Question 82
Which section of the Income Tax Act 1961 mentions unilateral relief?
  • A.90
  • B.89
  • C.91
  • D.92
Correct Answer: 91

Unilateral relief under the Income Tax Act, 1961 is provided under Section 91.

 

Under this method, relief is provided by home country, irrespective of any agreement with the country concerned. This kind of relief exists because bilateral agreements might not be sufficient to meet all the cases. In India, Section 91 of the Income Tax Act, 1961 provides such relief. In other words, where Section 90 does not apply, relief under Section 91 will be available. Unilateral relief is only available in respect of doubly taxed income, that is part of income which is included in assessee’s total income.

Question 83
Which one of the following isa value-added service of EXIM Bank?
  • A.Export Facilitation
  • B.Export Product Development
  • C.Workshops and Seminars
  • D.Export Marketing
Correct Answer: Workshops and Seminars

EXIM Bank (Export-Import Bank of India) provides various financial and non-financial services to promote international trade. Value-added services refer to non-financial support such as knowledge-sharing, capacity-building, and skill development.

 

(A) Export Facilitation ❌ (Incorrect)

This refers to financial support and trade facilitation, such as providing credit lines and guarantees.

 

(B) Export Product Development ❌ (Incorrect)

This involves financing research and development (R&D) to enhance product competitiveness in global markets.

 

(C) Workshops and Seminars ✅ (Correct)

EXIM Bank organizes workshops and seminars to educate exporters on trade policies, risk management, and market trends.

This is a value-added service as it provides knowledge and training rather than direct financial support.

 

(D) Export Marketing ❌ (Incorrect)

This refers to promotional and market-entry strategies, which are directly related to trade operations rather than additional value-added services.

Question 84
Arrange the following levels of economic integration in increasing order.A. Political UnionB. Free Trade AreaC. Customs UnionD. Common MarketE. Economic UnionChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C, D, E, A
  • B.B, A, C, D, E
  • C.B, A, D, C, E
  • D.E, D, B, A, C
Correct Answer: B, C, D, E, A

Economic integration refers to the process where countries coordinate and link their economic policies, trade, and markets to reduce trade barriers and increase cooperation. The levels of integration range from least integrated to most integrated.

 

Levels of Economic Integration in Increasing Order:

 

Free Trade Area (B) → Least Integrated

Countries remove tariffs and trade restrictions among themselves but maintain their own policies toward non-member countries.

 

Customs Union (C)

In addition to a free trade area, countries adopt a common external tariff on imports from non-member countries.

 

Common Market (D)

Goes beyond a customs union by allowing free movement of labor and capital between member countries.

 

Economic Union (E)

A common market with harmonized economic policies, including taxation, monetary policy, and currency union in some cases.

 

Political Union (A) → Most Integrated

Countries fully integrate their economic and political policies under a single government or authority.

Question 85
Which one of the following is not a social network of social media platforms?
  • A.Facebook
  • B.Blogs
  • C.Twitter
  • D.YouTube
Correct Answer: Blogs

Blogs are content-sharing platforms rather than social networking platforms. Social networks like Facebook, Twitter, and YouTube focus on user interactions, connections, and content sharing, whereas blogs primarily serve as personal or professional publishing platforms without a direct social networking structure.

Question 86
Arrange the practical steps involved in the preparation of a process account where there is work in progress.A. Prepare process accountB. Prepare statement of evaluationC. Prepare statement of cost per equivalent unitD. Prepare statement of equivalent productionE. Determine and analyze the number of physical units in the form of inputs (transferred from the previous process) and outputChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.E, D, C, B, A
  • C.C, D, E, A, B
  • D.B, C, D, A, E
Correct Answer: E, D, C, B, A

When preparing a process account with work in progress, the steps should be logically sequenced to ensure an accurate calculation of costs and production.

 

Steps in Logical Order:

Determine and analyze the number of physical units in the form of inputs (E): Identify the units introduced into the process and analyze the input and output quantities.

Prepare a statement of equivalent production (D): Since work-in-progress exists, we must convert partially completed units into equivalent full units.

Prepare a statement of cost per equivalent unit (C): Compute the cost per unit based on equivalent production and total costs.

Prepare a statement of evaluation (B): Evaluate the total cost incurred and allocate it to completed units and closing WIP.

Prepare the process account (A): Finally, record all inputs, costs, outputs, and losses in the process account.

Question 87
Which one of the following conditions is not true as per the IRDA Act, 1999, for the entry of private players into the insurance market?
  • A.The company’s sole purpose is to carry on life insurance business or general insurance business or reinsurance business.
  • B.The minimum paid-up equity capital for life insurance or general insurance business is ₹100 crore.
  • C.The minimum paid-up capital forcarryingreinsurance business is ₹300 crore.
  • D.Insurance companies are required to invest not less than 15 percent of their funds in infrastructure and social sectors.
Correct Answer: The minimum paid-up capital forcarryingreinsurance business is ₹300 crore.

Option C is incorrect because the minimum paid-up capital for carrying reinsurance business is ₹200 crore.

Question 88
The Securities Exchange Board of India (SEBI) regulates and supervises the securities throughA. RegulationsB. RulesC. GuidelinesD. SchemeE. OrdersChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, E Only
  • B.B, C, D Only
  • C.A, B, C, D, E
  • D.A, C, D, E Only
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D, E

The correct answer is A, B, C, D, E.

Question 89
Arrange the following actions of a manager in the increasing degree of control.A. Manager defines limits and asks for group decisionsB. Manager offers tentative decisions to changeC. Manager sells decisionsD. Manager lets subordinates function within limits defined by himE. Manager presents problems, invites suggestions, and makes decisionsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D, B, E, C
  • B.C, B, E, A, D
  • C.D, A, E, B, C
  • D.D, A, B, E, C
Correct Answer: D, A, E, B, C

The degree of managerial control increases as the manager moves from giving more autonomy to employees toward more directive control:

D (Manager lets subordinates function within limits defined by him) – Least control; employees have significant autonomy.

A (Manager defines limits and asks for group decisions) – Some control, as employees make decisions within set boundaries.

E (Manager presents problems, invites suggestions, and makes decisions) – More control, as the manager makes the final decision.

B (Manager offers tentative decisions to change) – Higher control, as the manager suggests decisions but allows some modification.

C (Manager sells decisions) – Highest control, as the manager decides and persuades employees to follow.

Question 90
Prepaid Insurance is which type of account?
  • A.Real Account
  • B.Personal Account
  • C.Nominal Account
  • D.Real and Nominal Both
Correct Answer: Personal Account

Personal accounts include accounts related to individuals, companies, and representative accounts (accounts that represent expenses or liabilities). Prepaid expenses (like Prepaid Insurance) are treated as representative personal accounts because they represent payments made in advance on behalf of the company.

Question 91
Which of the following refers to an attempt to avoid payment of taxes by using illegal means?
  • A.Tax Management
  • B.Tax Planning
  • C.Tax Avoidance
  • D.Tax Evasion
Correct Answer: Tax Evasion

Taxation involves different strategies that individuals and businesses use to minimize their tax liability. The key distinction is whether the approach is legal or illegal.

 

(A) Tax Management ❌ (Incorrect)

Tax Management refers to the lawful and efficient administration of tax matters, including timely filing of returns and compliance with tax laws.

 

(B) Tax Planning ❌ (Incorrect)

Tax Planning is a legal way to minimize tax liability by taking advantage of permissible deductions, exemptions, and incentives under the tax laws.

 

(C) Tax Avoidance ❌ (Incorrect)

Tax Avoidance refers to minimizing tax liability legally but in a way that exploits loopholes in the tax system. While it is not illegal, it is often considered unethical.

(D) Tax Evasion ✅ (Correct)

Tax Evasion refers to the illegal act of avoiding tax payments by misrepresenting or concealing income, inflating expenses, or using fraudulent methods.

Question 92
Comprehension:The first phase of modern banking in India began after independence in 1947, when the government nationalized the major banks and introduced various reforms to promote financial inclusion and social welfare. The second phase started in the 1990s, when the liberalization of the economy and the advent of technology enabled the emergence of new private and foreign banks, offering competitive and innovative products and services to the customers. In the 2000s, the third phase commenced when the Internet and mobile penetration increased, leading to the rise of online and mobile banking, as well as the entry of Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) and fintech startups, offering digital solutions to cater to the unbanked and underbanked segments of the population. The fourth and current phase of banking in India is characterized by the emergence of neo banks, which are digital-only banks that operate without physical branches and offer a range of banking and financial services through mobile apps and web platforms. Neo banks often function by partnering with licensed banks to provide their services to customers.While the digital banking landscape in India is evolving rapidly, there are still many challenges and gaps that need to be addressed. One of the major challenges is the lack of standardization and interoperability among the various players, platforms, and systems in the ecosystem. For instance, there are multiple payment methods, such as UPI, IMPS, NEFT, RTGS, cards, wallets, and QR codes, each with its own features, limitations, and charges. This creates confusion and inconvenience for customers, whohave toswitch between different apps and interfaces to make payments and access their accounts.Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a potent technology that can help digital banks to overcome the challenges and gaps mentionedabove, andadd value to their customers and stakeholders. AI can enable digital banks to leverage data and analytics, machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, and other advanced techniques to automate and enhance various banking processes, such as customer identification and verification, customer service and support, product recommendation and cross-selling, fraud detection and risk management, credit scoring and underwriting, and regulatory compliance and reporting.What is one of the major challenges in the digital banking landscape in India?
  • A.Lack of internet penetration
  • B.Overabundance of physical branches
  • C.Lack of standardization and interoperability
  • D.Over-regulation by the government
Correct Answer: Lack of standardization and interoperability

The digital banking ecosystem in India has multiple payment methods and platforms that are not standardized, leading to confusion and inconvenience for customers.

Question 93
Comprehension:The first phase of modern banking in India began after independence in 1947, when the government nationalized the major banks and introduced various reforms to promote financial inclusion and social welfare. The second phase started in the 1990s, when the liberalization of the economy and the advent of technology enabled the emergence of new private and foreign banks, offering competitive and innovative products and services to the customers. In the 2000s, the third phase commenced when the Internet and mobile penetration increased, leading to the rise of online and mobile banking, as well as the entry of Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) and fintech startups, offering digital solutions to cater to the unbanked and underbanked segments of the population. The fourth and current phase of banking in India is characterized by the emergence of neo banks, which are digital-only banks that operate without physical branches and offer a range of banking and financial services through mobile apps and web platforms. Neo banks often function by partnering with licensed banks to provide their services to customers.While the digital banking landscape in India is evolving rapidly, there are still many challenges and gaps that need to be addressed. One of the major challenges is the lack of standardization and interoperability among the various players, platforms, and systems in the ecosystem. For instance, there are multiple payment methods, such as UPI, IMPS, NEFT, RTGS, cards, wallets, and QR codes, each with its own features, limitations, and charges. This creates confusion and inconvenience for customers, whohave toswitch between different apps and interfaces to make payments and access their accounts.Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a potent technology that can help digital banks to overcome the challenges and gaps mentionedabove, andadd value to their customers and stakeholders. AI can enable digital banks to leverage data and analytics, machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, and other advanced techniques to automate and enhance various banking processes, such as customer identification and verification, customer service and support, product recommendation and cross-selling, fraud detection and risk management, credit scoring and underwriting, and regulatory compliance and reporting.What marked the beginning of the second phase of modern banking in India?
  • A.Nationalization of major banks
  • B.Liberalization of the economy
  • C.Emergence of fintech startups
  • D.Introduction of Internet banking
Correct Answer: Liberalization of the economy

The second phase started in the 1990s when India liberalized its economy, allowing private and foreign banks to enter and offer competitive banking services.

Question 94
Comprehension:The first phase of modern banking in India began after independence in 1947, when the government nationalized the major banks and introduced various reforms to promote financial inclusion and social welfare. The second phase started in the 1990s, when the liberalization of the economy and the advent of technology enabled the emergence of new private and foreign banks, offering competitive and innovative products and services to the customers. In the 2000s, the third phase commenced when the Internet and mobile penetration increased, leading to the rise of online and mobile banking, as well as the entry of Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) and fintech startups, offering digital solutions to cater to the unbanked and underbanked segments of the population. The fourth and current phase of banking in India is characterized by the emergence of neo banks, which are digital-only banks that operate without physical branches and offer a range of banking and financial services through mobile apps and web platforms. Neo banks often function by partnering with licensed banks to provide their services to customers.While the digital banking landscape in India is evolving rapidly, there are still many challenges and gaps that need to be addressed. One of the major challenges is the lack of standardization and interoperability among the various players, platforms, and systems in the ecosystem. For instance, there are multiple payment methods, such as UPI, IMPS, NEFT, RTGS, cards, wallets, and QR codes, each with its own features, limitations, and charges. This creates confusion and inconvenience for customers, whohave toswitch between different apps and interfaces to make payments and access their accounts.Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a potent technology that can help digital banks to overcome the challenges and gaps mentionedabove, andadd value to their customers and stakeholders. AI can enable digital banks to leverage data and analytics, machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, and other advanced techniques to automate and enhance various banking processes, such as customer identification and verification, customer service and support, product recommendation and cross-selling, fraud detection and risk management, credit scoring and underwriting, and regulatory compliance and reporting.How can artificial intelligence (AI) help digital banks to overcome challenges?
  • A.By reducing internet penetration
  • B.By increasing physical branches
  • C.By providing advanced analytics
  • D.By reducing customer base
Correct Answer: By providing advanced analytics

AI enables banks to leverage data analytics, machine learning, and automation to enhance customer services, fraud detection, and risk management.

Question 95
Comprehension:The first phase of modern banking in India began after independence in 1947, when the government nationalized the major banks and introduced various reforms to promote financial inclusion and social welfare. The second phase started in the 1990s, when the liberalization of the economy and the advent of technology enabled the emergence of new private and foreign banks, offering competitive and innovative products and services to the customers. In the 2000s, the third phase commenced when the Internet and mobile penetration increased, leading to the rise of online and mobile banking, as well as the entry of Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) and fintech startups, offering digital solutions to cater to the unbanked and underbanked segments of the population. The fourth and current phase of banking in India is characterized by the emergence of neo banks, which are digital-only banks that operate without physical branches and offer a range of banking and financial services through mobile apps and web platforms. Neo banks often function by partnering with licensed banks to provide their services to customers.While the digital banking landscape in India is evolving rapidly, there are still many challenges and gaps that need to be addressed. One of the major challenges is the lack of standardization and interoperability among the various players, platforms, and systems in the ecosystem. For instance, there are multiple payment methods, such as UPI, IMPS, NEFT, RTGS, cards, wallets, and QR codes, each with its own features, limitations, and charges. This creates confusion and inconvenience for customers, whohave toswitch between different apps and interfaces to make payments and access their accounts.Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a potent technology that can help digital banks to overcome the challenges and gaps mentionedabove, andadd value to their customers and stakeholders. AI can enable digital banks to leverage data and analytics, machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, and other advanced techniques to automate and enhance various banking processes, such as customer identification and verification, customer service and support, product recommendation and cross-selling, fraud detection and risk management, credit scoring and underwriting, and regulatory compliance and reporting.What is the primary focus of neo banks in India?
  • A.Offering physical branch services
  • B.Catering to the unbanked and underbanked segments
  • C.Providing traditional banking services
  • D.Emphasizing paper-based transactions
Correct Answer: Catering to the unbanked and underbanked segments

Neo banks operate digitally and partner with licensed banks to provide financial services, focusing on segments that lack access to traditional banking.

Question 96
Comprehension:The first phase of modern banking in India began after independence in 1947, when the government nationalized the major banks and introduced various reforms to promote financial inclusion and social welfare. The second phase started in the 1990s, when the liberalization of the economy and the advent of technology enabled the emergence of new private and foreign banks, offering competitive and innovative products and services to the customers. In the 2000s, the third phase commenced when the Internet and mobile penetration increased, leading to the rise of online and mobile banking, as well as the entry of Non-Banking Financial Companies (NBFCs) and fintech startups, offering digital solutions to cater to the unbanked and underbanked segments of the population. The fourth and current phase of banking in India is characterized by the emergence of neo banks, which are digital-only banks that operate without physical branches and offer a range of banking and financial services through mobile apps and web platforms. Neo banks often function by partnering with licensed banks to provide their services to customers.While the digital banking landscape in India is evolving rapidly, there are still many challenges and gaps that need to be addressed. One of the major challenges is the lack of standardization and interoperability among the various players, platforms, and systems in the ecosystem. For instance, there are multiple payment methods, such as UPI, IMPS, NEFT, RTGS, cards, wallets, and QR codes, each with its own features, limitations, and charges. This creates confusion and inconvenience for customers, whohave toswitch between different apps and interfaces to make payments and access their accounts.Artificial Intelligence (AI) is a potent technology that can help digital banks to overcome the challenges and gaps mentionedabove, andadd value to their customers and stakeholders. AI can enable digital banks to leverage data and analytics, machine learning, natural language processing, computer vision, and other advanced techniques to automate and enhance various banking processes, such as customer identification and verification, customer service and support, product recommendation and cross-selling, fraud detection and risk management, credit scoring and underwriting, and regulatory compliance and reporting.What is a consequence of the lack of standardization and interoperability in the digital banking ecosystem?
  • A.Convenience for customers
  • B.Increased trust in digital banking
  • C.Confusion and inconvenience for customers
  • D.Reduction in transaction costs
Correct Answer: Confusion and inconvenience for customers

The presence of multiple payment systems with different features and limitations forces customers to switch between platforms, leading to confusion and inconvenience for customers.

Question 97
Comprehension:The major source for the revenue for the government is indirect tax. The Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (CBIC) (erstwhile Central Board of Excise and Customs) is the apex regulatory body that supervises the levy and administration of Indirect Taxes in India. CBIC is a part of the Department of Revenue under the Ministry of Finance, Government of India. It deals with the tasks of formulation of policy concerning levy and collection of customs, Central Excise duties, Central Goods & Services Tax and IGST, prevention of smuggling and administration of matter relating to customs, Central Excise, Central Goods & Services Tax (CGST), IGST and narcotics to the extent under CBIC’s purview. The Board is the administrative authority for its subordinate organizations, including Custom Houses, Central Excise and Central GST Commissionerate’s and the Central Revenue Control Laboratory.In recent years, the Indian government has undertaken significant reforms under the indirect taxation system. This includes the implementation of Goods and Services Tax (GST). Goods and Services Tax (GST) is an indirect tax has replaced many indirect taxes in India. The Goods and Services Tax Act was passed in the Parliament on March 29, 2017. This Act came into effect on July 01, 2017. GST is adestination basedtax on consumption with credit of taxes paid at previous stages available as set-off. In nutshell, only value addition will betaxedand the burden of tax is to be borne by the final consumer.Destination based tax on consumption means the tax would accrue to the taxing authority which has jurisdiction over the place of consumption which is also termed as place of supply. GST has removed the cascading effect of taxes. This cascading effect implies charging tax on tax. In other words, at the time of levy of tax, the total value is considered which is inclusive of all taxes paid up to the points. In this manner, if the tax is always charged on the selling price of the products, the burden of tax keeps on increasing at each point of sales. In this process, the effect of taxation magnifies as at each level tax is calculated on value, which includes taxes already levied and paid. The charging of tax on tax is called the “Cascading Effect of Tax”.What is the significance of the term "destination-based tax" in the context of GST?
  • A.Tax is levied based on the destination of goods only
  • B.Tax is levied based on the origin of goods
  • C.Tax is collected at the point of sale
  • D.Tax accrues to the taxing authority at the place of consumption
Correct Answer: Tax accrues to the taxing authority at the place of consumption

GST is a destination-based tax, meaning the tax revenue goes to the state where the goods or services are consumed rather than the state of origin.

Question 98
Comprehension:The major source for the revenue for the government is indirect tax. The Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (CBIC) (erstwhile Central Board of Excise and Customs) is the apex regulatory body that supervises the levy and administration of Indirect Taxes in India. CBIC is a part of the Department of Revenue under the Ministry of Finance, Government of India. It deals with the tasks of formulation of policy concerning levy and collection of customs, Central Excise duties, Central Goods & Services Tax and IGST, prevention of smuggling and administration of matter relating to customs, Central Excise, Central Goods & Services Tax (CGST), IGST and narcotics to the extent under CBIC’s purview. The Board is the administrative authority for its subordinate organizations, including Custom Houses, Central Excise and Central GST Commissionerate’s and the Central Revenue Control Laboratory.In recent years, the Indian government has undertaken significant reforms under the indirect taxation system. This includes the implementation of Goods and Services Tax (GST). Goods and Services Tax (GST) is an indirect tax has replaced many indirect taxes in India. The Goods and Services Tax Act was passed in the Parliament on March 29, 2017. This Act came into effect on July 01, 2017. GST is adestination basedtax on consumption with credit of taxes paid at previous stages available as set-off. In nutshell, only value addition will betaxedand the burden of tax is to be borne by the final consumer.Destination based tax on consumption means the tax would accrue to the taxing authority which has jurisdiction over the place of consumption which is also termed as place of supply. GST has removed the cascading effect of taxes. This cascading effect implies charging tax on tax. In other words, at the time of levy of tax, the total value is considered which is inclusive of all taxes paid up to the points. In this manner, if the tax is always charged on the selling price of the products, the burden of tax keeps on increasing at each point of sales. In this process, the effect of taxation magnifies as at each level tax is calculated on value, which includes taxes already levied and paid. The charging of tax on tax is called the “Cascading Effect of Tax”.What does the term "cascading effect of taxes" refer to?
  • A.Tax evasion
  • B.Tax avoiding
  • C.Charging tax on tax
  • D.Tax exemption
Correct Answer: Charging tax on tax

The cascading effect refers to a situation where tax is levied on a value that already includes tax, leading to an increase in the overall tax burden.

Question 99
Comprehension:The major source for the revenue for the government is indirect tax. The Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (CBIC) (erstwhile Central Board of Excise and Customs) is the apex regulatory body that supervises the levy and administration of Indirect Taxes in India. CBIC is a part of the Department of Revenue under the Ministry of Finance, Government of India. It deals with the tasks of formulation of policy concerning levy and collection of customs, Central Excise duties, Central Goods & Services Tax and IGST, prevention of smuggling and administration of matter relating to customs, Central Excise, Central Goods & Services Tax (CGST), IGST and narcotics to the extent under CBIC’s purview. The Board is the administrative authority for its subordinate organizations, including Custom Houses, Central Excise and Central GST Commissionerate’s and the Central Revenue Control Laboratory.In recent years, the Indian government has undertaken significant reforms under the indirect taxation system. This includes the implementation of Goods and Services Tax (GST). Goods and Services Tax (GST) is an indirect tax has replaced many indirect taxes in India. The Goods and Services Tax Act was passed in the Parliament on March 29, 2017. This Act came into effect on July 01, 2017. GST is adestination basedtax on consumption with credit of taxes paid at previous stages available as set-off. In nutshell, only value addition will betaxedand the burden of tax is to be borne by the final consumer.Destination based tax on consumption means the tax would accrue to the taxing authority which has jurisdiction over the place of consumption which is also termed as place of supply. GST has removed the cascading effect of taxes. This cascading effect implies charging tax on tax. In other words, at the time of levy of tax, the total value is considered which is inclusive of all taxes paid up to the points. In this manner, if the tax is always charged on the selling price of the products, the burden of tax keeps on increasing at each point of sales. In this process, the effect of taxation magnifies as at each level tax is calculated on value, which includes taxes already levied and paid. The charging of tax on tax is called the “Cascading Effect of Tax”.How does GST eliminate the cascading effect of taxes?
  • A.By increasing tax rates
  • B.By reducing the number of tax types
  • C.By allowing tax credit on previous stages
  • D.By exempting certain products from tax
Correct Answer: By allowing tax credit on previous stages

GST allows businesses to claim an input tax credit on the tax they have already paid, ensuring that tax is levied only on the value addition at each stage.

Question 100
Comprehension:The major source for the revenue for the government is indirect tax. The Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (CBIC) (erstwhile Central Board of Excise and Customs) is the apex regulatory body that supervises the levy and administration of Indirect Taxes in India. CBIC is a part of the Department of Revenue under the Ministry of Finance, Government of India. It deals with the tasks of formulation of policy concerning levy and collection of customs, Central Excise duties, Central Goods & Services Tax and IGST, prevention of smuggling and administration of matter relating to customs, Central Excise, Central Goods & Services Tax (CGST), IGST and narcotics to the extent under CBIC’s purview. The Board is the administrative authority for its subordinate organizations, including Custom Houses, Central Excise and Central GST Commissionerate’s and the Central Revenue Control Laboratory.In recent years, the Indian government has undertaken significant reforms under the indirect taxation system. This includes the implementation of Goods and Services Tax (GST). Goods and Services Tax (GST) is an indirect tax has replaced many indirect taxes in India. The Goods and Services Tax Act was passed in the Parliament on March 29, 2017. This Act came into effect on July 01, 2017. GST is adestination basedtax on consumption with credit of taxes paid at previous stages available as set-off. In nutshell, only value addition will betaxedand the burden of tax is to be borne by the final consumer.Destination based tax on consumption means the tax would accrue to the taxing authority which has jurisdiction over the place of consumption which is also termed as place of supply. GST has removed the cascading effect of taxes. This cascading effect implies charging tax on tax. In other words, at the time of levy of tax, the total value is considered which is inclusive of all taxes paid up to the points. In this manner, if the tax is always charged on the selling price of the products, the burden of tax keeps on increasing at each point of sales. In this process, the effect of taxation magnifies as at each level tax is calculated on value, which includes taxes already levied and paid. The charging of tax on tax is called the “Cascading Effect of Tax”.Who bears the burden of tax in the GST system?
  • A.Manufacturers
  • B.Retailers
  • C.Final Consumer
  • D.Government
Correct Answer: Final Consumer

GST is a consumption-based tax, meaning the ultimate burden of tax is borne by the final consumer while businesses act as intermediaries for tax collection.

Quiz Attempt #118978

Total Questions: 100
Question 1
What is the correct sequence to be followed for the following while computing income under the head Capital Gains?A. Deduction of indexed cost of acquisitionB. Determination of full value of considerationC. Determination whether the asset is a capital asset or notD. Determination whether the transaction is regarded as transfer or notE. Exemption under section 54EC in respect of investment in the long-term specified asset.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, A, C, E, D
  • B.E, A, D, C, B
  • C.D, B, C, A, E
  • D.C, D, B, A, E
Correct Answer: C, D, B, A, E

To compute income under the head Capital Gains, the correct sequence of steps to follow is:

 

C. Determination whether the asset is a capital asset or not: First, you need to determine if the asset in question qualifies as a capital asset. Only then can you proceed with calculating capital gains.

 

D. Determination whether the transaction is regarded as transfer or not: If it is a capital asset, you need to establish whether the transaction constitutes a transfer. This step is crucial since only transfers lead to capital gains.

 

B. Determination of full value of consideration: Once you've established that there is a transfer of a capital asset, you can determine the full value of the consideration received or accrued.

 

A. Deduction of indexed cost of acquisition: After establishing the full value of consideration, you then deduct the indexed cost of acquisition from it to calculate the capital gains.

 

E. Exemption under section 54EC in respect of investment in the long-term specified asset: Finally, you can consider any exemptions that may apply, such as investments in specified long-term assets under section 54EC.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 2
Which one of the following selection tests answers the question "Does this test measure what it's supposed to measure"?
  • A.Content validity
  • B.Criterion validity
  • C.Contact validity
  • D.Test validity
Correct Answer: Test validity

Content validity evaluates whether a test accurately measures the specific skill or knowledge area it is intended to assess. It focuses on the extent to which the test content covers the subject matter relevant to the job or task. In other words, it answers the question, "Does this test measure what it's supposed to measure?" Criterion validity, on the other hand, evaluates the test's ability to predict future job performance, while test validity is a broader term encompassing different types of validity assessments.

Question 3
Which among the following is the correct value of Income Elasticity of Petrol consumption from the following information?The Government announces a 10 per cent dearness allowance to its employees. As a result, average monthly salary of Government employees increases from 20,000 to 22,000. Following the pay hike, monthly petrol consumption of government employees increased from 150 litres per month to 165 litres per month:
  • A.0.5
  • B.1
  • C.2
  • D.0.1
Correct Answer: 1

.

Question 4
Where there is an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property (ownership) in goods passes to the buyer when:
  • A.the contract is made
  • B.the payment is made
  • C.the goods are delivered
  • D.the goods are dispatched
Correct Answer: the contract is made

Under Section 20 of the Sale of Goods Act, 1930, the property (ownership) in specific goods passes to the buyer when the contract is made, provided the goods are in a deliverable state.

 

Specific Goods in a Deliverable State: The term "specific goods" refers to goods that are identified and agreed upon at the time of the contract. A "deliverable state" means that the goods are ready for delivery, and no further action is required by either party to make them available to the buyer.

 

Passage of Property: According to Section 20(1), in an unconditional contract for the sale of specific goods in a deliverable state, the property passes to the buyer at the moment the contract is made. This means that the ownership is transferred as soon as both parties agree to the terms, assuming the goods are ready for delivery.

 

Not Dependent on Payment or Delivery: The transfer of ownership does not depend on payment being made or goods being delivered. Payment can be made after the contract is concluded, and delivery may take place subsequently.

 

Thus, option (A) is correct.

Question 5
Which one of the following is a correct assumption of Law of Diminishing Returns to a variable Input?
  • A.Labour and Capital are the only variable inputs
  • B.The units of Labour and Capital are homogeneous
  • C.The state and technologyisnot given
  • D.Input prices are given
Correct Answer: Input prices are given

Here's a detailed explanation of each option:

 

(A) Labour and Capital are the only variable inputs

This statement is incorrect because, in the context of the Law of Diminishing Returns, not all inputs are variable. The law specifically applies to situations where one input (usually labor) is variable, while other inputs (such as capital) are held constant. It is essential to have at least one fixed input for the law to be observed.

 

(B) The units of Labour and Capital are homogeneous

It means that each unit of the input being added (e.g., labor) is of the same quality and effectiveness. Homogeneity ensures that any changes in productivity are due to the increasing quantity of the input rather than differences in the quality or effectiveness of each unit. Labour is homogenous but capital is not homogeneous. Hence this is incorrect.

 

(C) The state and technology is not given

This statement is incorrect because the Law of Diminishing Returns assumes that the state of technology remains unchanged. If technology changes, it could increase or decrease productivity, making it impossible to observe the law's effect. The assumption of constant technology allows for an accurate analysis of the relationship between inputs and output.

 

(D) Input prices are given

This is the correct assumption. The Law of Diminishing Returns assumes that the prices of inputs remain fixed. This allows the law to focus on the relationship between the quantity of input used and the resulting output, without the influence of changing input costs.

Question 6
Match the List-I with List-IIChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • B.A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
  • C.A-III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • D.A-IV, B-I, D-II
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II

Here’s an explanation of the given distributions:

 

Positively Skewed

In a positively skewed distribution, the tail on the right side is longer than the left, indicating that most of the data is concentrated on the left, with a few larger values extending to the right.

 

Leptokurtic Distribution

A leptokurtic distribution has a sharper peak than a normal distribution, indicating more data is concentrated around the mean, with fatter tails. This means it has higher kurtosis.

 

Negatively Skewed

In a negatively skewed distribution, the tail on the left side is longer than the right, indicating that most of the data is concentrated on the right, with a few smaller values extending to the left.

 

Shape: Platykurtic Distribution

A platykurtic distribution has a flatter peak than a normal distribution, suggesting that the data is more spread out and has thinner tails. This distribution has lower kurtosis.

Question 7
Which of the following factors constitute the Economic Environment of a country?A. Financial SystemB. Socio-cultural environmentC. Economic PoliciesD. Educational environmentE. Structural EquilibriumChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & C only
  • B.A, C & E only
  • C.B, D & E only
  • D.C, D & E only
Correct Answer: A, C & E only

The Economic Environment of a country consists of factors that influence the economic activities and overall economic health. These include:

A. Financial System: It plays a critical role in the economic environment by affecting the flow of money, investment, and economic growth.

C. Economic Policies: Government policies such as fiscal, monetary, and trade policies directly impact economic activities and the business environment.

E. Structural Equilibrium: Refers to the balance in economic structures, such as industrial composition and market functioning, which affects economic stability.

Socio-cultural environment (B) and Educational environment (D) are not considered part of the Economic Environment, as they relate more to the social and cultural context rather than directly influencing economic structures.

Question 8
Which of the following are the assumptions of Gordon's dividend-capitalization model?A. No taxesB. Cost of capital is less than the growth rateC. No internal financingD. Constant retentionE. Constant cost of capitalChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & D only
  • B.B, C & E only
  • C.A, C & D only
  • D.A, D & E only
Correct Answer: A, D & E only

Gordon's dividend-capitalization model, also known as the Gordon Growth Model, is based on several key assumptions:

A. No taxes: The model assumes that there are no taxes, making the analysis simpler by avoiding complications related to tax effects on dividends.

D. Constant retention: The model assumes that the company maintains a constant retention ratio, meaning the proportion of earnings retained and not paid out as dividends remains the same over time.

E. Constant cost of capital: It assumes that the required rate of return or the cost of capital remains constant, allowing the model to project future dividends based on a steady rate.

Option B (Cost of capital is less than the growth rate) and Option C (No internal financing) are not assumptions of the Gordon model. The model actually assumes that the growth rate is less than the cost of capital for valuation purposes. Financing is done from retained earnings, as per this model.

Question 9
Arrange the following theories of Profit in order of time when these were propounded from oldest to latest -A. Hawley's Risk Theory of profitB. Walker's Theory of Profit: Profit as Rent of AbilityC. Clerk's Dynamic Theory of ProfitD. Schumpeter's Innovation Theory of ProfitE. Knight's Theory of ProfitChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, D, B, E
  • B.B, C, A, D, E
  • C.E, B, C, D, A
  • D.B, C, A, E, D
Correct Answer: B, C, A, D, E

Here’s the chronological order of these profit theories:

 

B. Walker's Theory of Profit: Profit as Rent of Ability

Proposed by Francis A. Walker in the late 19th century, this theory likens profit to the rent earned by land, suggesting that profit arises due to the superior ability of some entrepreneurs.

 

C. Clark's Dynamic Theory of Profit

John Bates Clark introduced the Dynamic Theory of Profit around the turn of the 20th century, suggesting that profit results from dynamic changes in the economy, such as changes in population, technology, or consumer preferences.

 

A. Hawley's Risk Theory of Profit

F. B. Hawley proposed this theory in the early 20th century, stating that profit serves as a reward for entrepreneurs who take on business risks.

 

D. Schumpeter's Innovation Theory of Profit

Joseph Schumpeter’s Innovation Theory was developed in the early to mid-20th century, focusing on profit as a reward for innovation and technological advancements brought by entrepreneurs.

 

E. Knight's Theory of Profit

Frank H. Knight's Uncertainty-Bearing Theory of Profit emerged in the 1920s, emphasizing that profit arises from bearing uncertainty in business decisions.

Question 10
Which one of the following is standard deviation of first 7 (1 to 7) natural numbers?
  • A.4
  • B.3
  • C.2
  • D.6
Correct Answer: 2

.

Question 11
Read the passage and answer the questions given below.National power demand in India has hit 250Gw, 25 per cent more than last year and 71 per cent more than in 2022. The power ministry has rightly taken pride in ensuring that thermal power stations have adequate stocks of coal to keep the lights, fans and air-conditioning on. This has been a chronic problem in previous summers, leading to prolonged outages. This year, coal stocks have reached plants well on time. As on June 23, 2024 thermal power plants had 16 days of stocks as against 9.4 days on June 23, 2022 and 12.7 days on the same day in 2023.The Government expects to add 15.4Gwof coal-fired capacity in 2024-25, the highest in 9 years and 90Gwby 2032. A programme of "Coal Reforms 3.0" is on the agenda to increase the availability of coal for industrial sectors, especially steel units, with the broad objective of reducing imports to zero in the next two financial years.India has set a target to achieve 50 per cent cumulative installed capacity from non-fossil fuel- based energy resources by 2030 and has pledged to reduce the emission intensity of its gross domestic product by 45 per cent by 2030, based on 2005 levels. The installed capacity of non- fossil power in India is now 45.3 per cent of the total capacity, putting India on track to exceed its climate-change commitmentsButthis is illusory progress The absence of viable storage technologies has limited grid offtake from renewable sources.Encouraging industry to continue its dependence on coal is unhelpful. In this respect Coal Reforms 3.0 appears to be at odds with a scheme announced earlier this year for a pilot project for given hydrogen to replace coal both as a fuel and as feedstock (which is possible even in steel produced through the blast furnace route). Given that coal-based thermal plants are responsible for a disproportionately higher share of emission that the industrial sector, the government may do well to power India's economy in the immediate future.100.) How much (approximately) was the national power demand in 2022?
  • A.200 GW
  • B.175 GW
  • C.62.5 GW
  • D.146 GW
Correct Answer: 146 GW

The passage states that the national power demand has increased by 71% compared to 2022 and reached 250 GW in 2024. To calculate the demand in 2022:

x+ 71x100 = 250

By solving this, we get the value of national power demand in 2022 = x = 146.19 GW.

Question 12
Which of the following methods have been prescribed by the Central Board of Direct Taxes (CBDT) for computation of Ann's Length Price required to compute income arising from anInternationaltransaction under Chapter X of the Income-tax Act, 1961?A. Transactional Net Margin MethodB.UncomparableControlled Price MethodC. Profit Split MethodD. Resale Price MethodE. Cost Minus MethodChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, D & E Only
  • B.A, B & D Only
  • C.C, D & E Only
  • D.A, C & D Only
Correct Answer: A, C & D Only

Section 92C deals with the method for determining arm’s length price and the factors which are to be considered for applicability or non-applicability of a particular method to a given situation. The most appropriate method, from the methods given below, has to be applied for determination of arm’s length price, in the prescribed manner.

 

1. Comparable Uncontrolled Price Method: A ‘Comparable Uncontrolled Price’ is the price agreed between unconnected parties for the transaction of goods or services under similar circumstances. After identification of price charged/ paid for property transferred or services provided under any comparable uncontrolled transaction(s), such price is adjusted to account for differences, if any, between the international transaction and comparable uncontrolled transactions, which could materially affect the price in the open market. Such adjusted price arrived, is taken as arm’s length price, in respect of the property transferred or services provided in an international transaction. Here, uncontrolled transaction means a transaction between enterprises other than associated enterprises, whether resident or non-resident.

 

2. Resale Price Method (RPM): It is a method which compares the gross margins (i.e. gross profit over sales) earned in transactions between related and unrelated parties for the determination of ALP. This method is generally used to test transactions involving distribution function, i.e., when the tested party purchases products/ acquires services from related party and resells the same to independent parties.

 

3. Cost Plus Method: It determines ALP by adding an appropriate gross profit margin to an associated entity’s costs of producing goods or services. This method is most useful where semi-finished goods are sold between related parties, where related parties have concluded joint facility agreements or long-term buy-and-supply arrangements, or where the controlled transaction is the provision of services.

 

4. Profit Split Method: This is a method, which may be applicable, mainly in international transactions involving transfer of unique intangibles or in multiple international transactions which are so inter-related that they cannot be evaluated separately for the purpose of determining the ALP of any one transaction. In this method, combined net profit of the associated enterprises, arising out of international transaction in which they are engaged is determined. Then, there is an evaluation of relative contributions by each enterprise to the earning of such combined net profit on the basis of functions performed, risks assumed and assets employed by each enterprise. Such combined net profit is split amongst the enterprises in proportion to their relative contributions. Profit, thus, apportioned to the assessee, is taken into account to arrive at the arm’s length price in relation to the international transaction.

 

5. Transactional Net Margin Method (TNMM): Under this method, an arm’s length price is determined by comparing the net profit margin in relation to an appropriate base (for example costs, sales, assets) of the tested party with the net profit margin in relation to the same bases, of an uncontrolled party engaged in comparable transactions.

 

6. Other method as prescribed by CBDT: The other method allows the use of ‘any method’ which takes into account (a) the price which has been charged or paid, or (b) would have been charged or paid for the same or similar uncontrolled transactions with or between non-associated enterprises, under similar circumstances. The various data which may possibly be used for comparability purposes under this method could be third party quotations, valuation reports, tender/bid documents, documents relating to the negotiations, standard rate cards, commercial & economic business models, etc.

 

Thus, option (D) is correct.

Question 13
In WTO terminology, subsidies in general are identified by "boxes". Domestic support measure considered to distort production and trade, which is defined in Article 6 of the Agriculture Agreement falls into which box?
  • A.Amber Box
  • B.Jumbo Box
  • C.Greenfield Box
  • D.Black Box
Correct Answer: Amber Box

In WTO terminology, the Amber Box includes domestic support measures that are considered to distort production and trade. These subsidies are subject to reduction commitments under Article 6 of the Agriculture Agreement because they can influence market prices and production levels.

Question 14
If two regression lines are: 8x - 10y + 66 = 0 and 40x - 18y = 214, thenX-&Y-are respectively:
  • A.13, 14
  • B.16, 15
  • C.14, 13
  • D.13, 17
Correct Answer: 13, 17

Question 15
The rate of diffusion of any innovation depends upon the following factors:A. The relative advantage of the innovation over previous solutionsB. The compatibility of the innovation with existing values and normsC. A lack of complexity in using the innovationD. The divisibility of the innovation facilitating low-risk trialE. The communicability of the advantages of the innovationChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C & E Only
  • B.A, B, C & E only
  • C.A, B, C, D & E
  • D.B & D Only
Correct Answer: A, B, C, D & E

The rate of diffusion of any innovation is influenced by several factors, including:

A. The relative advantage: The perceived benefits of the innovation compared to existing solutions.

B. Compatibility: How well the innovation fits with existing values, past experiences, and needs.

C. Lack of complexity: Innovations that are easier to understand and use diffuse more quickly.

D. Divisibility: The ability to try the innovation on a limited basis reduces perceived risk.

E. Communicability: How easily the benefits of the innovation can be observed and shared.

All these factors together influence how quickly an innovation spreads.

Question 16
Import of service means:A. The Supplier of service is located in IndiaB. The Supplier of service is located outside IndiaC. The Recipient of service is located in IndiaD. The Recipient of service is located outside IndiaE. The place of Supply of service is in IndiaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & E Only
  • B.A, D & E Only
  • C.B, D & E Only
  • D.B, C & E Only
Correct Answer: B, C & E Only

Import of a service occurs when:

B. The supplier of the service is located outside India.

C. The recipient of the service is located in India.

E. The place of supply of the service is in India.

Question 17
Arrange the following content theories of work motivation in the increasing order of their development -A. Herzberg-motivation and hygiene factorsB. Alderfer ERG NeedsC. Maslow-Hierarchy of NeedsD. Scientific ManagementE. Human RelationsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, C, E, A, B
  • B.D, E, C, A, B
  • C.B, C, A, D, E
  • D.D, E, A, C, B
Correct Answer: D, E, C, A, B

. Arrange the content theories of work motivation in the increasing order of their development, we need to consider the chronological development of these theories. Here’s the breakdown:

 

D. Scientific Management: Developed by Frederick Taylor in the early 20th century (1911), this theory focuses on optimizing work processes and efficiency, laying the groundwork for later motivational theories.

 

E. Human Relations: Emerging in the 1930s, this approach, influenced by the Hawthorne studies, emphasized the importance of social relations and worker satisfaction, shifting the focus from purely mechanical productivity to human aspects.

 

C. Maslow - Hierarchy of Needs: Proposed by Abraham Maslow in 1943, this theory introduced the idea that human motivation is based on a hierarchy of needs, from physiological to self-actualization.

 

A. Herzberg - Motivation and Hygiene Factors: Developed in the 1950s, Frederick Herzberg's theory distinguished between motivators and hygiene factors, emphasizing that job satisfaction and dissatisfaction arise from different sources.

 

B. Alderfer ERG Needs: Introduced by Clayton Alderfer in the 1960s, this theory refined Maslow’s model into three core needs: Existence, Relatedness, and Growth, allowing for more flexibility than Maslow's hierarchy.

 

Given this chronological order, the correct arrangement in increasing order of development is: option (B) D, E, C, A, B.

Question 18
Which of the following condition is NOT required to be satisfied by an individual for the purpose of claiming unilateral relief under section 91(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, in a previous year?
  • A.He must be resident in India in that previous year
  • B.His total income exceeds Rs. 10,00,000 during that previous year
  • C.He has earned an income during that previous year from another country and that income has accrued or arose outside India
  • D.(D) He has paid income-tax in that country on the income earned in that country and no Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement (DTAA) exists between India and that country
Correct Answer: His total income exceeds Rs. 10,00,000 during that previous year

To prevent the problem of double taxation—where the same income is taxed by two different jurisdictions—reliefs are provided under international tax law. These reliefs are broadly categorized into two types:

 

1. Bilateral Relief

Bilateral relief applies when a Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement (DTAA) exists between India and another country. Under this arrangement, there are two main methods to alleviate double taxation:

  • Exemption Method: This method allows income that has been taxed in one country to be exempt from tax in the resident country, thus preventing double taxation.
  • Credit Method: Under this method, the tax paid in one country is credited against the tax payable in the resident country on the same income, effectively reducing the total tax liability to the higher of the two rates.

 

2. Unilateral Relief

Unilateral relief comes into play when there is no DTAA between the resident country and the source country. In such cases, the resident country, on its own initiative, may offer relief to its residents. Section 91 of the Income Tax Act of 1961 provides the framework for unilateral relief, where the home country allows a credit for the tax paid in another country on income derived from that country.

 

Certain conditions must be met to be eligible for relief under Section 91 of the Income Tax Act. These conditions include:

(a) The income is taxable in India, and the taxpayer is a resident in India during the previous year, with the income accruing or arising outside India.

(b) The income should accrue or arise outside India during the previous year.

(c) The income in question has already been subjected to income tax in the foreign country.

(d) The taxpayer has paid tax on the income in the foreign country.

(e) There is no existing Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement between India and the country where the income has accrued or arisen.

 

Thus, statement in option (B) is not a condition to be satisfied by an individual for the purpose of claiming unilateral relief under section 91(1) of the Income-tax Act, 1961, in a previous year.

Question 19
Which one of the followingtheoryof capital structure discusses Arbitrage Process?
  • A.Traditional Approach
  • B.Modigliani and Miller (MM) Approach
  • C.Net Operating Income (NOI) Approach
  • D.Net Income (NI) Approach
Correct Answer: Modigliani and Miller (MM) Approach

The Modigliani and Miller (MM) Approach to capital structure theory discusses the Arbitrage Process, which states that in perfect capital markets, the value of a firm is unaffected by its capital structure. Investors can create their own leverage by borrowing or lending, thus offsetting any benefits of corporate leverage. This arbitrage ensures that the firm's market value remains unchanged, regardless of the debt-to-equity ratio.

Question 20
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Personality Traits)A. ConscientiousnessB. AgreeablenessC. ExtraversionD. Openness to experienceLIST II (Descriptive Characteristics)I. OutgoingII. CaringIII. CreativeIV. DependableChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-II, C-I, D-IV
  • B.A-IV, B-II, C-III, D-I
  • C.A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III
  • D.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III

Here’s the matching explanation:

A. Conscientiousness – IV. Dependable: Conscientious individuals are known for being responsible, organized, and reliable.

B. Agreeableness – II. Caring: People high in agreeableness tend to be kind, cooperative, and compassionate towards others.

C. Extraversion – I. Outgoing: Extraverted individuals are sociable, talkative, and enjoy interacting with others.

D. Openness to experience – III. Creative: Those high in openness are open-minded, imaginative, and enjoy trying new things.

Thus, the correct matching is A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III.

Question 21
