Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Ind AS)A. Ind AS-12B. Ind AS-17C. Ind AS-19D. Ind AS-23LIST II (Related)I. LeasesII. Borrowing CostsIII. Employee BenefitsIV. Income TaxesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- IV, B- I, C- III, D-II
  • B.A- III, B-II, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A- I, B-IV, C- III, D-II
  • D.A- IV, B-III, C- I, D-II
Correct Answer: A- IV, B- I, C- III, D-II

The correct match is as follows.

LIST I (Ind AS) - LIST II (Related)

A. Ind AS-12 - Income Taxes

B. Ind AS-17 - Leases

C. Ind AS-19 - Employee Benefits

D. Ind AS-23 - Borrowing Costs

Question 22
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Macro Level Organizational Stressors)A. Administrative Policies and StrategiesB. Organizational Structure and DesignC. Organizational ProcessesD. Working ConditionsLIST II (Examples)I. Crowded work areaII. Merit Pay PlansIII. No opportunity for advancementIV. Lack of participation in decisionsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I
  • B.A-III, B-II, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-II, B-III, C-IV, D-I

The various types of job stressors are classified as follows.

Therefore, the correct match is as follows.

A. Administrative Policies and Strategies – II. Merit Pay Plans: Policies like merit pay can create stress by affecting motivation and perceived fairness.

B. Organizational Structure and Design – III. No opportunity for advancement: Structural issues such as lack of career growth can be a significant stressor.

C. Organizational Processes – IV. Lack of participation in decisions: Processes that exclude employee input can lead to feelings of powerlessness and stress.

D. Working Conditions – I. Crowded work area: Physical working conditions, like cramped spaces, can contribute to stress.

Question 23
Which one of the following is NOT an issue (to be tackled) of conceptual component of a CRMprogramme?
  • A.Choosing the technology
  • B.Setting out the objectives in clear terms
  • C.Processing all customer requests coming in through multiple channels
  • D.Putting customers first
Correct Answer: Processing all customer requests coming in through multiple channels

The conceptual component of a Customer Relationship Management (CRM) program primarily deals with strategic aspects, such as setting objectives, aligning customer-centric strategies, and choosing the right technology to support the program. Processing customer requests through various channels is more of an operational issue rather than a conceptual one. The conceptual focus is on designing the overall CRM framework rather than handling day-to-day customer service processes.

Question 24
In international trade, factoring is widely used in short-term transactions as a continuous arrangement. Arrange the steps of export factoring operations in sequence -A. The export factor transfers the invoice to the import factor, who, in return, assumes credit risk and undertakes administration of receivable.B. The export factor pays cash in advance to the exporter against receivables until the payment is received from the importer.C. The importer and exporter enter into a sales contract and agree on the terms of sale.D. The import factor presents invoice to importer, take payment and pays to the export factor.E. The exporter ships the goods to the importer and submits the invoice to the export factor.Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, A, B, D, C
  • B.E, B, A, D, C
  • C.C, B, E, D, A
  • D.C, E, B, A, D
Correct Answer: C, E, B, A, D

The correct answer is (D) C, E, B, A, D.

Here is the sequence of export factoring operations:

C. The importer and exporter enter into a sales contract and agree on the terms of sale.

E. The exporter ships the goods to the importer and submits the invoice to the export factor.

B. The export factor pays cash in advance to the exporter against receivables until the payment is received from the importer.

A. The export factor transfers the invoice to the import factor, who, in return, assumes credit risk and undertakes administration of receivable.

D. The import factor presents the invoice to the importer, collects the payment, and pays the export factor.

Question 25
Compute the after-tax cost of capital of a company in case a perpetual bond (face value is Z100) is sold as well as redeemed at par having coupon rate of interest being 7% and corporate tax rate is 30%.
  • A.2.1%
  • B.4.9%
  • C.7%
  • D.10%
Correct Answer: 4.9%

Question 26
Arrange the steps of Sampling Design in a form of questions that are to be answered in securing a sampleA. What is the appropriate sampling method?B. What are the parameters of interest?C. What size sample is needed?D. What is the target population?E. What is the sampling frame?Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, D, B, A, C
  • B.B, E, A, C, D
  • C.C, B, A, E, D
  • D.D, B, E, A, C
Correct Answer: D, B, E, A, C

Here is the correct sequence of steps in Sampling Design, framed as questions:

D. What is the target population?

Identify the group of individuals or elements from which the sample will be drawn.

B. What are the parameters of interest?

Determine the characteristics or metrics that need to be measured in the sample.

E. What is the sampling frame?

Identify the list or source from which the sample will be selected.

A. What is the appropriate sampling method?

Choose the method for selecting the sample (e.g., random, stratified).

C. What size sample is needed?

Decide on the number of observations required to achieve reliable results.

Question 27
The Narsimhan Committee 1991 recommended the reforms with respect to the banking sector. These reforms are also known as:
  • A.First generation reforms
  • B.Second generation reforms
  • C.Financial sector reforms
  • D.Third generation reforms
Correct Answer: First generation reforms

The Narsimhan Committee of 1991 recommended a series of reforms aimed at improving the efficiency and stability of the banking sector in India. These reforms are referred to as First generation reforms, as they were the initial set of structural changes introduced to liberalize the financial sector, including measures such as reducing government control, enhancing competition, and improving banking practices.

Question 28
Which one of the following is NOT a marketingprinciple ?
  • A.Focus on the customer
  • B.Markets are homogeneous
  • C.Customers do not buy products
  • D.Marketing is too important to leave to the marketing department
Correct Answer: Markets are homogeneous

One of the fundamental marketing principles is that markets are not homogeneous; rather, they consist of diverse customer segments with varying needs, preferences, and behaviors. Successful marketing requires recognizing and addressing these differences. The other options reflect core marketing principles: focusing on the customer, understanding that customers seek solutions rather than just products, and involving the entire organization in marketing efforts.

Question 29
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Pricing Strategies)A. Skimming Price PolicyB. Penetration Price PolicyC. Peak Load Pricing PolicyD. Dumping Pricing PolicyLIST II (Their Explanation)I. Where the nature of the productsarenon-storableII. Where close substitutes of a new product are not availableIII. Exporting goods at a price lower than the domestic priceIV. Substitutes of new products are availableChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- III, B-II, C- I, D-IV
  • B.A- IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • C.A- I, B- III, C-II, D-IV
  • D.A- II, B-IV, C-I, D-III
Correct Answer: A- II, B-IV, C-I, D-III

Here’s the matching explanation:

A. Skimming Price Policy – II. Where close substitutes of a new product are not available:
Skimming involves setting a high initial price to maximize profit from customers who are willing to pay a premium, especially when there are no close substitutes.

B. Penetration Price Policy – IV. Substitutes of new products are available:
Penetration pricing sets a low initial price to attract customers and gain market share quickly when substitutes are available.

C. Peak Load Pricing Policy – I. Where the nature of the products are non-storable:
This strategy charges higher prices during peak demand periods, commonly used for services or non-storable goods.

D. Dumping Pricing Policy – III. Exporting goods at a price lower than the domestic price:
Dumping involves selling products in a foreign market at a price lower than in the domestic market to increase market share or eliminate competition.

Thus, the correct matching is A-II, B-IV, C-I, D-III.

Question 30
For the purpose of taking Capital Budgeting Decisions in respect of a company in India, following are taken into consideration in computing cash flows in the terminal year of the project:A. Tax loss on short-term capital gainsB. Tax loss on short-term capital lossC. Release of net working capitalD. Tax saving on short-term capital lossE. Tax saving on short-term capital gainsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C & D only
  • B.B, C & E only
  • C.C & E only
  • D.B & E only
Correct Answer: A, C & D only

In capital budgeting, the following factors are considered in computing cash flows during the terminal year:

A. Tax loss on short-term capital gains: Any tax implications from losses can affect the final cash flows.

C. Release of net working capital: At the end of the project, the net working capital is released, resulting in an inflow.

D. Tax saving on short-term capital loss: Tax savings from capital losses can reduce the tax liability and impact the cash flow positively.

Question 31
For test hypothesisH0:μ1≤μ2andH1:μ1>μ2, the critical region (Z) at α = 0.10 and n > 30 will be
  • A.Z < 1.96
  • B.Z > 1.96
  • C.Z > 1.645
  • D.Z > 1.28
Correct Answer:

Thus, the critical region is Z > 1.28, indicating that if the test statistic exceeds 1.28, we reject the null hypothesis H0​ in favor of the alternative hypothesis H1​.

Question 32
Arrange the following sequentially with respect to operating cycle of a manufacturing firm -A. Payables Deferral PeriodB. Finished Goods Conversion PeriodC. Raw Material Conversion PeriodD. Receivables Conversion PeriodE. Work-in-progress Conversion PeriodChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D, C, E, B
  • B.C, E, B, D, A
  • C.B, D, A, E, C
  • D.D, B, E, A, C
Correct Answer: C, E, B, D, A

Here’s the sequential order with respect to the operating cycle of a manufacturing firm:

C. Raw Material Conversion Period: This is the time taken to convert raw materials into work-in-progress.

E. Work-in-progress Conversion Period: The time required to convert work-in-progress into finished goods.

B. Finished Goods Conversion Period: The duration needed to convert finished goods into sales.

D. Receivables Conversion Period: The time taken to collect payments from customers after sales.

A. Payables Deferral Period: The time allowed by suppliers to pay for raw materials.

Question 33
RBI permitted the issue of commercial papers within the framework of its guidelines. Which one of the followingcommitteerecommended these guidelines?
  • A.Verma Committee
  • B.PadmnabhanCommittee
  • C.Kalia Committee
  • D.VaghulCommittee
Correct Answer: VaghulCommittee

The Vaghul Committee was responsible for recommending the introduction of commercial papers (CPs) in India. These guidelines allowed companies to issue short-term, unsecured promissory notes as a way to raise working capital. The introduction of CPs aimed to develop the money market and provide an alternative source of short-term funding for companies, in line with the committee's recommendations to modernize the financial sector.

Question 34
The price of a company's share is Rs 80 and the value of growth opportunities is Rs 20. If the company's capitalisation rate is 15%, how much is the EPS?
  • A.Rs. 20
  • B.Rs. 12
  • C.Rs. 3
  • D.Rs. 9
Correct Answer: Rs. 9

Question 35
What is the correct sequence to be followed for the following transactions undertaken by an individual while computing his gross total income as per the Income-tax Act, 1961?A. Investment in own public provident fundB. Investment in one residential house in India for exemption from capital gainsC. Interest on capital borrowed for purchasing a self-occupied house propertyD. Tax on employmentE. Payment of Medical insurance premium on his own lifeChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, B, D, E, A
  • B.D, C, B, A, E
  • C.E, A, D, B, C
  • D.B, C, E, A, D
Correct Answer: D, C, B, A, E

Here is the section-wise arrangement of provisions as per Income-Tax Act, 1961:

D. Tax on employment – Section 16

C. Interest on capital borrowed for purchasing a self-occupied house property – Section 24(b)

B. Investment in one residential house in India for exemption from capital gains – Section 54F

A. Investment in own public provident fund – Section 80 C

E. Payment of Medical insurance premium on his own life – Section 80D

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 36
WTO in its 8th Ministerial conference adopted a decision allowing members to waive the provisions of Article II (mostfavored-National Treatment) of the GATS to allow the granting of preferential treatment to services and service supplies to which countries?
  • A.Adjacent Countries
  • B.Non-Nuclear Countries
  • C.Least-Developed Countries
  • D.SAARC Countries
Correct Answer: Least-Developed Countries

The WTO's 8th Ministerial Conference allowed members to waive Article II of the GATS to grant preferential treatment to services and service suppliers from Least-Developed Countries (LDCs), aiming to support their integration into the global economy.

Question 37
Arrange the following steps of Activity Based Costing (ABC) in proper sequence -A. Staff Training and Review Follow upB. Identify Main ActivitiesC. Process specificationD. Identify Non-value adding Activity and cost poolsE. Selection of Activity Cost Drivers and Tracing of CostsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C, B, D, E, A
  • B.B, C, D, E, A
  • C.D, B, C, A, E
  • D.E, D, B, C, A
Correct Answer: C, B, D, E, A

The correct answer is (A) C, B, D, E, A.

Here’s the sequence of steps in Activity-Based Costing (ABC):

C. Process specification: Define the processes and understand the flow of activities.

B. Identify Main Activities: Determine the key activities that consume resources.

D. Identify Non-value adding Activity and cost pools: Separate value-adding from non-value-adding activities and create cost pools.

E. Selection of Activity Cost Drivers and Tracing of Costs with objects: Choose cost drivers that link activity costs to products or services.

A. Staff Training and Review Follow up: Ensure staff are trained on ABC and review the implementation.

Question 38
Which of the following are the characteristics of a Leader?A. Focuses on systems and structureB. Eye on the horizonC. Asks how and whenD. Does things rightE. OriginatesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & D Only
  • B.B & E Only
  • C.B, C & D Only
  • D.A, B, D & E Only
Correct Answer: B & E Only

Characteristics of a leader viz-a-viz manager include:

 

 

Thus, the following 2 options depict characteristics of Leader:

 

B. Eye on the horizon: Leaders focus on future possibilities and long-term vision rather than just day-to-day operations.

E. Originates: Leaders are innovative and initiate new ideas, setting direction rather than just following established practices.

 

The other options (A, C, and D) are more characteristic of managers, who focus on systems, structure, and doing things right.

Question 39
Which one of the following is Value Added Service of EXIM Bank?
  • A.Line of Credit
  • B.Pre-shipment Credit
  • C.Buyers Credit
  • D.Export Marketing Services
Correct Answer: Export Marketing Services

Export Marketing Services are considered a value-added service provided by EXIM Bank to help exporters promote and market their products internationally. It includes support such as market research, product adaptation, and identifying potential buyers. The other options (Line of Credit, Pre-shipment Credit, Buyers Credit) are core services of EXIM bank rather than value-added services.

Question 40
Which one of the following non-functional rewards does NOT fall under job design category?
  • A.Compliment of work progress
  • B.Flexible hours
  • C.Participation in decisions
  • D.Flexible breaks
Correct Answer: Compliment of work progress

In the context of non-functional rewards related to job design, we can analyse the options:

 

(A) Compliment of work progress: This is a form of recognition or feedback and is often considered a motivational tool rather than a job design element. It focuses on acknowledging employee performance.

 

(B) Flexible hours: This falls under job design as it pertains to how work is structured and scheduled, allowing employees to have control over their work hours.

 

(C) Participation in decisions: This relates to job design as it involves empowering employees and involving them in decision-making processes, which can enhance their job satisfaction and engagement.

 

(D) Flexible breaks: This also falls under job design because it relates to how employees can manage their work-life balance and work structure throughout the day.

 

Thus, option (A) Compliment of work progress, is more about recognition and feedback rather than the structural elements of job design.

Question 41
If selling price per unit is 56.00. Variable cost per unit is 32.00 and total fixed cost is 60,000, what is the number of units that used to be sold in order to achieve a profit of 84,000?
  • A.6000 units
  • B.8400 units
  • C.5000 units
  • D.6500 units
Correct Answer: 6000 units

.

Question 42
Match List-I and List-IIList I (Institutions)A. National Housing BankB. Industrial Development Bank of IndiaC. Small Industrial Development Bank of IndiaD. Industrial Finance Corporation of IndiaList II (Date of establishment)I. 01 – 07 – 1964II. 01 – 07 – 1948III. 02 – 04 – 1990IV. 09 – 07 – 1988Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- I, B-II, C- III, D-IV
  • B.A- III, B-I, C-IV, D-II
  • C.A- I, B- IV, C-III, D-II
  • D.A- IV, B-I, C-III, D-II
Correct Answer: A- IV, B-I, C-III, D-II

The correct match is as follows.

List I (Institutions) – List II (Date of establishment)

A. National Housing Bank - 09 – 07 – 1988

B. Industrial Development Bank of India - 01 – 07 – 1964

C. Small Industrial Development Bank of India - 02 – 04 – 1990

D. Industrial Finance Corporation of India - 01 – 07 – 1948

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 43
Which of the following are true in case of Internal Reconstruction?A. The existing company is liquidatedB. No new company is formedC. There is certain reduction of capital and sometime liabilities are also reducedD. The new company issues fresh capitalE. It is done as per section 66 of the Companies Act, 2013Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D & E only
  • B.A, C & E only
  • C.B, C & E only
  • D.B, C & D only
Correct Answer: B, C & E only

To determine which statements are true regarding Internal Reconstruction, let's analyze each statement based on the principles of corporate restructuring under the Companies Act:

 

A. The existing company is liquidated: This is false for internal reconstruction. Internal reconstruction does not involve liquidation; instead, it refers to restructuring the company's finances without dissolving the existing entity.

 

B. No new company is formed: This is true. In internal reconstruction, the existing company continues to exist, and no new company is created.

 

C. There is certain reduction of capital and sometimes liabilities are also reduced: This is true. Internal reconstruction often involves reducing the company’s capital and may also involve negotiating with creditors to reduce liabilities.

 

D. The new company issues fresh capital: This is false. In internal reconstruction, the existing company does not issue new shares. Instead, it may involve restructuring the existing capital structure.

 

E. It is done as per section 66 of the Companies Act, 2013: This is true. Section 66 of the Companies Act, 2013, provides the legal framework for the reduction of share capital, which is a key component of internal reconstruction.

 

Based on this analysis, the true statements regarding internal reconstruction are option (C) i.e., B, C, and E.

Question 44
X Ltd. incurred a capital expenditure of Rs. 5,00,000 for the purpose of promoting family planning amongst its employees during the assessment year 2024-25. How much deduction in respect of such expenditure can be claimed by X Ltd. during the assessment year 2024-25, while computing income under the head Profits and Gains of Business or Profession?
  • A.Rs. 5,00,000
  • B.Rs. 2,50,000
  • C.Rs. 1,00,000
  • D.Rs. 50,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 1,00,000

As per the provisions of (Sec. 36(1)(ix)) of Income Tax Act, 1961 - Expenses on family planning, any bonafide expenditure of revenue nature incurred by a company for the purpose of promoting family planning amongst its employees will be allowed as a deduction in computing the company’s business income.

 

Where, the expenditure is of capital nature, 1/5th of such expenditure will be deducted in the previous year, in which it was incurred and in each of the four immediately succeeding previous years. This deduction is allowable only to companies and not to other assessees. The assessee would be entitled to carry forward and set off the unabsorbed part of the allowance in the same way as unabsorbed depreciation.

 

Thus, 1/5th of Rs. 5,00,000 = Rs. 1,00,000 will be deducted in the previous year, in which it was incurred and in each of the four immediately succeeding previous years.

Question 45
Which one of the following is NOT good forbargainerswhile bargaining with employees?
  • A.Do not hurry
  • B.Build a reputation for being fair but not firm
  • C.Strive to keep some flexibility in your position
  • D.Respect the importance of face saving for the other party
Correct Answer: Build a reputation for being fair but not firm

In the context of effective bargaining with employees, the list of good expressions for bargainers is as follows.

 

Question 46
How much per cent of income by way of interest received on compensation or on enhanced compensation is allowed as deduction while computing income under the head Income from Other Sources under the Income-tax Act, 1961?
  • A.25%
  • B.50%
  • C.75%
  • D.100%
Correct Answer: 50%

Interest received on compensation or enhanced compensation is taxable in the year of receipt under the head ‘Income from other sources’, even if it pertains to a regular business activity. A deduction of 50% is allowed and, effectively, only 50% of such interest is taxable under the said head of income.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 47
In which one of the following ratios, the share capital of RRBs is prescribed for the Central Government, State Government and Sponsoring bank?
  • A.50:30:20
  • B.50:35:15
  • C.60:20:20
  • D.50:15:35
Correct Answer: 50:15:35

The share capital ratio for Regional Rural Banks (RRBs) is prescribed as 50% by the Central Government, 15% by the State Government, and 35% by the Sponsoring Bank.

Question 48
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Concept)A. Profitability IndexB. Accounting Rate of Return (ARR)C. Internal Rate of Return (IRR)D. Modified Internal Rate of Return (MIRR)LIST II (Meaning)I. Rate that equates the investment outlay with the present value of cash inflow received after one periodII. Compound average annual rate that is calculated with a reinvestment rate different than the project's IRRIII. Rate that is computed by dividing the average profit after tax with the average investmentIV. Ratio of the present value of cash inflows, at the required rate of return, to the initial cash outflow of the investmentChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
  • B.A-I, B-IV, C-II, D-III
  • C.A- II, B-I, D-IV
  • D.A-III, B-II, C-IV, D-I
Correct Answer: A- IV, B-III, C-I, D-II

Here’s the matching explanation:

A. Profitability Index – IV. Ratio of the present value of cash inflows, at the required rate of return, to the initial cash outflow of the investment: This measures the profitability of an investment.

B. Accounting Rate of Return (ARR) – III. Rate that is computed by dividing the average profit after tax with the average investment: ARR measures the return on investment based on accounting profit.

C. Internal Rate of Return (IRR) – I. Rate that equates the investment outlay with the present value of cash inflow received after one period: IRR is the discount rate that makes the net present value (NPV) of cash flows zero.

D. Modified Internal Rate of Return (MIRR) – II. Compound average annual rate that is calculated with a reinvestment rate different than the project's IRR: MIRR addresses some limitations of the traditional IRR by using a different reinvestment rate.

Question 49
Which one of the following refers to the need on the part of the customer that gets satisfied by the service?
  • A.Service Benefits
  • B.Service Expectations
  • C.Service Offer
  • D.Service Level
Correct Answer: Service Benefits

Service Benefits refer to the advantages or value that the customer gains from using a service, which directly satisfies their needs or desires. This concept focuses on the outcome that fulfills the customer's requirements, distinguishing it from expectations, offers, or service levels, which relate to different aspects of service delivery.

Question 50
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Classification of goods as per the Sales of Goods Act, 1932)A. Specific GoodsB. Ascertained GoodsC. Unascertained GoodsD. Future GoodsLIST II (Their Definition)I. The goods which are to be manufactured or produced or acquired by the seller after making the contract of saleII. The goods, which are not identified and agreed upon at the time of formation of contract of saleIII. The goods, which are identified and agreed upon subsequent to the formation of contract of saleIV. The goods, which are identified and agreed upon at the time of making the contract of saleChoose the correct answer from the options given below
  • A.A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I
  • B.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
  • C.A-IV, B-II, C-III, D-I
  • D.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-II, D-I

The correct match for the classifications of goods as per the Sales of Goods Act, 1932 (List I) with their definitions (List II),

 

A. Specific Goods: These are goods that are identified and agreed upon at the time of making the contract of sale - Match: IV. (The goods, which are identified and agreed upon at the time of making the contract of sale)

 

B. Ascertained Goods: These are goods that are identified and agreed upon subsequent to the formation of the contract of sale- Match: III. (The goods, which are identified and agreed upon subsequent to the formation of the contract of sale).

 

C. Unascertained Goods: These are goods that are not identified and agreed upon at the time of formation of the contract of sale - Match: II. (The goods, which are not identified and agreed upon at the time of formation of the contract of sale).

 

D. Future Goods: These are goods that are to be manufactured, produced, or acquired by the seller after making the contract of sale - Match: I. (The goods which are to be manufactured or produced or acquired by the seller after making the contract of sale).

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 51
Which of the following are true about Digital Signature under Information Technology (IT) Act, 2000?A. A Digital Signature is an Electronic SignatureB. Digital Signatures are accepted GloballyC. Each vendor has to make his own standard to regulate Digital SignaturesD. The term Electronic Signature is broader than Digital SignatureE. A Digital Signature is less secure than Electronic SignatureChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D & E Only
  • B.A, B & D Only
  • C.C, B & E Only
  • D.B, C & D Only
Correct Answer: A, B & D Only

The correct answer is (B) A, B & D Only.

 

A. A Digital Signature is an Electronic Signature: True, as digital signatures are a type of electronic signature used to authenticate the identity of the sender.

 

B. Digital Signatures are accepted Globally: True, digital signatures are recognized and accepted internationally under various legal frameworks.

 

D. The term Electronic Signature is broader than Digital Signature: True, because electronic signatures encompass all forms of electronic authentication, while digital signatures specifically use encryption techniques for security.

 

C (Each vendor has to make his own standard) and E (A Digital Signature is less secure than Electronic Signature) are incorrect statements.

Question 52
Arrange the following steps for the Incorporation of a new LLP (Limited Liability Partnership) in the correct order -A. Drafting of LLP AgreementB. Deciding the partners and designated partnersC. Electronic filing of documents with ROC & issuing of Certificate of Incorporation by ROC (Registrar of Companies)D. Checking the availability of NameE. Obtaining DPIN & Digital Signature CertificateChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, E, D, A, C
  • B.C, A, B, D, E
  • C.A, B, C, D, E
  • D.E, A, C, D, B
Correct Answer: B, E, D, A, C

To arrange the steps for the incorporation of a new Limited Liability Partnership (LLP) in the correct order, let’s consider the logical sequence involved in the process:

 

B. Deciding the partners and designated partners: Before you can incorporate an LLP, you need to determine who the partners and designated partners will be.

 

E. Obtaining DPIN & Digital Signature Certificate: The Designated Partners Identification Number (DPIN) and a Digital Signature Certificate (DSC) must be obtained for the designated partners to proceed with the registration.

 

D. Checking the availability of Name: Once the partners are decided and the necessary identification is secured, the next step is to check the availability of the desired name for the LLP.

 

A. Drafting of LLP Agreement: After securing the name, the next step involves drafting the LLP Agreement, which outlines the terms of the partnership.

 

C. Electronic filing of documents with ROC & issuing of Certificate of Incorporation by ROC (Registrar of Companies): Finally, the required documents, including the LLP Agreement, are electronically filed with the ROC, leading to the issuance of the Certificate of Incorporation.

Question 53
Which of the following are social factors influencing consumer buyingbehavior?A. CultureB. Reference groupsC. Social ClassD. Roles assumedE. Sub-cultureChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & C Only
  • B.B & D Only
  • C.A, C & D Only
  • D.B. D & E Only
Correct Answer: B & D Only

Social factors influencing consumer buying behavior include:

B. Reference groups: These are groups that influence a person's attitudes or behavior, such as friends, family, or colleagues.

D. Roles assumed: The roles people play in their social groups (e.g., parent, employee) can affect their buying decisions.

 

Culture (A), Social Class (C), and Sub-culture (E) are cultural factors, not social factors, influencing consumer behavior.

Question 54
Which one of the following is known as backbone of auditing?
  • A.Verification of assets
  • B.Internal check
  • C.Vouching
  • D.Internal audit
Correct Answer: Vouching

Vouching involves examining the underlying documents (like invoices, receipts, etc.) that support the transactions recorded in the financial statements. It helps to verify the authenticity and accuracy of the transactions, ensuring that the financial records reflect the true state of the company's affairs.

 

While verification of assets, internal check, and internal audit are important aspects of the audit process, vouching is fundamentally critical as it establishes the evidence upon which the auditor bases their opinions and findings.

Question 55
Which of the following is NOT the assumption of Baumol's model of cash management?
  • A.The firm is unable to forecast its cash needs with certainty
  • B.The opportunity cost of holding cash is known
  • C.The firm will incur the same transaction cost whenever it converts securities to cash
  • D.The firm's cash payments occur uniformly over a period of time
Correct Answer: The firm is unable to forecast its cash needs with certainty

Baumol's model of cash management assumes that:

The opportunity cost of holding cash is known (B).

The transaction cost is fixed whenever converting securities to cash (C).

Cash payments occur uniformly over time (D).

However, it does not assume uncertainty in forecasting cash needs. The model presumes that cash requirements can be predicted accurately. Hence, option (A) is not an assumption of the Baumol model.

Question 56
Arrange the given component tasks to be handled in positioning in the logical sequence -A. Developing the value propositionB. Analysing competitors' positioning: Is there a gap somewhere?C. Communicating the value proposition to target consumersD. Deciding the locus in consumers' mind: Where to lodge the product/brand?E. Ensuring the infrastructure/competitive advantage for delivering the premiseChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, B, A, E, C
  • B.D, B, E, A, C
  • C.B, D, A, E, C
  • D.B, D, C, A, E
Correct Answer: D, B, E, A, C

Here’s the logical sequence for positioning:

D. Deciding the locus in consumers' mind: Where to lodge the product/brand?

Determine how you want the product/brand to be perceived in the consumer's mind.

B. Analyzing competitors' positioning: Is there a gap somewhere?

Assess the market and identify any gaps or opportunities relative to competitors.

E. Ensuring the infrastructure/competitive advantage for delivering the premise

Make sure the organization can deliver on the positioning promise.

A. Developing the value proposition

Create a compelling value proposition to differentiate the brand/product.

C. Communicating the value proposition to target consumers

Finally, convey the value proposition to the target audience through appropriate channels.

Thus, the sequence is D, B, E, A, C.

Question 57
Which of the following subsidiaries are fully owned by the Reserve Bank of India?A. National Housing BankB. National Bank for Agriculture and Rural DevelopmentC. The Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation of IndiaD. Bhartiya Reserve Bank NoteMudranPrivate LimitedE. Securities Trading Corporation of IndiaChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.C & D Only
  • B.A, D & E Only
  • C.B, D & E Only
  • D.B, C & E Only
Correct Answer: C & D Only

The Deposit Insurance and Credit Guarantee Corporation of India (C) and Bhartiya Reserve Bank Note Mudran Private Limited (D) are fully owned subsidiaries of the Reserve Bank of India.

Question 58
Which of the following item is included in the definition of the term "Goods" as per Sales of Goods Act, 1930?
  • A.Purchase of lottery tickets
  • B.The decree of Court of Law
  • C.Actionable claims
  • D.Immovable Property
Correct Answer: The decree of Court of Law

According to the Sales of Goods Act, 1930, "goods" are defined as every kind of movable property, excluding actionable claims and money. This definition includes items such as stock and shares, growing crops, grass, and items that are attached to or form part of the land, provided they are agreed to be severed before sale or under the contract of sale.

 

Actionable claims (Option C) and immovable property (Option D) are explicitly excluded from this definition. Actionable claims refer to claims that can be enforced through legal action, which means they do not fall under the category of goods.

 

The purchase of lottery tickets (Option A) is considered an actionable claim, thus it is also not classified as goods.

 

However, the decree of a Court of Law (Option B) has been interpreted in various legal judgments as being included within the definition of goods, making it a valid item under this definition.

Therefore, the correct interpretation is that the decree of a Court of Law is recognized as "goods" in the context of the Sales of Goods Act, 1930.

Question 59
Which of the following are cases of Funds Flow?A. Payment of trade creditors by sale of LandB. Cash collection from debtorsC. Purchase of Furniture by issue of bills payableD. Payment oflong termloan by cashE. Payment of bills payable by cashChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, D & E only
  • B.B, C & D only
  • C.A, C & D only
  • D.B & E only
Correct Answer: A, C & D only

The term "flow" refers to change or movement. Therefore, "flow of funds" indicates changes in funds or working capital. In business, numerous transactions occur daily. Some transactions increase funds, while others decrease them, and some have no impact on the funds position.

 

Transactions that result in an increase in funds are termed "sources of funds," whereas those that decrease funds are called "applications of funds." If a transaction does not alter the funds position, it is labeled a "non-fund transaction."

 

A. Current Assets and Current Liabilities

Current Assets are assets intended to be converted into cash within a year or within the normal operating cycle of the business. Examples include cash, bank deposits, inventories, prepaid expenses, accounts receivable, bills receivable, and short-term investments.

 

Current Liabilities are obligations expected to be settled in the near future, typically within one year or the normal operating cycle. They include accounts payable, bills payable, accrued expenses, bank overdrafts, short-term loans, dividends payable, and tax payables. An obligation is considered a current liability only if it can be settled using existing current assets or by creating new current liabilities.

 

B. Non-Current Assets and Non-Current Liabilities

Non-Current Assets encompass all assets other than current assets. These include land, buildings, machinery, furniture, goodwill, patents, copyrights, and long-term investments in other companies.

 

Non-Current Liabilities refer to obligations that are not classified as current liabilities. These consist of share capital, debentures, long-term loans, share premiums, and reserves (such as general reserves and capital redemption reserves).

 

C. Identifying Transactions Affecting Flow of Funds

To prepare a funds flow statement, it’s crucial to identify which transactions affect the flow of funds (changes in working capital) and which do not. The following guidelines can help in this identification:

 

Transactions Among Current Accounts:

•Transactions involving two current assets do not affect funds.

•Transactions involving two current liabilities do not affect funds.

•Transactions between current assets and current liabilities do not affect funds.

 

For example, if a company collects Rs.25,000 from its debtors, debtors decrease by Rs.25,000, but cash increases by the same amount. Thus, the total current assets remain unchanged, indicating that this transaction does not affect funds.

 

Transactions Among Non-Current Accounts:

•Transactions involving two non-current (fixed) assets do not affect funds.

•Transactions involving two long-term liabilities do not affect funds.

•Transactions between non-current assets and long-term liabilities do not affect funds.

 

For instance, if a company purchases furniture for Rs.15,000 using a long-term loan of Rs.15,000, this transaction does not impact working capital, as both are non-current accounts.

 

Transactions Between Current and Non-Current Accounts:

•Transactions involving a current asset and a fixed asset affect funds.

•Transactions involving a current liability and a fixed asset affect funds.

•Transactions involving a current asset and a fixed liability affect funds.

•Transactions involving a current liability and a fixed liability affect funds.

 

For example, if a company raises Rs.75,000 in cash by issuing shares, the cash position increases by Rs.75,000 without altering current liabilities, leading to an increase in working capital by the same amount. Similarly, the sale of fixed assets or repayment of long-term liabilities using cash or current liabilities will affect the working capital.

 

Now, let’s look at each of the option given in the question.

 

A. Payment of trade creditors by sale of land: This transaction affects the flow of funds because it involves a current liability (payment to trade creditors) and the sale of a non-current asset (land). Therefore, it changes the funds position.

 

B. Cash collection from debtors: This transaction does not affect the flow of funds. Collecting cash from debtors simply converts one current asset (debtors) into another (cash), leaving total current assets unchanged.

 

C. Purchase of furniture by issue of bills payable: This transaction affects the flow of funds because it involves acquiring a non-current asset (furniture) and increasing current liabilities (bills payable).

 

D. Payment of long-term loan by cash: This transaction affects the flow of funds because it decreases cash (a current asset) and decreases long-term liabilities (the loan). It results in a change in the funds position.

 

E. Payment of bills payable by cash: This transaction involves a decrease in cash (a current asset) and a decrease in current liabilities (bills payable), but it does not affect the overall working capital since it is a movement between current asset and current liability.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C), i.e., statement A, C and D.

Question 60
A statistical statement inInternationalbusiness that shows at a point the value of financial assets of residents of an economy that are claims on non-residents or are gold bullion held as reserve assets and the liabilities of residents of an economy to non-residents is known as
  • A.Currency Composition Table
  • B.Special Purpose Entities (SPEs)
  • C.Cross Border Flows
  • D.The International Investment Position (IIP
Correct Answer: The International Investment Position (IIP

The International Investment Position (IIP) is a statistical statement that shows the value of a country's financial assets and liabilities with the rest of the world at a specific point in time. It includes claims on non-residents, reserve assets, and liabilities owed to non-residents, reflecting the country's financial relationships globally.

Question 61
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Negotiable Instruments)A. Inchoate InstrumentB. Ambiguous InstrumentC. EscrowD. Fictitious BillLIST II (Their Explanation)I. When negotiable instrument is delivered conditionally or for a specific purpose as a collateral security or for safe custody onlyII. When the name of the drawer, or the payee, or both are fake in a billIII. When the instrument owing to its faulty drafting may be interpreted either as a promissory note or bill of exchangeIV. An incomplete instrument in some respect, where a person signs & delivers to another a blank or incomplete paperChoose the coffee answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-II, B-III, C-I, D-IV
  • B.A-III, B-II, C-IV, D-I
  • C.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-I, B-II, C-III, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II

The correct match is as follows.

LIST I (Negotiable Instruments) - LIST II (Their Explanation)

A. Inchoate Instrument - An incomplete instrument in some respect, where a person signs & delivers to another a blank or incomplete paper

B. Ambiguous Instrument - When the instrument owing to its faulty drafting may be interpreted either as a promissory note or bill of exchange

 

C. Escrow - When negotiable instrument is delivered conditionally or for a specific purpose as a collateral security or for safe custody only

D. Fictitious Bill - When the name of the drawer, or the payee, or both are fake in a bill

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C) - A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II.

Question 62
Which one of the following cost-value-price trio, a manufacturer would like to seek?
  • A.Value > Price > Costs
  • B.Price > Value > Costs
  • C.Price > Costs > Value
  • D.Price = Value > Costs
Correct Answer: Price = Value > Costs

The correct answer is (D) Price = Value > Costs.

A manufacturer aims for the price to equal the perceived value to the customer, while keeping costs lower than both, ensuring profitability.

Question 63
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Purpose for which deduction is given under the Income-tax Act, 1961)A. Contribution toAgnipathSchemeB. Profits and gains from business of collecting and processing of bio- degradable wasteC. Interest on deposits in case of senior citizensD. Contributions given by companies to political partiesLIST II (Relevant Section)I. Section 8OTTBII. Section 80GGBIII. Section 80CCHIV. Section 80JJAChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II
  • B.A-II, B-IV, C-III, D-I
  • C.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
  • D.A-I, B-II, C-IV, D-III
Correct Answer: A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II

The correct match is as follows.

LIST I - LIST II

(Purpose for which deduction is given under the Income-tax Act, 1961) - (Relevant Section)

A. Contribution to Agnipath Scheme - Section 80CCH

A new section 80CCH to the Act has been inserted vide Finance Act 2023 to provide that an assessee, being an individual enrolled in the Agnipath Scheme and subscribing to the Agniveer Corpus Fund on or after the 1st day of November, 2022, shall be allowed a deduction of the whole of the amount deposited by him and also the amount contributed by the Central Government to his account in the Agniveer Corpus Fund, from his total income.

 

B. Profits and gains from business of collecting and processing of bio- degradable waste - Section 80JJA

This deduction is available to the taxpayer, who is in the business of collecting, processing or treating of bio-degradable waste for generating power or producing bio-fertilizers, bio-pesticides or other biological agents or for producing bio-gas or making pellets or briquettes for fuel or organic manure. The amount of deduction is 100% profit from any such activity and is deductible for first 5 years.

C. Interest on deposits in case of senior citizens - Section 8OTTB

The deduction under this Section is available from AY 2019-20, with respect to, interest on deposit in saving/fixed account of a senior citizen (at least 60 years of age) with a banking company, a post office, co-operative society engaged in banking business, etc. (subject to certain conditions). The deduction is available up to 100% of amount of such income subject to maximum of Rs. 50,000.

 

D. Contributions given by companies to political parties - Section 80GGB

This Section provides for deduction of any sum, contributed in the previous year, by an Indian company (Section 80GGB) to any political party or an electoral trust. However, no deduction shall be allowed in respect of any sum contributed by way of cash. The deduction is not available to a local authority and every artificial juridical person wholly or partly funded by the Government. From AY 2014-15, no deduction shall be allowed in respect of any contribution (which is given in cash) to a political party.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (A), i.e., A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II.

Question 64
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Product)A. DinosaurB. FlamingoC. OstrichD. PearlLIST II (Description)I. Products that are beautiful but unsaleableII. Products that are blind to the futureIII. Products that are source of a profitable futureIV. Products that have missed their nicheChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-IV, B-II, C-I, D-III
  • B.A-II, B-I, C-IV, D-III
  • C.A-I, B-II, C-IV, D-III
  • D.A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III

To match the items in List I (Product) with their corresponding descriptions in List II, we can analyze each product and description to find the best matches.

 

A. Dinosaur - IV. Products that have missed their niche

Dinosaurs are extinct and represent a product that no longer fits into any current market or niche.

 

B. Flamingo - I. Products that are beautiful but unsaleable

Flamingos are often considered beautiful but may not have a practical market demand, making them more of a decorative or aesthetic product rather than a saleable one.

C. Ostrich - II. Products that are blind to the future

Ostriches are sometimes seen as a product that has not adapted to changes or trends in the market (e.g., their feathers or meat). This can suggest a failure to recognize future opportunities.

 

D. Pearl - III. Products that are a source of a profitable future

Pearls are often seen as valuable and can be a source of profit, representing luxury and long-term market value.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (D) i.e., A-IV, B-I, C-II, D-III.

Question 65
Data preparation needs to ensure the accuracy of the data and their conversion from raw form to reduced and classified forms for analysis. It includes which of the following:A. CodingB. Data EntryC. EditingD.StemingE. AliasingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A & C only
  • B.B & D only
  • C.A, B & C only
  • D.C, D & E only
Correct Answer: A, B & C only

The correct answer is (C) A, B & C only.

 

Data preparation involves processes such as coding (assigning numerical or other symbols to responses), data entry (inputting data into a system), and editing (reviewing data for errors). These steps ensure data accuracy and organization for analysis. Stemming and aliasing are not typically part of the standard data preparation process in this context.

Question 66
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Concept)A. Systematic riskB. BetaC. Risk-free rateD. Unsystematic riskLIST II (Meaning)I. Compensation for timeII. Increase in corporate tax rateIII. Sensitivity coefficientIV. Competitor enters the marketChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- I, B-IV, C- III, D-II
  • B.A- IV, B-I, C-II, D-III
  • C.A-III, B-II, C-IV, D-I
  • D.A-II, B-III, C-I, D-IV
Correct Answer: A-II, B-III, C-I, D-IV

The correct answer is (D) A-II, B-III, C-I, D-IV.

Here’s the matching explanation:

A. Systematic risk – II. Increase in corporate tax rate: Systematic risk is related to market-wide factors, such as changes in economic policies or tax rates, that affect all companies.

B. Beta – III. Sensitivity coefficient: Beta measures a stock's sensitivity to market movements, indicating its systematic risk.

C. Risk-free rate – I. Compensation for time: The risk-free rate represents the return on an investment with no risk, compensating for the time value of money.

D. Unsystematic risk – IV. Competitor enters the market: Unsystematic risk is specific to a company or industry, such as changes due to a new competitor.

Thus, the correct matching is A-II, B-III, C-I, D-IV.

Question 67
The current ratio of a company is 2:1 Which one the following suggestions would improve the current ratio?
  • A.Purchase of stock for cash
  • B.Cash collection from debtors
  • C.Pay a current liability
  • D.Purchase of fixed assets
Correct Answer: Pay a current liability

To determine which option would improve the current ratio of a company, let’s first understand what the current ratio represents. The current ratio is calculated as:

 

Current Ratio= Current AssetsCurrent Liabilities

 

Now, given Current Ratio: 2:1, this means that for every 2 units of current assets, there is 1 unit of current liabilities. Thus, to improve current ratio, either the current assets must increase, or current liabilities must decrease.

 

Let us now analyze each of the given question:

 

(A) Purchase of stock for cash: This transaction does not affect the current ratio because both current assets (stock) and cash are current assets. While stock increases one component, cash decreases by the same amount, leaving the overall current assets unchanged.

 

(B) Cash collection from debtors: This transaction also does not affect the current ratio. Collecting cash from debtors converts one current asset (accounts receivable) into another (cash), resulting in no overall change in current assets.

 

(C) Pay a current liability: Paying a current liability will increase the current ratio. This is because paying a current liability decreases both current assets (cash) and current liabilities by the same amount, but the decrease in current liabilities has a larger impact on the ratio calculation since it's in the denominator. 

 

 

(D) Purchase of fixed assets: This transaction does not directly affect the current ratio. When a company uses current assets (like cash) to purchase fixed assets, current assets decrease while non-current assets increase, leading to a lower current ratio.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C).

Question 68
Arrange the following banks in an increasing order of their year of formation-A. State Bank of IndiaB. Imperial Bank of IndiaC. Reserve Bank of IndiaD. Regional Rural BanksE. Small Finance BankChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, D, C, B, A
  • B.E, D, A, B, C
  • C.B, C, A, D, E
  • D.C, B, A, D, E
Correct Answer: B, C, A, D, E

The banks in an increasing order of their year of formation are as follows:

B. Imperial Bank of India – 27.01.1921

C. Reserve Bank of India – 01.04.1935

A. State Bank of India – 01.07.1955

D. Regional Rural Banks - 1975

E. Small Finance Bank – 2016

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (C) i.e., B, C, A, D, E.

Question 69
Arrange the following steps ofdecision makingprocess in application of Economics in Business decision making from starting to end -A. Selection and Implementation of the DecisionB. Inventing, developing possible Course of ActionC. Collection and Analysis of Relevant DataD. Identifying Business Related IssuesE. Determining and defining objectiveChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, C, E, B, A
  • B.C, D, B, E, A
  • C.B, C, D, E, A
  • D.E, D, C, B, A
Correct Answer: E, D, C, B, A

The correct answer is (D) E, D, C, B, A.

Here is the sequence of the decision-making process:

E. Determining and defining objective: Start by identifying the goal or purpose of the decision.

D. Identifying Business Related Issues: Understand and clarify the business problems that need to be addressed.

C. Collection and Analysis of Relevant Data: Gather and analyze data that will support the decision-making process.

B. Inventing, developing possible Course of Action: Develop various potential courses of action to achieve the objective.

A. Selection and Implementation of the Decision: Select the best option and put it into action.

This sequence is logical for using economics in business decision-making.

Question 70
The tool that International Development Association (IDA) uses to address the impact of severe natural disasters, public health emergencies by providing extra finances is known as:
  • A.Emergency Response Fund (ERF)
  • B.Long term Lending system
  • C.Crisis Response Window (CRW)
  • D.Monetary Fund
Correct Answer: Crisis Response Window (CRW)

The Crisis Response Window (CRW) is a tool used by the International Development Association (IDA) to provide additional financial resources to countries affected by severe natural disasters, public health emergencies, and other crises. This helps affected countries recover and rebuild more effectively.

Question 71
Arrange the given steps involved in designing a channel system in the logical order -A. Evaluating the distribution environmentB. Evaluating the short-listed alternative designs and selecting the one that suits the firm bestC. Matching the channel design to customer needs/characteristicsD. Choosing the channel intensity and number of tiersE. Evaluating competitors channel designChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, E, B, D
  • B.C, A, E, D, B
  • C.C, E, D, A, B
  • D.C, A, E, B, D
Correct Answer: C, A, E, B, D

Here’s the logical order for designing a channel system:

C. Matching the channel design to customer needs/characteristics: Start by understanding and aligning the channel design with the needs and characteristics of the target customers.

A. Evaluating the distribution environment: Assess the market and distribution conditions to understand any constraints or opportunities.

E. Evaluating competitors' channel design: Analyze how competitors have set up their channel systems to identify best practices or potential gaps.

B. Evaluating the short-listed alternative designs and selecting the one that suits the firm best: Compare the possible channel options and choose the most suitable one.

D. Choosing the channel intensity and number of tiers: Decide on the level of distribution coverage and the number of intermediary tiers to effectively reach the target market.

Thus, the correct sequence is C, A, E, B, D.

Question 72
Which of the following are primary functions of Commercial Banks:A. Accepting DepositsB. Agency ServiceC. Discounting Trade BillsD. Financing Foreign TradeE. General Utility ServiceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C & E only
  • B.A, B & D only
  • C.B, C & E only
  • D.A, C & D only
Correct Answer: A, C & D only

The primary functions of commercial banks include:

A. Accepting Deposits: The fundamental activity of a bank is to accept deposits from individuals and businesses.

C. Discounting Trade Bills: Commercial banks provide liquidity by discounting trade bills.

D. Financing Foreign Trade: Commercial banks play a crucial role in financing international trade by issuing letters of credit, guarantees, etc.

Agency services (B) and general utility services (E) are considered secondary functions rather than primary functions.

Question 73
An exploratory study is finished when the researcher has achieved the following:A. Established the major dimensions of the research taskB. Defined a set of subsidiary investigative questions that can be used as guides to a detailed research designC. Developed several hypotheses about possible causes of a management dilemmaD. Learned that certain other hypothesis are such remote possibilities that they can be safely ignored in any subsequent studyE. Concluded additional research is needed and it is feasibleChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A & B only
  • B.A, B & C only
  • C.A, B, C & D only
  • D.B, C, D & E only
Correct Answer: A, B, C & D only

An exploratory study is completed when the researcher:

A. Establishes the major dimensions of the research task.

B. Defines a set of subsidiary investigative questions for detailed research.

C. Develops hypotheses about possible causes of a management issue.

D. Identifies hypotheses that can be ignored due to their low relevance.

Option E (Concluding additional research is needed and is feasible) refers to subsequent planning rather than completing the exploratory study.

Question 74
Which one of the following sources of power of the supervisor is NOT true for the subordinates to comply?
  • A.Reward
  • B.Coercive
  • C.Expert
  • D.Means-ends-control
Correct Answer: Expert

Expert power comes from the supervisor's knowledge or expertise, but subordinates may choose not to comply if they don't value or recognize that expertise, unlike the influence from reward, coercive, or means-ends-control power.

Question 75
A person applies for a loan of 51,00,000. The bank informed him that over the years, it had received 2920 loan applications per year and the probability of approval was, on an average 0.85. The applicant wants to know the average number of loans approved per year by the bank. What can be that number?
  • A.1920
  • B.3250
  • C.1000
  • D.2482
Correct Answer: 2482

The average number of loans approved per year is calculated by multiplying the total number of applications by the probability of approval:

2920 × 0.85 = 2482

Thus, the average number of loans approved per year by the bank is 2482.

Question 76
Which of the following are true about the equilibrium of theIndustryin long run under perfect competition?A. The long-run supply and demand for the product of the industry should be in equilibriumB. All firms in the industry should be in long run equilibrium by equating price with long-run marginal cost (P=LMC)C. There should be tendency for the new firms to enter the industry, or for the existing firms to leave itD. The firms are earning zero economic profits with price being equal to long-run minimum average cost (P=min. LAC)E The firms would not have adjusted their size of plants when there is long-run equilibrium (P=LMC)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & C only
  • B.C, D & E only
  • C.A, B & D only
  • D.B, C & D only
Correct Answer: A, B & D only

In long-run equilibrium under perfect competition:

A. Long-run supply and demand must be in equilibrium: Industry demand equals industry supply.

B. Firms equate price with long-run marginal cost (P = LMC): Ensuring no further profit opportunities exist.

D. Firms earn zero economic profits (P = min. LAC): Price equals the minimum average cost, meaning only normal profits are earned.

Option C is incorrect because, in long-run equilibrium, there is no tendency for firms to enter or leave the industry (because there is no economic profit).

Option E is incorrect as firms adjust their plant size in response to long-run equilibrium conditions.

Question 77
Under section 206C of the Income-tax Act, 1961, a seller is supposed to collect income tax from the buyer in respect of sale of the following goods:A. Motor Vehicle of the value between Rs. 7,00,000 - Rs. 9,00,000B. Alcoholic liquor for human consumptionC. Electronic items of the value between Rs. 10,00,000 - Rs. 15,00,000D. Timber obtained under a forest leaseE. Minerals, being coal or lignite or iron oreChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C & E Only
  • B.B, D & E Only
  • C.A & C Only
  • D.B & E Only
Correct Answer: B, D & E Only

Tax Collected at Source (TCS) is income tax collected in India, payable by the seller, who collects, in turn, from the buyer and it is provided under Section 206C of Income Tax Act, 1961, at the sale of some goods which are specified. The TCS Rate is different for each category of goods.

Types of Goods

Rate of TCS

Liquor of alcoholic nature, made for consumption by humans

1%

Timber Wood under a forest leased

2.5%

Tendu Leaves

5%

Timber wood by any other mode (other than forest leased)

2.5%

Forest produce, other than Tendu leaves and timber

2.5%

Scrap

1%

Minerals like lignite, coal and iron ore

1%

Purchase of Motor Vehicle exceeding Rs. 10 Lakhs

1%

Parking lot, Toll Plaza and Mining and Quarrying

2%

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B), i.e., B, D and E only.

Question 78
Which one of the following is NOT true about the relationship between Average Cost (AC) and Marginal Cost (MC)?
  • A.When MC is falling, the rate of fall in MC is greater than that of AC
  • B.When MC increases, AC also increase but at a lower rate. However, there is a range of output where MC begins to increase while AC continue to decrease
  • C.When AC is constant, AC
  • D.MC curve intersects AC curve at its minimum
Correct Answer: When AC is constant, AC

When Average Cost (AC) is constant, it means that the cost per unit is neither increasing nor decreasing. In this case, Marginal Cost (MC) must be equal to AC to maintain a constant average. Therefore, AC = MC, making option (C) incorrect.

Question 79
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Trade Agreement Types)A. Early Harvest Scheme (EHS)B. Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA)C. Preferential Trade AgreementD. Free Trade AgreementLIST II (Description)I. Two or more parties give right of entry to certain products by reducing duties on an agreed number in tariff linesII. In which two or more countries agree to provide trade terms,tarrifconcession to partner countriesIII. A Precursor of CECA, thus a step towards enhanced engagement and confidence buildingIV. Looks into the regulatory aspect of trade and encompasses an agreement on customs, competition & IPRChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A- III, B- IV, C- I, D-II
  • B.A- IV, B- III, C- II, D-I
  • C.A- I, B- III, C- II, D-IV
  • D.A- II, B- I, C- IV, D-III
Correct Answer: A- III, B- IV, C- I, D-II

The correct answer is (A) A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II.

Explanation:

A. Early Harvest Scheme (EHS) – III: EHS is a preliminary step towards a Comprehensive Economic Cooperation Agreement (CECA), used for building confidence and enhancing engagement.

B. Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) – IV: CEPA looks into regulatory aspects like customs, competition, and intellectual property rights (IPR).

C. Preferential Trade Agreement – I: In a PTA, parties reduce tariffs on an agreed number of products, providing preferential treatment.

D. Free Trade Agreement – II: FTAs involve trade terms and tariff concessions between two or more countries to facilitate free trade.

Thus, the correct matching is A-III, B-IV, C-I, D-II.

Question 80
Which among the following are the key aspects/ determinants for an equilibrium under monopolistic competition?A. The mobility of factors of productionB. The PriceC. Imperfect knowledge about the marketD. The Nature of the ProductE. The amount of advertising outlayChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, D & E only
  • B.A, B & C only
  • C.B, C & D only
  • D.C, D & E only
Correct Answer: B, D & E only

Key aspects of equilibrium under monopolistic competition include:

 

B. The Price: Firms in monopolistic competition set prices above marginal cost due to product differentiation.

D. The Nature of the Product: Differentiation plays a crucial role, as each firm offers a unique product.

E. The Amount of Advertising Outlay: Firms spend on advertising to differentiate their product and increase demand.

Question 81
Which of the following are the instruments of qualitative Credit Control Methods in India's Monetary Policy?A. Cash Reserve RatioB. Consumer Credit RegulationC. Altering Margin RequirementsD. Statutory Liquidity RatioE. Differential Rate of InterestChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & D only
  • B.B, C & E only
  • C.C, D & E only
  • D.D, E & A only
Correct Answer: B, C & E only

Qualitative credit control methods in India's monetary policy include Consumer Credit Regulation (B), Altering Margin Requirements (C), and Differential Rate of Interest (E), which help influence credit distribution to specific sectors. Cash Reserve Ratio (A) and Statutory Liquidity Ratio (D) are quantitative tools, not qualitative.

Question 82
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Theories of International Investment)A. Eclectic TheoryB. Appropriability TheoryC. Market Imperfection TheoryD Theory of Capital MovementsLIST II (Outline of Theory)I. FDI occurs largely in oligopolistic industries rather than in industries operating under near perfect competitionII. Capital as an investment will move from countries where it is abundant to countries where itis scarce because the returns on investment opportunities are higher where capital is limitedIII. The firm should be able to keep the benefits resulting from its innovation & Research for its exclusive useIV. The framework follows three tiers-ownership, location and internalization, assuming that companies are not likely to follow through the FDI, if they can get the service or product internally and at lower costsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A-IV, B-I, C-III, D-II
  • B.A-I, B-III, C-II, D-IV
  • C.A-III, B-IV, C-II, D-I
  • D.A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II
Correct Answer: A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II

The correct match is as follows:

A. Eclectic Theory – IV: This theory involves the ownership, location, and internalization (OLI) framework to determine why companies engage in foreign direct investment (FDI).

B. Appropriability Theory – III: This theory suggests firms must protect and exclusively use the benefits from their innovation and research.

C. Market Imperfection Theory – I: According to this theory, FDI is more common in oligopolistic industries than in those with near-perfect competition.

D. Theory of Capital Movements – II: This theory explains that capital moves from countries where it is abundant to countries where it is scarce due to higher returns.

Thus, the correct matching is A-IV, B-III, C-I, D-II.

Question 83
Under the Income-Tax-Act, 1961, the value of perquisite in respect of movable assets (other than the assets already specified in Rule 3 of the Income tax Rules, 1962) owned by the employer is calculated at the rateof :
  • A.10% per annum of the actual cost
  • B.20% per annum of the actual cost
  • C.10% per month of the actual cost
  • D.20% per month of the actual cost
Correct Answer: 10% per annum of the actual cost

As per the provisions of the Income Tax Act, 961, perquisite in respect of use of moveable assets is as follows:

 

If computer/ laptop is provided by an employer to employee, nothing is chargeable to tax in the hands of employee. If any other moveable asset is provided to an employee, the perquisite is chargeable to tax in the hands of employee. 10% per annum of actual cost of asset to the employer (or hire charges) as reduced by any amount recovered from the employee is a taxable perquisite in the hands of employee.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (A).

Question 84
A company forfeits 100 shares of Rs. 10 each on which Rs. 300 had been received. 60 shares are reissued at Rs. 9 per share. Which one of the followingamountsis to be transferred to Capital Reserve Account?
  • A.Rs. 200
  • B.Rs. 180
  • C.Rs. 120
  • D.Rs. 60
Correct Answer: Rs. 120

Since the company has forfeited Rs. 3 per share (300 ÷ 100), the amount forfeited on re-issued shares is (60 × Rs. 3) = Rs. 180, the amount with which the share forfeiture account will be credited.

 

Also, the company re-issues these forfeited shares at Re. 1 (10 – 1) discount each, thus the share forfeiture account will be debited with Rs. 60 (60 × Rs. 1).

 

The total amount of share forfeiture account to be transferred to Capital Reserve account will be Rs. 180 – Rs. 60 = Rs. 120.

Question 85
Match the List-I with List-IILIST I (Valuation of Human Resources approach)A. Historical Cost approachB. Replacement Cost approachC. Opportunity Cost approachD. Standard Cost approachLIST II (Developed by)I.RensisLikert and Eric GFlamhollzII. Hekimian and JonesIII. David WatsonIV. BrummetFlamhottzand PyleChoose the correct answer from the options given below
  • A.A- I, B- II, C- III, D-IV
  • B.A- III, B- IV, C- I, D-II
  • C.A- I, B-IV, C- II, D-III
  • D.A- IV, B- I, C- II, D-III
Correct Answer: A- IV, B- I, C- II, D-III

The correct match is as follows.

A. Historical Cost approach → IV. Brummet, Flamhottz, and Pyle

B. Replacement Cost approach → I. Rensis Likert and Eric G Flamhollz

C. Opportunity Cost approach → II. Hekimian and Jones

D. Standard Cost approach → III. David Watson

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 86
Which one of the following is not a basic property of Indifference curve?
  • A.Indifference curve slope downwards to right
  • B.Indifference curve of imperfect substitutesareconvex to the origin
  • C.Indifference curve either intersect or are tangent to one another
  • D.Upper indifference curves indicate a higher level of satisfaction
Correct Answer: Indifference curve either intersect or are tangent to one another

Indifference curves never intersect or become tangent to one another because each curve represents a different level of satisfaction. If they were to intersect, it would imply inconsistent preferences, which contradicts the basic principles of consumer theory. Other properties include downward sloping (A), convex shape for imperfect substitutes (B), and higher curves representing higher satisfaction (D).

Question 87
Arrange the following Financial Institution in the increasing order of their date of establishment-A. NABARDB. EXIM BankC. UTID. SIDBIE. ECGCChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.C, B, A, D, E
  • C.C, A, B, E, D
  • D.E, C, B, A, D
Correct Answer: E, C, B, A, D

The following Financial Institution in the increasing order of their date of establishment-

E. ECGC – 30 July 1957

C. UTI - 1963

B. EXIM Bank – 1 January 1982

A. NABARD – 12 July 1982

D. SIDBI – 2 April 1990

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D), i.e., E, C, B, A, D.

Question 88
Arrange the given Prefatory Information sub - modules into a sequence to form a Long Management Report -A. Title PageB. Executive SummaryC. Table of contentsD. Letter of transmittalE. Authorization statementChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B, C, D, A, E
  • B.E, D, B, C, A
  • C.D, A, E, B, C
  • D.C, A, D, E, B
Correct Answer: D, A, E, B, C

The correct sequence is as follows.

Letter of Transmittal (D): This is typically the first item, as it accompanies the report and provides context.

Title Page (A): The title page follows the letter of transmittal, presenting the title and basic report information.

Authorization Statement (E): This statement comes next, indicating who authorized the report.

Executive Summary (B): The executive summary provides a concise overview of the report’s key points.

Table of Contents (C): Finally, the table of contents lists the sections of the report, helping readers navigate it.

Question 89
The maximum number of Partners in a Limited Liability Partnership canbe :
  • A.Seven
  • B.Fifty
  • C.Hundred
  • D.No Limit
Correct Answer: No Limit

In a Limited Liability Partnership (LLP), the number of partners is not capped. The law governing LLPs does not specify a maximum limit on the number of partners, allowing for flexibility in terms of partnership size.

Question 90
Which of the following antecedent conditions explain intergroup conflict?A. Personal differencesB. Competition for resourcesC. Role incompatibilityD. Task independenceE. Jurisdictional ambiguityChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & C Only
  • B.A, B, D & E only
  • C.A, C & D Only
  • D.B, D & E Only
Correct Answer: B, D & E Only

The factors that can lead to inter-group conflict and suggests stages for managing or mitigating such conflicts are as follows.

 

Competition for Resources: When groups compete for limited resources (like money, time, or personnel), it can lead to tension and conflict. Each group may feel entitled to the resources, leading to disputes.

 

Task Interdependence: When groups rely on one another to complete tasks or achieve goals, any misalignment in objectives, priorities, or performance can result in conflict. The more dependent they are, the more likely conflicts can arise if one group perceives the other as not pulling its weight.

 

Jurisdictional Ambiguity: Confusion over roles and responsibilities can create conflict. If group members are unclear about their authority or tasks, it can lead to overlaps and disputes, with each group claiming jurisdiction over certain areas.

 

Status Struggles: Competition for status and recognition can lead to conflicts. Groups may vie for prestige, leading to negative interactions and disputes over who is more valued or important.

 

Stages to Avoid Inter-Group Conflict

Understanding the antecedent conditions that lead to inter-group conflict is crucial for effective conflict management. By employing these stages—avoidance, diffusion, containment, and confrontation—groups can address and resolve conflicts more effectively, promoting a more collaborative and harmonious working environment.

 

Avoidance: This involves steering clear of the issues or situations that may lead to conflict. Groups may choose to ignore the differences or disagreements, hoping they will resolve themselves. While it may provide temporary relief, it doesn't address underlying issues.

 

Diffusion: This stage aims to lessen the intensity of the conflict by promoting communication and understanding. It may involve informal discussions, team-building activities, or other methods to build rapport and understanding between groups.

 

Containment: If conflict has already arisen, containment strategies can be employed to limit the escalation. This might involve setting boundaries, clarifying roles, or temporarily separating conflicting parties to prevent further disputes.

 

Confrontation: In some cases, direct confrontation may be necessary to resolve deep-seated issues. This stage involves open dialogue about the conflict, facilitating discussions that allow each group to express their concerns, expectations, and proposed solutions.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (D).

Question 91
In which of the following cases, undue influence is presumed:
  • A.Creditor and debtor
  • B.Landlord and tenant
  • C.Husband and Wife
  • D.Parent and Child
Correct Answer: Parent and Child

A contract is said to be induced by “undue influence” where the relations subsisting between the parties are such that one of the parties is in a position to dominate the will of the other and uses that position to obtain an unfair advantage over the other.

 

In particular and without prejudice to the generality of the foregoing principle, a person is deemed

to be in a position to dominate the will of another—

(a) where he holds a real or apparent authority over the other, or where he stands in a fiduciary relation to the other; or

(b) where he makes a contract with a person whose mental capacity is temporarily or permanently

affected by reason of age, illness, or mental or bodily distress.

 

Where a person who is in a position to dominate the will of another, enters into a contract with him, and the transaction appears, on the face of it or on the evidence adduced, to be unconscionable, the

burden of proving that such contract was not induced by undue influence shall lie upon the person in a position to dominate the will of the other.

The relationships that raise presumptions of undue influence under the Indian Contract Act 1872 are:

(i) Parent and child

(ii) Doctor and patient

(iii) Fiance and fiancée.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option (D). It is important to note that although the relationship between husband and wife is inherently fiduciary, it does not raise a presumption of undue influence under the Indian Contract Act 1872.

 

If a presumption of undue influence is raised, the burden of proof shifts to the party in the dominant position to prove that the contract was entered into freely and voluntarily by the other party, without any undue influence.

Question 92
