Read the passage and answer the questions given below.The export hubs are expected to act as a centre for favourable business infrastructure and facilities for cross-border e-commerce, including facilitating faster customs clearance of cargo and also addressing the problem of reimportation because about 25 per cent of goods in e-commerce are reimported. Additionally, the hubs will offer warehousing facilities, processing returns, labelling, product, testing, repackaging items and dedicated logistics infrastructure for connecting to and leveraging the services of nearby logistics hubs, thereby achieving agglomeration benefits for exporters.In an attempt to leverage e-commerce platforms to support local exporters, manufacturers and MSMEs in reaching potential international buyers, the DGFT signed a memorandum of understanding with global e-commerce firm Amazon last year to offer capacity-building sessions, training and workshops for MSMEs across districts identified by the DGFT as part of the "District as Exports Hub" initiative. Amazon surpassed $8 billion in cumulative exports from India in 2023 and aims to achieve its ambitious target of $20 billion by next year.India's exports through online platforms stood at $8-10 billion in 2022-23 compared to China's staggering figure of more than $300 billion. A key reason for this gap is the cumbersome compliance process associated with exports, especially when it comes to payment reconciliation, which is particularly challenging for new or small exporters. At the same time, global cross-border e-commerce trade was $800 billion. With India's cross-border e-commerce exports likely to increase to $200 billion over the next six to seven years, it can become a key strategy in achieving the $2 trillion overall exports target by 2030.India's services export increased by only 515.8 billion in 2023-24 over 2022-23, while merchandise export declined $14 billion in the same period. Overall, India's combined value of exported goods and services registered a marginal increase of around $2 billion in 2023-24. At a time when export growth remains tepid and the overall trade deficit is around $78 billion, establishing a supportive e-commerce ecosystem can truly give a fillip to India's export performance. Given the patchwork of rules and export provisions framed for exporters, there is an urgent for a separate e-commerce export policy, which can ease the compliance burden on exporters.91.) Why there is an urgent need for a separate e-commerce export policy?A. Reimport issues are being addressed by existing export policiesB Cross-border e-commerce has gained significantly in last few yearsC. Existing exportcentershavefavorablebusiness infrastructureD. E-commerce export can be managed with existing logistic hubs E. E-commerce exports need a combination of facilities including warehousing, processing returns, repackingChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A & C Only
  • B.B, C & D Only
  • C.B & E Only
  • D.C, D & E Only
Correct Answer: B & E Only

The correct answer is (C), i.e., B & E Only

 

B: Cross-border e-commerce has gained significantly in the last few years.

E: E-commerce exports need a combination of facilities including warehousing, processing returns, repacking.

 

This reflects the need for a dedicated policy to address the specific requirements of e-commerce exports.

Question 93
Read the passage and answer the questions given below.The export hubs are expected to act as a centre for favourable business infrastructure and facilities for cross-border e-commerce, including facilitating faster customs clearance of cargo and also addressing the problem of reimportation because about 25 per cent of goods in e-commerce are reimported. Additionally, the hubs will offer warehousing facilities, processing returns, labelling, product, testing, repackaging items and dedicated logistics infrastructure for connecting to and leveraging the services of nearby logistics hubs, thereby achieving agglomeration benefits for exporters.In an attempt to leverage e-commerce platforms to support local exporters, manufacturers and MSMEs in reaching potential international buyers, the DGFT signed a memorandum of understanding with global e-commerce firm Amazon last year to offer capacity-building sessions, training and workshops for MSMEs across districts identified by the DGFT as part of the "District as Exports Hub" initiative. Amazon surpassed $8 billion in cumulative exports from India in 2023 and aims to achieve its ambitious target of $20 billion by next year.India's exports through online platforms stood at $8-10 billion in 2022-23 compared to China's staggering figure of more than $300 billion. A key reason for this gap is the cumbersome compliance process associated with exports, especially when it comes to payment reconciliation, which is particularly challenging for new or small exporters. At the same time, global cross-border e-commerce trade was $800 billion. With India's cross-border e-commerce exports likely to increase to $200 billion over the next six to seven years, it can become a key strategy in achieving the $2 trillion overall exports target by 2030.India's services export increased by only 515.8 billion in 2023-24 over 2022-23, while merchandise export declined $14 billion in the same period. Overall, India's combined value of exported goods and services registered a marginal increase of around $2 billion in 2023-24. At a time when export growth remains tepid and the overall trade deficit is around $78 billion, establishing a supportive e-commerce ecosystem can truly give a fillip to India's export performance. Given the patchwork of rules and export provisions framed for exporters, there is an urgent for a separate e-commerce export policy, which can ease the compliance burden on exporters.92.) E-commerce export hub can offer which of the following agglomeration benefits for exporters?A. Repacking and labelling of productsB. Substantial decrease in upfront cost incurred in exportC. Interconnection of Logistics Custom clearance exemptionD. Custom clearance exemptionE. Assured export ordersChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & C Only
  • B.B, C & D Only
  • C.A, B & E Only
  • D.C, D & E Only
Correct Answer: A, B & C Only

The correct answer is option (A), i.e., A, B & C only.

 

A: Repacking and labelling of products.

B: Substantial decrease in upfront costs incurred in export.

C: Interconnection of Logistics Custom clearance exemption.

 

These options encompass various logistical and operational advantages provided by the e-commerce export hub.

Question 94
Read the passage and answer the questions given below.The export hubs are expected to act as a centre for favourable business infrastructure and facilities for cross-border e-commerce, including facilitating faster customs clearance of cargo and also addressing the problem of reimportation because about 25 per cent of goods in e-commerce are reimported. Additionally, the hubs will offer warehousing facilities, processing returns, labelling, product, testing, repackaging items and dedicated logistics infrastructure for connecting to and leveraging the services of nearby logistics hubs, thereby achieving agglomeration benefits for exporters.In an attempt to leverage e-commerce platforms to support local exporters, manufacturers and MSMEs in reaching potential international buyers, the DGFT signed a memorandum of understanding with global e-commerce firm Amazon last year to offer capacity-building sessions, training and workshops for MSMEs across districts identified by the DGFT as part of the "District as Exports Hub" initiative. Amazon surpassed $8 billion in cumulative exports from India in 2023 and aims to achieve its ambitious target of $20 billion by next year.India's exports through online platforms stood at $8-10 billion in 2022-23 compared to China's staggering figure of more than $300 billion. A key reason for this gap is the cumbersome compliance process associated with exports, especially when it comes to payment reconciliation, which is particularly challenging for new or small exporters. At the same time, global cross-border e-commerce trade was $800 billion. With India's cross-border e-commerce exports likely to increase to $200 billion over the next six to seven years, it can become a key strategy in achieving the $2 trillion overall exports target by 2030.India's services export increased by only 515.8 billion in 2023-24 over 2022-23, while merchandise export declined $14 billion in the same period. Overall, India's combined value of exported goods and services registered a marginal increase of around $2 billion in 2023-24. At a time when export growth remains tepid and the overall trade deficit is around $78 billion, establishing a supportive e-commerce ecosystem can truly give a fillip to India's export performance. Given the patchwork of rules and export provisions framed for exporters, there is an urgent for a separate e-commerce export policy, which can ease the compliance burden on exporters.93.) India's export through online platforms in comparison to China in 2022-23 was-
  • A.9%
  • B.6%
  • C.12%
  • D.3%
Correct Answer: 3%

The passage states that India's exports through online platforms stood at $8-10 billion compared to China's more than $300 billion, indicating a significant gap. The percentage can be calculated as follows, if we take the average of India’s exports at 9 billion:

 

9300 × 100 = 3%

A key reason for this gap is the cumbersome compliance process associated with exports, especially when it comes to payment reconciliation, which is particularly challenging for new or small exporters. At the same time, global cross-border e-commerce trade was $800 billion. Question 96
Read the passage and answer the questions given below.The export hubs are expected to act as a centre for favourable business infrastructure and facilities for cross-border e-commerce, including facilitating faster customs clearance of cargo and also addressing the problem of reimportation because about 25 per cent of goods in e-commerce are reimported. Additionally, the hubs will offer warehousing facilities, processing returns, labelling, product, testing, repackaging items and dedicated logistics infrastructure for connecting to and leveraging the services of nearby logistics hubs, thereby achieving agglomeration benefits for exporters.In an attempt to leverage e-commerce platforms to support local exporters, manufacturers and MSMEs in reaching potential international buyers, the DGFT signed a memorandum of understanding with global e-commerce firm Amazon last year to offer capacity-building sessions, training and workshops for MSMEs across districts identified by the DGFT as part of the "District as Exports Hub" initiative.Amazon surpassed $8 billion in cumulative exports from India in 2023 and aims to achieve its ambitious target of $20 billion by next year.India's exports through online platforms stood at $8-10 billion in 2022-23 compared to China's staggering figure of more than $300 billion. A key reason for this gap is the cumbersome compliance process associated with exports, especially when it comes to payment reconciliation, which is particularly challenging for new or small exporters. At the same time, global cross-border e-commerce trade was $800 billion. With India's cross-border e-commerce exports likely to increase to $200 billion over the next six to seven years, it can become a key strategy in achieving the $2 trillion overall exports target by 2030.India's services export increased by only 515.8 billion in 2023-24 over 2022-23, while merchandise export declined $14 billion in the same period. Overall, India's combined value of exported goods and services registered a marginal increase of around $2 billion in 2023-24. At a time when export growth remains tepid and the overall trade deficit is around $78 billion, establishing a supportive e-commerce ecosystem can truly give a fillip to India's export performance. Given the patchwork of rules and export provisions framed for exporters, there is an urgent for a separate e-commerce export policy, which can ease the compliance burden on exporters.95.) Which of the following statements are correct based on export related details given in the passage?A. India's services export declined in 2023-24 over 2022-23B. India's export through online platform is less than China in 2022-23C. Amazon targets to double or more than double its exports from India in 2024-25D. More than 20% of goods in e-commerce are reimportedE. India's merchandize exports increased in 2023-24 over 2022-23Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B & C Only
  • B.B, C & D only
  • C.C, D & E Only
  • D.A, B & E Only
Correct Answer: B, C & D only

Let us analyze each statement one by one, based on passage given:

A. India's services export declined in 2023-24 over 2022-23 – False, the passage clearly mentions that India's services export increased by only 515.8 billion in 2023-24 over 2022-23.

B. India's export through online platform is less than China in 2022-23 – True, the passage mentions that India's exports through online platforms stood at $8-10 billion in 2022-23 compared to China's staggering figure of more than $300 billion.

C. Amazon targets to double or more than double its exports from India in 2024-25 – True, the passage mentions that Amazon surpassed $8 billion in cumulative exports from India in 2023 and aims to achieve its ambitious target of $20 billion by next year.

D. More than 20% of goods in e-commerce are reimported – True, the passage mentions that about 25 per cent of goods in e-commerce are reimported.

E. India's merchandize exports increased in 2023-24 over 2022-23 – False, the passage clearly mentions that India's services export increased by only 515.8 billion in 2023-24 over 2022-23, while merchandise export declined $14 billion in the same period.

 

Thus, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 97
Read the passage and answer the questions given below.National power demand in India has hit 250Gw, 25 per cent more than last year and 71 per cent more than in 2022. The power ministry has rightly taken pride in ensuring that thermal power stations have adequate stocks of coal to keep the lights, fans and air-conditioning on. This has been a chronic problem in previous summers, leading to prolonged outages. This year, coal stocks have reached plants well on time. As on June 23, 2024 thermal power plants had 16 days of stocks as against 9.4 days on June 23, 2022 and 12.7 days on the same day in 2023.The Government expects to add 15.4Gwof coal-fired capacity in 2024-25, the highest in 9 years and 90Gwby 2032. A programme of "Coal Reforms 3.0" is on the agenda to increase the availability of coal for industrial sectors, especially steel units, with the broad objective of reducing imports to zero in the next two financial years.India has set a target to achieve 50 per cent cumulative installed capacity from non-fossil fuel- based energy resources by 2030 and has pledged to reduce the emission intensity of its gross domestic product by 45 per cent by 2030, based on 2005 levels. The installed capacity of non- fossil power in India is now 45.3 per cent of the total capacity, putting India on track to exceed its climate-change commitmentsButthis is illusory progress The absence of viable storage technologies has limited grid offtake from renewable sources.Encouraging industry to continue its dependence on coal is unhelpful. In this respect Coal Reforms 3.0 appears to be at odds with a scheme announced earlier this year for a pilot project for given hydrogen to replace coal both as a fuel and as feedstock (which is possible even in steel produced through the blast furnace route). Given that coal-based thermal plants are responsible for a disproportionately higher share of emission that the industrial sector, the government may do well to power India's economy in the immediate future.96.) The availability of coal stock with power plants this year is approximately ________ more than it was 2 years ago.
  • A.26%
  • B.52%
  • C.70%
  • D.100%
Correct Answer: 70%

The passage mentions that the coal stock as of June 23, 2024, was for 16 days, compared to 9.4 days in 2022. To calculate the increase:

 

(16-9.4)9.4 ×100 = 70.21%

Question 98
Read the passage and answer the questions given below.National power demand in India has hit 250Gw, 25 per cent more than last year and 71 per cent more than in 2022. The power ministry has rightly taken pride in ensuring that thermal power stations have adequate stocks of coal to keep the lights, fans and air-conditioning on. This has been a chronic problem in previous summers, leading to prolonged outages. This year, coal stocks have reached plants well on time. As on June 23, 2024 thermal power plants had 16 days of stocks as against 9.4 days on June 23, 2022 and 12.7 days on the same day in 2023.The Government expects to add 15.4Gwof coal-fired capacity in 2024-25, the highest in 9 years and 90Gwby 2032. A programme of "Coal Reforms 3.0" is on the agenda to increase the availability of coal for industrial sectors, especially steel units, with the broad objective of reducing imports to zero in the next two financial years.India has set a target to achieve 50 per cent cumulative installed capacity from non-fossil fuel- based energy resources by 2030 and has pledged to reduce the emission intensity of its gross domestic product by 45 per cent by 2030, based on 2005 levels. The installed capacity of non- fossil power in India is now 45.3 per cent of the total capacity, putting India on track to exceed its climate-change commitmentsButthis is illusory progress The absence of viable storage technologies has limited grid offtake from renewable sources.Encouraging industry to continue its dependence on coal is unhelpful. In this respect Coal Reforms 3.0 appears to be at odds with a scheme announced earlier this year for a pilot project for given hydrogen to replace coal both as a fuel and as feedstock (which is possible even in steel produced through the blast furnace route). Given that coal-based thermal plants are responsible for a disproportionately higher share of emission that the industrial sector, the government may do well to power India's economy in the immediate future.97.) Which of the following statement is true?
  • A.Industrial sectorpollutemore than coal based thermal power plants
  • B.The Chronic problem of coal shortage is likely to continue
  • C.Coal Reforms 3.0 is in synergy with green hydrogen pilot project
  • D.Coal Reforms 3.0 will bring down coal imports to zero in the coming two years
Correct Answer: Coal Reforms 3.0 will bring down coal imports to zero in the coming two years

The passage states that under Coal Reforms 3.0, the broad objective is to reduce coal imports to zero within the next two financial years, especially for the industrial sector, making statement D correct.

Question 99
Read the passage and answer the questions given below.National power demand in India has hit 250Gw, 25 per cent more than last year and 71 per cent more than in 2022. The power ministry has rightly taken pride in ensuring that thermal power stations have adequate stocks of coal to keep the lights, fans and air-conditioning on. This has been a chronic problem in previous summers, leading to prolonged outages. This year, coal stocks have reached plants well on time. As on June 23, 2024 thermal power plants had 16 days of stocks as against 9.4 days on June 23, 2022 and 12.7 days on the same day in 2023.The Government expects to add 15.4Gwof coal-fired capacity in 2024-25, the highest in 9 years and 90Gwby 2032. A programme of "Coal Reforms 3.0" is on the agenda to increase the availability of coal for industrial sectors, especially steel units, with the broad objective of reducing imports to zero in the next two financial years.India has set a target to achieve 50 per cent cumulative installed capacity from non-fossil fuel- based energy resources by 2030 and has pledged to reduce the emission intensity of its gross domestic product by 45 per cent by 2030, based on 2005 levels. The installed capacity of non- fossil power in India is now 45.3 per cent of the total capacity, putting India on track to exceed its climate-change commitmentsButthis is illusory progress The absence of viable storage technologies has limited grid offtake from renewable sources.Encouraging industry to continue its dependence on coal is unhelpful. In this respect Coal Reforms 3.0 appears to be at odds with a scheme announced earlier this year for a pilot project for given hydrogen to replace coal both as a fuel and as feedstock (which is possible even in steel produced through the blast furnace route). Given that coal-based thermal plants are responsible for a disproportionately higher share of emission that the industrial sector, the government may do well to power India's economy in the immediate future.98.) Out of the total installed Power capacity, the installed capacity of fossil power is:
  • A.45.3%
  • B.50%
  • C.54.7%
  • D.45%
Correct Answer: 54.7%

The passage states that 45.3% of the total installed power capacity comes from non-fossil fuel sources. Therefore, fossil fuel-based power accounts for the remaining percentage, which is:

100% − 45.3% = 54.7 %

Question 100
Read the passage and answer the questions given below.National power demand in India has hit 250Gw, 25 per cent more than last year and 71 per cent more than in 2022. The power ministry has rightly taken pride in ensuring that thermal power stations have adequate stocks of coal to keep the lights, fans and air-conditioning on. This has been a chronic problem in previous summers, leading to prolonged outages. This year, coal stocks have reached plants well on time. As on June 23, 2024 thermal power plants had 16 days of stocks as against 9.4 days on June 23, 2022 and 12.7 days on the same day in 2023.The Government expects to add 15.4Gwof coal-fired capacity in 2024-25, the highest in 9 years and 90Gwby 2032. A programme of "Coal Reforms 3.0" is on the agenda to increase the availability of coal for industrial sectors, especially steel units, with the broad objective of reducing imports to zero in the next two financial years.India has set a target to achieve 50 per cent cumulative installed capacity from non-fossil fuel- based energy resources by 2030 and has pledged to reduce the emission intensity of its gross domestic product by 45 per cent by 2030, based on 2005 levels. The installed capacity of non- fossil power in India is now 45.3 per cent of the total capacity, putting India on track to exceed its climate-change commitmentsButthis is illusory progress The absence of viable storage technologies has limited grid offtake from renewable sources.Encouraging industry to continue its dependence on coal is unhelpful. In this respect Coal Reforms 3.0 appears to be at odds with a scheme announced earlier this year for a pilot project for given hydrogen to replace coal both as a fuel and as feedstock (which is possible even in steel produced through the blast furnace route). Given that coal-based thermal plants are responsible for a disproportionately higher share of emission that the industrial sector, the government may do well to power India's economy in the immediate future.99.) Which of the following power sources have limitation of storage capacity?A. WindB. SolarC. ThermalD. NuclearE.HydralChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C & D Only
  • B.A, B & E Only
  • C.B, C & D Only
  • D.A, B, D & E Only
Correct Answer: A, B & E Only

The passage mentions the limitation of storage technologies for renewable sources.

A: Wind power is intermittent and storage is an issue.

B: Solar power also has storage limitations due to its intermittent nature.

E: Hydral (hydropower) can have storage limitations, especially for managing surplus power.

 

Option (C): Thermal and Option (D): Nuclear power are not storage-limited in the same way since they can provide consistent power.

Quiz Attempt #118979

Total Questions: 100
Question 1
_______ as defined under the Foreign Trade Policy (FTP), implemented by Director General of Foreign Trade has the main aim to 'mentor new and potential exporters on the intricacies of foreign trade through counselling, training and outreach programmes' so that they can get into international trade.
  • A.NiryatBharat Scheme
  • B.NiryatBandhuScheme
  • C.NiryatBenefit Scheme
  • D.NiryatBorder Scheme
Correct Answer: NiryatBandhuScheme

The Niryat Bandhu Scheme, implemented by the DGFT, has two primary objectives:

 

1. To "mentor new and potential exporters on the nuances of foreign trade through counselling, training, and outreach programmes, enabling them to venture into international trade.

2. To enhance exports from India.

Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

Question 2
_______ is a marketing term for any design to prompt an immediate response or encourage an immediate sale.
  • A.Call for Promotion
  • B.Call for Activity
  • C.Call to Action
  • D.Call to Aspiration
Correct Answer: Call to Action

A "Call to Action" (CTA) is a marketing term that refers to any element within a marketing message designed to prompt an immediate response or encourage an immediate sale. It typically appears as a clear and concise directive, urging the audience to take a specific action, such as "Buy Now," "Sign Up Today," or "Learn More." CTAs are strategically placed within advertisements, emails, websites, and other marketing materials to guide potential customers towards the desired action, ultimately driving conversions and engagement. By leveraging compelling CTAs, marketers aim to capture the audience's attention, generate interest, and motivate them to take the next step in the customer journey.

Question 3
The exporting firm is termed 'rider' where the other firm with an established distribution channel in the target country is termed as 'Carrier'. This phenomenon is known as:
  • A.Counter Trade
  • B.Barter
  • C.Piggy Backing
  • D.Switch Trading
Correct Answer: Piggy Backing

Piggybacking, in the context of international business and exporting, refers to a strategy where one company (the rider) leverages the established distribution network of another company (the carrier) to sell its products in foreign markets. This arrangement is a form of strategic alliance that allows both companies to achieve mutual objectives that would be challenging to reach independently.

Question 4
In International Commercial Terms (INCOTERMES), identify the one under which the delivery of goods to the named place of destination (discharge) takes place at the seller's expense. Buyers assumes the cargo insurance; import custom clearance.paymentof custom duties, taxes and other costs and risk.
  • A.Carriage and Insurance Paid To (CIP)
  • B.Cost, Insurance and Freight (CIF)
  • C.Carriage Paid To (CPT)
  • D.Cost and Freight (CFR)
Correct Answer: Carriage Paid To (CPT)

Under the CPT term, the seller is responsible for arranging and paying for the transportation of the goods to the named place of destination. However, the risk is transferred to the buyer once the goods are handed over to the first carrier. The buyer is responsible for the cargo insurance, import customs clearance, payment of customs duties, taxes, and any other costs and risks from that point onward.

 

Other INCOTERMS are explained as follows:

 

1. Carriage and Insurance Paid To (CIP): Similar to CPT, but the seller also pays for insurance coverage up to the named destination.

 

2. Cost, Insurance and Freight (CIF)

The seller pays for the cost of goods, insurance, and freight to bring the goods to the port of destination. However, the risk transfers to the buyer once the goods are loaded onto the vessel.

 

3. Cost and Freight (CFR)

The seller pays for the cost of goods and freight to bring the goods to the port of destination, but the risk transfers to the buyer once the goods are loaded onto the vessel, and the buyer is responsible for insurance.

 

Given the requirement that the seller pays for delivery to the named place of destination, and the buyer assumes cargo insurance, import customs clearance, payment of customs duties, taxes, and other costs and risks, CPT (Carriage Paid To) is the correct term.

Question 5
In which ratio, will the remaining partners compensate the retiring partner for a share of goodwill?
  • A.Profit-sharing ratio
  • B.Sacrificing ratio
  • C.Gaining ratio
  • D.Capital ratio
Correct Answer: Gaining ratio

The retiring or deceased partner is entitled to his share of goodwill at the time of retirement/death because the goodwill has been earned by the firm with the efforts of all the existing partners. Hence, at the time of retirement/death of a partner, goodwill is valued as per agreement among the partners the retiring/ deceased partner compensated for his share of goodwill by the continuing partners (who have gained due to acquisition of share of profit from the retiring/ deceased partner) in their gaining ratio.

Question 6
Which one of the following accounting concepts and conventions consider it reasonable to use the historical cost to record long-lived assets?
  • A.The entity concept
  • B.Going concern convention
  • C.Materiality convention
  • D.The periodicity convention
Correct Answer: Going concern convention

The Going Concern Convention or accounting principle assumes that a business will continue to operate for the foreseeable future and not liquidate or be forced to halt operations. Under this assumption, it is considered reasonable to use the historical cost to record long-lived assets. Historical cost refers to the original purchase price of the asset, which is recorded and then depreciated over its useful life.

 

Other Options are explained as follows:

 

1. The Entity Concept: This principle states that a business is a separate legal entity distinct from its owners. It does not specifically address the valuation method for long-lived assets.

 

2. Materiality Convention: This principle suggests that all significant information should be disclosed in the financial statements. It focuses on the importance of the information rather than the method of asset valuation.

 

3. The Periodicity Convention: This principle relates to dividing the life of a business into regular intervals (periods) for reporting purposes. It doesn't specify how long-lived assets should be valued.

 

Therefore, the going concern convention is the accounting principle that supports the use of historical cost for recording long-lived assets, as it assumes the business will continue operating, and the assets will be used over their intended life.

Question 7
Luxmiindustries issued 1000 shares ofRs. 100 at a premium ofRs10 per share, payableRs20 on application,Rs. 35 on allotment (including premium) and the balance on the first and final call.Mr.X who held 200 shares has paid only the application money and these shares were subsequently forfeited by the company. In this regard, by which amount share forfeiture account will be credited?
  • A.Rs. 4000
  • B.Rs. 2000
  • C.Rs. 3000
  • D.Rs. 200
Correct Answer: Rs. 4000

In case shares are issued at premium and thereafter forfeited there can be two situations:

 

1. Premium on shares has been received prior to the forfeiture.

In this case, if the amount of premium on shares forfeited has been received by the company prior to the forfeiture, securities Premium A/c will not get affected. In this case the journal entry of forfeiture of shares will be similar to the entry made as if the shares had been issued at par.

 

The journal entry under Case 1 will be:

Share Capital A/c …Dr

To Share forfeited A/c

To Unpaid Calls A/c./Calls in arrears A/c

(forfeiture of share issued at premium)

 

2. Amount of premium on shares has not been received and it still stands credited to the Securities Premium A/c.

When a share is forfeited on which the amount of premium has been made due but has not been received, either wholly or partially, the Securities Premium A/c will be cancelled. At the time of making due, Securities Premium A/c will be credited.

 

The journal entry will be as follows:

 

Share Capital A/c Dr

Securities Premium A/c Dr

To Share Forfeited A/c

To Unpaid call A/c

(Being forfeiture of shares originally issued at premium due to non-payment of dues).

 

Since, in the given case, shares have been forfeited before the payment of premium, case 2 applies here.

 

The journal entry will be as follows.

 

Share Capital A/c Dr (200 × 100) DrRs. 20,000

Securities Premium A/c (200 × 10) Dr Rs. 2,000

To Share Forfeited A/c (200 × 20)Rs. 4,000

To Share Allotment A/c (200 × 35)Rs. 7,000

To Unpaid Call A/c (200 × 55)Rs. 11,000

(Being forfeiture of shares originally issued at premium due to non-payment of dues).

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option A.

Question 8
Which of the following frameworks is considered as the Open International Standard for Digital Business Reporting?
  • A.CSR reporting
  • B.TBL reporting
  • C.XBRL reporting
  • D.PPP reporting
Correct Answer: XBRL reporting

XBRL (eXtensible Business Reporting Language) reporting is the open international standard for digital business reporting. XBRL is a language for the electronic communication of business and financial data, which is used globally for a variety of reporting purposes. It allows the easy sharing and analysis of financial statements and other business information, ensuring that data can be reliably and accurately exchanged between different systems and organizations.

Question 9
Which one of the following statements is the most relevant to the substitution effect?
  • A.In the real world, substitution effect is much larger than the income effect
  • B.Most of the goods are not reasonable substitutes
  • C.In reality, the income effect represents its predominance over the substitution effect
  • D.Substitution and income effects cannot be separated easily
Correct Answer: In the real world, substitution effect is much larger than the income effect

The substitution effect refers to the tendency of consumers to replace a good with a similar alternative when its price rises, assuming that the level of satisfaction or utility remains constant. In other words, consumers opt for a cheaper substitute when the price of a good increases, leading to a decrease in the quantity demanded of the relatively more expensive good.

 

Statement (A) suggests that, in the real world, the substitution effect is much larger than the income effect. This means that when the price of a good changes, consumers are more likely to respond by substituting it with a cheaper alternative rather than adjusting their overall consumption due to changes in their income. This viewpoint implies that consumers are highly responsive to changes in relative prices and are quick to switch to substitutes when prices change, making the substitution effect more significant than the income effect in influencing consumer behaviour.

Question 10
Identify the source of oligopoly which is also applicable to monopoly firms:
  • A.Economies of scale may operate over a small range of outputs
  • B.Huge capital investments and specialized inputs are required to enter the market
  • C.Large firms may own a patent for the exclusive right to produce a commodity
  • D.New firms have chances to win customer loyalty
Correct Answer: Huge capital investments and specialized inputs are required to enter the market

Option (B) highlights the requirement of significant capital investments and specialized inputs to enter the market. This condition is applicable to both oligopoly and monopoly firms.

 

In oligopoly, a small number of large firms dominate the market, often due to significant barriers to entry, such as high capital requirements or the need for specialized technology or resources. These barriers deter new entrants from easily entering the market, allowing existing firms to maintain their market power and influence prices.

 

Similarly, in monopoly, there is only one dominant firm in the market, and entry barriers can be even higher. Monopolies often arise when a single firm controls essential resources, owns patents or copyrights, or possesses exclusive rights to produce a particular product or service. As a result, potential competitors face significant hurdles in entering the market, such as the need for substantial capital investments or access to proprietary technology.

 

In both cases, the requirement for substantial capital investments and specialized inputs acts as a barrier to entry, limiting competition and allowing existing firms to maintain their dominance in the market.

Question 11
Read the given passage and answer the questions that follow:Over $350 billion of private capital has been deployed over the last decade, which has propelled more than 5,000 enterprises. These new businesses are anchored in innovative business models combining the full potential of technology, facilitating every Indian to fulfil their aspirations.The big shift in the last decade is thereimaginationof India as an addressable market of 300 million households, a massive shift from only 20 million households in tier-I cities earlier. This has been propelled by the strong partnership between entrepreneurs and the PE/VC ecosystem. The share of FDI funnelled into PE/VC has surged to 50-60%, up from 20-30% two decades back.Besides the tremendous focus on value creation, the PE/VC industry has brought about multidimensional progress in the economy. The principles of responsible investing that this industry is committed to have enabled the building of a more equitable, inclusive economy, and one that has earned the trust of large global investors as an attractive investment destination.The PE/VC ecosystem sparked a renaissance, empowering young minds to take a bold leap. This led to a change inmindsetwhere entrepreneurship is now an accepted livelihood and, indeed, a proud way of life. Today,startupsand new businesses are celebrated, and many are giving up established careers to follow their heart, with families standing as stalwart supporters of entrepreneurship. The proportionality of risk and reward has been embraced, forging a harmonious relationship between uncertainty and achievement.Stories at home and those that went global are a testament to the power of partnerships between the capital provider and entrepreneurs, transforming a large democracy to be self-reliant, and elevating over a billion people to a new world of greater aspirations and confidence.This revolution has been largely possible because ofGol'sthrust towards attracting capital. The frameworks of alternative investment funds (AIFs), GIFT City IFSC,StartupIndia programme and budget allocations, coupled with progressive amendments such as GST and India Stack, have made India an attractive destination for investment.Given below are two statements: one is labelled as Assertion 'A' and the other is labelled as Reason 'R'.Assertion 'A':The private equity and venture capital ecosystem has sparked a renaissance, empowering young minds to take a bold leap.Reason 'R':Today,startupsand new business are celebrated and many are given up their established careers to follow their heart, with families standing as stalwart supporters.In The light of the above statements, choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both 'A' and 'R' are true and 'R' is the correct explanation of 'A'.
  • B.Both 'A' and 'R' are true but 'R' is NOT the correct explanation at 'A'.
  • C.'A' is true but 'R' is false.
  • D.'A' is false but 'R' true.
Correct Answer: Both 'A' and 'R' are true and 'R' is the correct explanation of 'A'.

Assertion 'A' states that the private equity and venture capital ecosystem has sparked a renaissance, empowering young minds to take a bold leap.

Reason 'R' describes the current trend where startups and new businesses are celebrated, and many individuals are giving up their established careers to follow their passion, with families providing strong support.

Question 12
Which one of the following statements does not support the concept of third degree price discrimination?
  • A.The firm must have monopoly power
  • B.This type of price discrimination is most likely to occur in the manufacturing industries
  • C.The firm must be able to keep the two markets separate
  • D.The price elasticity and demand for the commodity must be different in the two markets
Correct Answer: This type of price discrimination is most likely to occur in the manufacturing industries

Option (B) states that this type of price discrimination is most likely to occur in manufacturing industries. However, this statement does not directly support the concept of third-degree price discrimination. Third-degree price discrimination involves charging different prices to different groups of consumers based on their willingness to pay, which can occur in various sectors, not just manufacturing industries. Therefore, option (B) does not support the concept of third-degree price discrimination.

Question 13
Which one of the following concepts measures the amount of capital that the firm can give up by using one additional unit of labour and still remain on the same isoquant?
  • A.Diminishing Marginal Rate of Substitution
  • B.Economic Trade-off Region
  • C.Diminishing Marginal Rate of Technical Substitution
  • D.Diminishing Marginal Utility
Correct Answer: Diminishing Marginal Rate of Technical Substitution

The concept that measures the amount of capital that a firm can give up by using one additional unit of labour while still remaining on the same isoquant is the Diminishing Marginal Rate of Technical Substitution (MRTS).

Marginal Rate of Technical Substitution (MRTS) measures the rate at which a firm can substitute capital for labour (or vice versa) while keeping the output level constant. It is represented by the slope of the isoquant. As more labour is used, the firm can typically afford to give up progressively smaller amounts of capital to maintain the same output level, leading to a diminishing MRTS.

Question 14
Which of the following theories of capital structure articulates that a firm borrows up to the point where the tax benefit from extra debt is exactly equal to the cost that comes from the increased probability of financial distress?
  • A.The static theory
  • B.Net income approach
  • C.Modigliani-Miller theory
  • D.Net operating income approach
Correct Answer: The static theory

The Static Trade-off Theory provides a framework for understanding how firms determine their optimal capital structure by balancing the benefits and costs of debt financing. At the core of this theory is the notion that firms aim to maximize their value by borrowing up to a point where the marginal tax benefit from additional debt equals the marginal cost of financial distress.

 

On one hand, debt offers tax advantages through interest deductions, which reduce the firm's taxable income and, consequently, its tax liability. This tax shield provided by debt financing can enhance the firm's after-tax profitability and overall value. However, as a firm increases its debt levels, it also assumes greater financial risk. This heightened risk stems from the obligation to meet interest payments and repay principal amounts, which can strain the firm's financial flexibility, particularly during economic downturns or adverse market conditions.

 

The cost of financial distress associated with higher debt levels encompasses various factors, including potential bankruptcy costs, such as legal fees and settlement expenses, as well as intangible costs like damage to the firm's reputation and customer relationships. Moreover, excessive debt may restrict the firm's ability to invest in growth opportunities or respond effectively to changes in the business environment, further exacerbating financial vulnerabilities.

 

In aligning with the Static Trade-off Theory, firms seek to strike a balance between the tax benefits of debt and the costs of financial distress. They aim to identify the optimal level of debt that maximizes the firm's overall value by carefully evaluating the trade-offs between the tax advantages gained from leverage and the risks associated with potential financial distress.

Question 15
When a target company makes a counter bid for the stock of the bidder, the defensive strategy in reference is called?
  • A.Greenmail
  • B.Poison pill
  • C.Pacmandefense
  • D.Golden parachute
Correct Answer: Pacmandefense

The Pacman defense is a defensive strategy used by a target company in a hostile takeover situation. In this strategy, the target company makes a counter bid to acquire the stock of the bidding company. Essentially, the target company turns the tables by attempting to take over the bidder.

 

Other options are explained as follows.

(A) Greenmail: This strategy involves the target company buying back its own shares at a premium from the hostile bidder to prevent the takeover. The bidder agrees to drop the takeover attempt in exchange for the payment.

(B) Poison pill: This is a strategy where the target company makes its stock less attractive to the bidder by allowing existing shareholders to purchase additional shares at a discount, diluting the value and making the takeover more expensive for the bidder.

(D) Golden parachute: This refers to substantial benefits or compensation provided to top executives if the company is taken over and they lose their positions as a result. It is a deterrent to hostile takeovers but does not involve a counter bid.

Therefore, the correct term for the defensive strategy where a target company makes a counter bid for the stock of the bidder is Pacman defense.

Question 16
The earning per share for Avanti corporation isRs. 4.0. The rate of return on investments is 16 per cent and the return required by its shareholders is 12 percent. What will be the price per share as per the Walter model, if thepayoutratio is 40 per cent?
  • A.Rs24
  • B.Rs36
  • C.Rs40
  • D.Rs72
Correct Answer: Rs40

The correct answer is option (C) based on following calculation:

Question 17
Which one of the following instruments is often used to protect the value of a foreign currency denominated transaction?
  • A.Forward contract
  • B.Forward swap
  • C.Forward hedge
  • D.Forward premium
Correct Answer: Forward hedge

The use of a forward exchange contract to hedge or protect the value of a foreign currency denominated transaction is called Forward Hedge.

 

A forward exchange contract is an agreement to exchange a specific amount of one currency for another at a predetermined rate on a future date. When this contract is utilized to safeguard the value of a foreign currency denominated transaction, it's termed a forward hedge.

 

Essentially, it acts as a form of insurance against potential losses stemming from fluctuating exchange rates. For instance, if a company anticipates paying for imported goods in a foreign currency at a later date, they may enter into a forward hedge to lock in a favorable exchange rate, shielding themselves from adverse rate movements. By doing so, they mitigate the risk of currency fluctuations impacting the cost of their transaction. This strategy is particularly valuable for businesses engaged in international trade, as it enables them to manage currency risk and budget effectively for future transactions. In summary, a forward hedge provides a proactive approach to managing exchange rate risk, offering stability and predictability in foreign currency transactions.

Question 18
A discrete probability distribution
  • A.is a listing of all possible values of the random variable
  • B.assigns a probability to each possible value of the random variable
  • C.can assume the value between -1 and +1
  • D.is independent of the parameters of the distribution
Correct Answer: assigns a probability to each possible value of the random variable

A discrete probability distribution (B) assigns a probability to each possible value of the random variable.

This statement accurately describes a key characteristic of discrete probability distributions. They provide probabilities for each possible outcome of a random variable, often represented in the form of a probability mass function (PMF). Each value of the random variable has an associated probability assigned to it, allowing for the calculation of probabilities for specific events or outcomes.

Question 19
The price earnings ratio for firms in a certain industry follows the normal distribution. A firm's price-earnings ratio has a standardized value (Z) = 1.0 and it is included in the highest _______ of firms in the industry.
  • A.99.73%
  • B.68.27%
  • C.15.87%
  • D.34.13%
Correct Answer: 15.87%

The firm's price-earnings ratio standardized value (Z) = 1.0 indicates that it lies one standard deviation above the mean in the normal distribution.

 

Since the normal distribution is symmetric, approximately 34.13% of the data lies between the mean and one standard deviation above the mean on one side, and the same percentage lies between the mean and one standard deviation below the mean on the other side.

 

Therefore, the firm's price-earnings ratio standardized value of 1.0 places it in the highest (0.50- 0.34 = 0.16) of firms in the industry.

Question 20
In one-factor ANOVA, the computed F-value will be negative:
  • A.whenthere is no difference in the treatment of means.
  • B.whenthere is no difference within treatments.
  • C.when SST (total variance) is larger than SSE (error variance)
  • D.under no circumstances
Correct Answer: under no circumstances

The computed F-value in one-factor ANOVA will never be negative. The F-value is always a non-negative value because it is computed as the ratio of two variances: the variance between treatment means (which is always non-negative) and the variance within treatments (also always non-negative). Therefore, the F-value will be zero or positive, but never negative, regardless of the circumstances.

Question 21
In a certain population, 22% of people are smokers, 57% of people are males and 12% are males who smoke. If a person is chosen at random from the population, what is that probability that selected person is either a male or a smoker?
  • A.0.79
  • B.0.22
  • C.0.45
  • D.0.67
Correct Answer: 0.67

The correct answer is option (D) based on following calculation.

Question 22
Effective mentoring requires trust and the level of trust reflects the mentor's:
  • A.Competence, consistency, communication abilities and control sharing readiness
  • B.Concerned, cooperativeness, communication abilities and coordination skills
  • C.Competence, consistency, complexity and communication abilities
  • D.Communication abilities, competence, concerned behaviour, control sharing readiness
Correct Answer: Competence, consistency, communication abilities and control sharing readiness

Effective mentoring requires a strong foundation of trust between the mentor and the mentee. The level of trust reflects the mentor's qualities and behaviours that contribute to building and maintaining trust. These include:

 

1. Competence: The mentor's knowledge, skills, and expertise in their field are essential for gaining the trust of the mentee. Demonstrating competence helps the mentee feel confident in the mentor's guidance and advice.

2. Consistency: Consistency in actions, words, and behavior builds predictability and reliability, which are crucial for trust. Mentors who are consistent in their support and guidance establish a sense of dependability that fosters trust.

3. Communication abilities: Effective communication is a key to establishing rapport, understanding, and mutual respect between the mentor and mentee. Clear, open, and honest communication helps to build trust and strengthen the mentoring relationship.

4. Control sharing readiness: Mentors who are willing to share control and empower the mentee in decision-making processes demonstrate trust in the mentee's abilities. This willingness to share control encourages autonomy and fosters trust in the mentor-mentee relationship.

 

Option (A) captures these essential qualities and behaviours of a mentor that contribute to building trust, making it the most appropriate choice.

Question 23
Which one of the following consists of physical working conditions, work schedule, incentives and the number of people with whom the employee would normally interact?
  • A.Job profile
  • B.Job content
  • C.Job context
  • D.Job specification
Correct Answer: Job context

Job context refers to the broader environment and circumstances in which a job is performed. It includes factors such as physical working conditions, work schedule, incentives, and the number of people with whom the employee would normally interact. These elements provide a framework within which the job tasks and responsibilities are carried out.

 

Other Options are explained as follows.

(A) Job profile: This typically refers to a summary of a job's duties, responsibilities, qualifications, and requirements. It may include information about the tasks and skills involved in the job but does not encompass the broader working conditions or context.

(B) Job content: This refers to the specific tasks, duties, and responsibilities that make up the job. It focuses on the work itself rather than the broader environmental factors or context in which the work is performed.

(D) Job specification: This typically outlines the qualifications, skills, knowledge, and experience required for a particular job. It describes the characteristics of the ideal candidate for the job but does not cover the working conditions or context.

Question 24
Which one of the following beliefs and behaviours does not characterise 'collectivism'?
  • A.Relations are moral not contractual
  • B.Relations take precedence over tasks
  • C.Individual opinions are independent of collective opinions
  • D.Maintaining harmony is highly valued
Correct Answer: Individual opinions are independent of collective opinions

Collectivism is a cultural orientation where the emphasis is on the group rather than the individual. In collectivist societies, individuals prioritize the needs and goals of the group over their own interests.

 

Here's how each option aligns with collectivism:

 

(A) Relations are moral not contractual: Collectivist cultures often prioritize relationships and emphasize moral obligations to others rather than formal contracts or agreements.

 

(B) Relations take precedence over tasks: In collectivist cultures, interpersonal relationships are valued highly, and maintaining harmony within the group often takes precedence over individual tasks or goals.

 

(C) Individual opinions are independent of collective opinions: This statement contradicts the concept of collectivism. In collectivist cultures, individual opinions are often influenced by, and integrated with, collective opinions. The emphasis is on consensus and group harmony rather than independent individual viewpoints.

 

(D) Maintaining harmony is highly valued: Collectivist cultures typically place a high value on maintaining harmony within the group, even if it means suppressing individual preferences or opinions that may disrupt group cohesion.

Therefore, the belief and behaviour that do not characterize collectivism is option (C) i.e., Individual opinions are independent of collective opinions.

Question 25
HoneywellInc'smove from a hierarchical management structure to a much flatter and team-based structure is a good description of which one of the following?
  • A.Centralisation
  • B.Decentralisation
  • C.Span of control
  • D.Work specialization
Correct Answer: Decentralisation

The description provided in the question, "Honeywell Inc's move from a hierarchical management structure to a much flatter and team-based structure," is a good example of option (B) i.e., Decentralization.

 

Each of the given option is explained below.

Centralization: Centralization refers to the concentration of decision-making authority at the top of the organizational hierarchy. In a centralized structure, decisions are made by a few individuals at the top, and there is limited delegation of authority.

Decentralization: Decentralization, on the other hand, involves distributing decision-making authority throughout the organization. It often involves flattening the organizational structure and empowering employees at lower levels to make decisions. In a team-based structure, decision-making authority is typically decentralized, allowing teams to make decisions collaboratively.

Span of Control: Span of control refers to the number of subordinates that a manager can effectively supervise. While a move to a flatter structure might impact span of control, the description provided focuses more on the overall organizational structure rather than the number of subordinates under each manager.

Work Specialization: Work specialization refers to the degree to which tasks in an organization are divided into separate jobs. A move to a flatter and team-based structure might involve reevaluating work specialization, but it's not the primary focus of the description provided.

 

Therefore, the move described, from a hierarchical management structure to a much flatter and team-based structure, is a good example of decentralization.

Question 26
Companies use _______ when they lack financial resources to carry out direct marketing and when they can earn more by doing so.
  • A.Intermediaries
  • B.Internationalisation
  • C.Influencers
  • D.Innovation
Correct Answer: Intermediaries

Let us consider each of the given option one by one.

Intermediaries: Companies may use intermediaries such as wholesalers, retailers, or agents when they lack the financial resources or capabilities to carry out direct marketing themselves. Intermediaries can help reach a wider customer base and distribute products more efficiently, especially when companies are unable to invest in their own direct marketing channels.

Internationalization: Internationalization refers to the process of expanding business operations into international markets. While internationalization can involve various strategies, it is not directly related to the situation described in the question.

Influencers: Influencers are individuals or entities with the ability to affect the purchasing decisions of others due to their authority, knowledge, position, or relationship with their audience. While influencers can be part of a marketing strategy, they are not directly related to the lack of financial resources for direct marketing.

Innovation: Innovation involves the development and implementation of new ideas, products, or processes to improve business performance. While innovation can certainly play a role in marketing strategies, it is not specifically related to the situation described in the question regarding financial constraints and direct marketing.

 

Therefore, the most appropriate term in this context is intermediaries, as companies may use intermediaries when they lack financial resources to carry out direct marketing and when they can earn more by doing so.

Question 27
Which one of the following committees has suggested the establishment of NBFCs' regulatory framework?
  • A.Raj Study Group (1975)
  • B.ChakkravartyCommittee (1985)
  • C.VaghulCommittee (1987)
  • D.Shah Committee (1992)
Correct Answer: Shah Committee (1992)

It was Dr. A. C. Shah Committee (1992) which made wide ranging recommendations covering, inter alia entry point norms, compulsory registration of large sized NBFCs, prescription of prudential norms for NBFCs on the lines of banks, stipulation of credit rating for acceptance of public deposits and more statutory powers to Reserve Bank for better regulation of NBFCs.

Question 28
The sequential stages of moral development in business organisations are characterised by:
  • A.Conceptualised disposition, consistency and harmony, principled oriented
  • B.Consistency and harmony, conceptualised disposition, principled oriented
  • C.Principled oriented, conventional andpreconventional
  • D.Preconventional, conventional, principled oriented
Correct Answer: Preconventional, conventional, principled oriented

Lawrence Kohlberg's stages of moral development offer a sequential progression through different levels of ethical understanding. At the initial stage, known as the preconventional level, morality is perceived as externally controlled, with individuals adhering to rules to avoid punishment or gain rewards. This level comprises two stages: the punishment/obedience orientation, where behavior is influenced by fear of consequences, and the instrumental purpose orientation, where behavior is driven by personal gain.

Moving to the conventional level, individuals prioritize conformity to social rules, seeking approval from others and striving to maintain social order. This level includes the good boy/nice girl orientation, where behavior is guided by the desire for social approval, and the law and order orientation, where individuals adhere to societal laws to uphold social harmony.

Finally, at the postconventional or principled level, moral reasoning transcends societal norms, focusing instead on abstract principles and universal values. Here, individuals consider individual rights and ethical principles that apply universally, even if they conflict with societal rules. This level encompasses the social contract orientation, where individual rights take precedence, and the universal ethical principle orientation, where decisions are guided by self-chosen ethical principles rooted in conscience and applicable to all situations.

Question 29
Which one of the following are disposed to promote financial inclusion?
  • A.Poor quality of services rendered
  • B.High transaction costs
  • C.Universal access to financial services
  • D.Lack of trust in the system
Correct Answer: Universal access to financial services

Financial inclusion refers to the availability and accessibility of financial services to all individuals and businesses, regardless of their income level or social status. Universal access to financial services is a key component of financial inclusion because it ensures that everyone has the opportunity to use banking and financial services to manage their finances, save money, access credit, and participate in the formal economy.

Question 30
Which one of the following digital payment systems is developed and managed by the National Payments Corporation of India?
  • A.Paytm
  • B.BharatPe
  • C.Mastercard
  • D.RuPay
Correct Answer: RuPay

RuPay is an Indian multinational financial services and payment service system, conceived and launched by the National Payments Corporation of India (NPCI).

Question 31
Which amongst the following methods is not a method of generating sales leads in personal selling?
  • A.Referrals
  • B.Networking
  • C.Coupons
  • D.Cold calls
Correct Answer: Coupons

The method of generating sales leads in personal selling that is not typically considered a method is option (C), i.e., Coupons.

 

Let's review each option:

(A) Referrals: Referrals involve asking existing customers or contacts to recommend potential customers or clients. This method relies on leveraging existing relationships to expand the customer base.

(B) Networking: Networking involves building and maintaining relationships with individuals and organizations to exchange information, contacts, and potential business opportunities. It is a common method for generating sales leads in personal selling.

(C) Coupons: Coupons are typically associated with marketing strategies aimed at promoting products or services to existing or potential customers. While coupons can stimulate sales, they are not traditionally used as a method of generating sales leads in personal selling.

(D) Cold calls: Cold calling involves contacting potential customers or clients who have not expressed prior interest in the product or service being offered. It is a proactive approach to reaching out to new leads and generating sales opportunities.

Question 32
_______ takes into account a host of inputs, such as buyer's image of the product performance, the channel deliverables, the warranty quality, customer support and softer attributes such as thesuppliersreputation, trust worthiness and esteem.
  • A.Target rate-of-return pricing
  • B.Auction-type pricing
  • C.Economic-value-to-customer pricing
  • D.Competitive pricing
Correct Answer: Economic-value-to-customer pricing

The option that takes into account a host of inputs, such as buyer's image of the product performance, channel deliverables, warranty quality, customer support, and softer attributes such as the supplier's reputation, trustworthiness, and esteem, is option (C), i.e., Economic-value-to-customer pricing.

 

Let us explain the options one by one.

Target rate-of-return pricing: This pricing strategy involves setting prices to achieve a target rate of return on investment or profit margin. It typically focuses on the company's internal financial objectives rather than customer perceptions or value.

Auction-type pricing: This involves setting prices through an auction process, where buyers bid for products or services, and prices are determined based on the highest bid. It is not specifically tailored to consider the various attributes mentioned in the question.

Economic-value-to-customer pricing: Economic-value-to-customer (EVC) pricing is a pricing strategy that seeks to set prices based on the value that a product or service delivers to the customer. It takes into account a range of factors, including product performance, channel deliverables, warranty quality, customer support, and softer attributes such as reputation and trustworthiness. EVC pricing aims to capture the value that customers perceive in a product or service and align pricing accordingly.

Competitive pricing: This strategy involves setting prices based on competitors' prices or market norms. While competitive pricing may consider some customer perceptions, it may not comprehensively account for all the inputs mentioned in the question.

Therefore, the option that aligns with the description provided is (C), i.e., Economic-value-to-customer pricing.

Question 33
The present value of future profits, the individual or segment will generate over a lifetime relationship with a brand or firm, is known as
  • A.Lifelong Value
  • B.Lifetime Value
  • C.LonglifeValue
  • D.Longtermvalue
Correct Answer: Lifetime Value

Lifetime value refers to the present value of the future profits that an individual or segment will generate over their lifetime relationship with a brand or firm. It is a key metric used in marketing and customer relationship management to assess the long-term value of acquiring and retaining customers.

Question 34
A charitable trust (registered under section 12AB of the Income Tax Act) is registered under GST in New Delhi. It provided yoga training to middle-aged people, coaching for Basket-ball to teenagers and skill development services to persons over the age of 65 years residing in New Delhi in the month of July. This trust is liable to pay GST on:
  • A.Yoga training
  • B.Skill-development services
  • C.Coaching for basket-ball
  • D.Coaching for basket-ball and Yoga training
Correct Answer: Skill-development services

Section 12AB of the Income Tax Act, 1961, introduces stringent measures for the registration and operation of charitable trusts and institutions to ensure that only genuine organizations receive tax benefits. Compliance with multiple conditions is required for registration and maintenance under this section.

 

Section 12AA regulates the initial registration of charitable organizations, while section 12AB regulates the re-registration and operation of existing organizations. Existing charitable organizations that were registered under the earlier provisions of the Income Tax Act must apply for re-registration under section 12AB to retain their tax exemption status.

 

Note that not all services provided by such entities are exempt from GST.

 

Exemption for Charitable Activities

The specific charitable activities which are exempt include:

(i) Public health activities such as care or counseling of terminally ill persons, persons with severe physical or mental disability, persons afflicted with HIV or AIDS, and persons addicted to narcotic drugs or alcohol. Public awareness programs about preventive health, family planning, or HIV infection prevention are also included.

(ii) Advancement of religion, spirituality, or yoga.

(iii) Educational programs or skill development for abandoned, orphaned, or homeless children; physically or mentally abused and traumatized persons; prisoners; and persons over the age of 65 years residing in a rural area.

(iv) Preservation of the environment including watershed, forests, and wildlife​​.

 

Specific Exemptions for Religious Activities

Exemptions are provided for:

(i) Conduct of any religious ceremony.

(ii) Renting of precincts of a religious place meant for the general public by an entity registered under Section 12AA, with specific conditions where the exemption does not apply:

Renting of rooms for Rs. 1000 or more per day.

Renting of premises like community halls for Rs. 10,000 or more per day.

Renting of shops or spaces for business or commerce for Rs. 10,000 or more per month​​.

 

Training or Coaching in Recreational Activities

Exemptions are provided for:

Training or coaching in recreational activities relating to arts or culture or sports by charitable entities registered under Section 12AA​​.

 

Management of Educational Institutions

Exemptions are provided for:

Running schools, colleges, or educational institutions specifically for abandoned orphans, homeless children, physically or mentally abused persons, prisoners, or persons over 65 years in rural areas​​.

 

Services to Educational Institutions

Exempted services include:

Transportation of students, faculty, and staff.

Catering services including mid-day meals sponsored by the Government.

Security, cleaning, or housekeeping services.

Services related to admission or conduct of examinations​​.

 

Public Libraries

No GST is applicable for:

Running public libraries and lending books or knowledge-enhancing content​​.

 

Healthcare Services

Exempt as under:

Healthcare services at clinical establishments, by authorized medical professionals, or paramedics. This includes services for diagnosis, treatment, or care of illness, injury, deformity, abnormality, or pregnancy, and transportation of patients to and from clinical establishments​​.

 

Import of Services

Integrated Tax (Rate) exempts:

Services received by charitable trusts registered under Section 12AA from providers in non-taxable territories for charitable purposes from GST under the reverse charge mechanism​​.

 

Now, based on above discussion and the information given in the question, the skill development services provided to persons over 65 years old residing in New Delhi are subject to GST because the exemption only applies to those in rural areas. Therefore, the answer is option (B).

Question 35
Which one of the following is invalid for the relationship among the agent, the sub-agent and the principal?
  • A.Sub-agent works under the control and on the directions of the agent
  • B.Sub-agent is responsible to the agent only
  • C.Privityof contract exists between the principal and the sub-agent
  • D.Agent is responsible to the principal for the acts of the sub-agent
Correct Answer: Privityof contract exists between the principal and the sub-agent

Based on the Indian Contract Act, 1872, the relationship among the agent, sub-agent, and principal is defined with specific roles and responsibilities.

 

Let us examine each of the given statement one by one.

(A) Sub-agent works under the control and on the directions of the agent: This statement is true. According to Section 191 of the Indian Contract Act, a sub-agent is defined as a person employed by and acting under the control of the original agent in the business of the agency​​.

(B) Sub-agent is responsible to the agent only: This statement is true. The sub-agent is responsible to the original agent and not directly to the principal. This means the sub-agent's primary accountability lies with the agent who appointed them​​.

(C) Privity of contract exists between the principal and the sub-agent: This statement is false. There is no direct privity of contract between the principal and the sub-agent. The principal cannot directly hold the sub-agent responsible; instead, the agent who appointed the sub-agent is held responsible for his actions​​.

(D) Agent is responsible to the principal for the acts of the sub-agent: This statement is true. The agent remains responsible to the principal for the acts of the sub-agent, as per Section 192 of the Indian Contract Act, unless the principal has expressly agreed to accept responsibility for the sub-agent​​.

Question 36
In case of anti-competitive activities by a firm, the Competition Commission of India can impose a penalty which shall be not more than
  • A.Five percent of the average turnover/income of the firm of the three preceding financial years.
  • B.Ten percent of the average turnover/income of firm of the three preceding financial years
  • C.Fifteen percent of the average turnover/income of firm of the three preceding financial years
  • D.Five percent of the average turnover/income of firm of the five preceding financial years
Correct Answer: Ten percent of the average turnover/income of firm of the three preceding financial years

The provision in the Competition Act, 2002, allows the CCI to impose penalties for anti-competitive activities.

 

According to Section 27(b) of the Competition Act, 2002, if the Competition Commission of India finds that any agreement or action of an enterprise in a dominant position is in contravention of Section 3 or Section 4, it can impose a penalty. This penalty can be "not more than ten percent of the average of the turnover for the last three preceding financial years" upon each of the parties involved in such agreements or abuses​ This penalty aims to deter firms from engaging in practices that harm market competition and consumer welfare.

Therefore, the correct answer is option (B).

Question 37
Which one of the following is an exception to the doctrine of ConstructiveNotice.
  • A.Doctrine of Subrogation
  • B.Doctrine of Ultra Vires
  • C.Corporate Veil
  • D.TurquandRule
Correct Answer: TurquandRule

The doctrine of constructive notice implies that any person dealing with a company is presumed to have knowledge of the contents of its public documents, such as the memorandum of association and articles of association. This doctrine protects the company from being bound by contracts or actions that are beyond its corporate powers as stated in these documents.

 

However, the Turquand Rule (also known as the "indoor management rule") serves as an exception to the doctrine of constructive notice. It provides that individuals dealing with the company can assume that internal company procedures have been properly followed. This rule was established in the case of Royal British Bank v. Turquand (1856), where the court held that outsiders are not expected to know the internal workings of the company and can assume that everything is being done in accordance with the company's internal regulations.

 

The other doctrines mentioned are also discussed below.

Doctrine of Subrogation: This relates to the substitution of one person for another, with the substituted person assuming the legal rights and claims of the original party.

Doctrine of Ultra Vires: This doctrine holds that any act outside the scope of the powers of the company as defined in its memorandum of association is ultra vires and void.

Corporate Veil: This refers to the legal concept that separates the personality of a corporation from its shareholders and protects them from being personally liable for the company’s debts and obligations.

Thus, the correct answer is option (D), i.e., Turquand Rule, as it is the recognized exception to the doctrine of constructive notice.

Question 38
As per the sub-section (8A) of Section 139 of the Income Tax Act, a person may furnish an updated return of his income for the previous year relevant to such assessment year, within _______ from the end of assessment year?
  • A.6 months
  • B.12 months
  • C.24 months
  • D.36 months
Correct Answer: 24 months

An updated return can be furnished u/s 139(8A) of the Income Tax Act 1961 by any person, whether or not he has furnished a return under sub-section (1) or sub-section (4) or sub-section (5), for an assessment year, of his income or the income of any other person in respect of which he is assessable under this Act, for the previous year relevant to such assessment year, in the prescribed form at any time within 24 months from the end of the relevant assessment year.

Thus, the correct answer is option C.

Question 39
Mr.X is holding equity shares of ABC Ltd with voting power of 26 per cent.Mrs.X is working in ABC Ltd at a salary ofRs. 20,000 p.m. The other income ofMr.X andMrs.X areRs. 6,00,000andRs. 3,00,000, respectively. The gross total income ofMr.X andMrs.X are _______ respectively for the Assessment Year 2023-24.
  • A.Rs. 6,00,000 andRs. 5,40,000
  • B.Rs. 7,90,000 andRs. 3,00,000
  • C.Rs. 6,00,000 andRs. 4,90,000
  • D.Rs. 8,40,000 andRs. 3,00,000
Correct Answer: Rs. 7,90,000 andRs. 3,00,000

The question is related to clubbing provisions (in respect of remuneration of spouse) under Income Tax Act.

 

It is the case where the taxpayer is an individual and he/she has a substantial interest in a concern. In addition, spouse of the taxpayer (i.e. husband /wife) is employed in such concern without any technical or professional knowledge or experience. An individual has a ‘substantial interest’ in any of the following two situations:

 

In the case of a company – If an individual beneficially holds (individually or along with his relatives), 20% or more of equity shares, in the company, at any time during the previous year.

In the case of a concern (other than company) – If an individual is entitled to 20% or more share in profit in the concern (individually or along with his relatives), at any time, during the previous year.

 

‘Relative’ in relation to an ‘individual’ means the husband, wife, brother or sister or any lineal ascendant/ descendant of that individual. If such conditions are satisfied, then salary income of the spouse will be taxable in the hands of the taxpayer.

 

For example, X has substantial interest in A Ltd. and Mrs. X is employed by A Ltd., without any technical or professional qualification, to justify the remuneration. In this case, salary income of Mrs. X shall be taxable in the hands of X. In other words, if spouse of the taxpayer receives the salary due to his/her application of technical or professional knowledge & experience, then, such salary will be taxed in the hands of the person receiving it and not clubbed.
