When both husband and wife have a substantial interest in a concern and both are in receipt of the remuneration from such concern, then, the remuneration will be included in the total income of husband or wife whose total income, excluding such remuneration, is greater.

 

The case in question is solved as follows.

 

Income from other sources for Mr. X = Rs. 6,00,000 and for Mrs. X = Rs. 3,00,000

 

Clubbing of Income will be done in the income of Mr. X

 

Mr. X’s Income = Rs. 6,00,000

Salary of Mrs. X (to be clubbed with Mr. X’s income) = 20,000 × 12 = Rs. 2,40,000

Less: Standard Deduction (from salary income of Mrs. X) = Rs. 50,000

 

Total income of Mrs. X to be clubbed with Mr. X’s income = Rs. 6,00,000 + Rs. 1,90,000 = Rs. 7,90,000

 

Other income of Rs. 3,00,000 for Mrs. X will remain taxable in the hands of Mrs. X only.

 

Thus, Mr. X taxable income = Rs. 7,90,000 and Mrs. X taxable income = Rs. 3,00,000.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

Question 40
Every seller who receives an amount exceeding _______ as consideration for sale of a motor vehicle, shall collect tax @ 1% of the sale consideration from the buyer at the time of receipt of such an amount.
  • A.Rs. 25 lakhs
  • B.Rs. 15 lakhs
  • C.Rs. 10 lakhs
  • D.Rs. 50 lakhs
Correct Answer: Rs. 10 lakhs

According to Section 206C(1F) of the Income Tax Act 1961, every person, being a seller, who receives any amount as consideration for sale of a motor vehicle of the value exceeding Rs. 10 Lakh, shall, at the time of receipt of such amount, collect from the buyer, a sum equal to 1 % of the sale consideration as income-tax."

Question 41
Which one of the following is the allowable deduction as per the Income Tax Act, 1961 in respect of entertainment allowance paid to a government employee?
  • A.Lower of one-fourth of basic salary orRs. 5000 or entertainment allowance received.
  • B.Lower of one-fifth of basic salary orRs. 5000 or entertainment allowance received.
  • C.Lower of one-fifth of salary orRs. 5000 or entertainment allowance received.
  • D.Lower of one-fourth of salary orRs. 5000 or entertainment allowance received.
Correct Answer: Lower of one-fifth of basic salary orRs. 5000 or entertainment allowance received.

Entertainment allowance received from employer is first included in gross salary and, thereafter, with effect from A.Y.2002-03, a deduction is allowed to government employees (State or Central Government) to the extent of least of following 3 amounts:

Rs.5000

20% of basic salary.

Amount of Entertainment Allowance actually received during the year.

Note that if an employee opts to be taxed under section 115BAC (under new tax regime), the above deduction of entertainment allowance shall not be allowed.

Thus, the correct answer is option B.

Question 42
For Foreign Direct Investment, it is argued that a location in question attracts FDI because it combines the unique advantage of which of the following conditions?A. Internalisation AdvantageB. First Mover AdvantageC. Knowledge AdvantageD. Ownership AdvantageE. Location AdvantageChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.E, A and C Only
  • B.E, A and D Only
  • C.C, B and D Only
  • D.C, E and D Only
Correct Answer: E, A and D Only

For Foreign Direct Investment (FDI), the location in question attracts investment because it combines the unique advantages of ownership, location, and internalization. The Ownership, Location, Internationalization (OLI) model, proposed by John H. Dunning in 1979, serves as a framework for evaluating FDI decisions.

Ownership Advantage: This encompasses proprietary information, ownership rights, and intangible assets like branding, copyrights, trademarks, or patents. Ownership advantages confer a competitive edge to the company, such as a strong reputation for reliability.

Location Advantage: This refers to the benefits derived from the strategic positioning of business activities in specific geographic locations. It includes factors like access to resources, infrastructure, labor, market demand, and favorable government policies. Location advantages are often fixed and immobile, requiring a partnership with a foreign investor to fully utilize them.

Internalization Advantage: This signals when it's more beneficial for a company to produce a product in-house rather than outsourcing it. Internalization advantages enable companies to retain control over their operations, resources, and profits, thereby enhancing efficiency and cost-effectiveness.

Question 43
Channel power is the ability to alter channel members' behaviour so that they take actions they would not have taken otherwise. From the following channel powers, list the ones which are subjective in nature.a. Legal Powerb. Coercive Powerc. Expert Powerd. Referent Powere. Reward PowerChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.d, a and c only
  • B.d, a and b only
  • C.a, b and e only
  • D.a, c and e only
Correct Answer: d, a and c only

Among the types of channel powers listed, the ones that are subjective in nature are:

Reward Power: It is defined as the dealer’s perception that the supplier has the ability to mediate rewards to the target. The supplier has the ability to control valued resources whether such resources are tangible or intangible.

Coercive Power: Punishment or coercive is defined as the dealer’s perception that the supplier has the ability to take disciplinary action over the dealer and has the ability to mediate punishment to the target. The supplier has the ability to force compliance from the dealer such as withdrawal of important support or service.

Legitimate power: It is defined as the dealer’s perception that the supplier has a legitimate right to prescribe behaviour for him/her. Legitimate power is created from perceived standing and natural privileged to such power. The suppliers may believe that their dealers have the right to authority within the supply. Legitimacy involves mandating behaviour in an informal contractual agreement. The supplier is assumed to legitimately influence certain marketing policy on small dealers such as pricing policy or product returns policy.

Referent Power: It is defined as the dealer’s identification with the supplier, or the dealer’s desire to be closely associated with the supplier. Both parties’ desire to be associated with another is out of admiration from them. They may respect the business practices or position of a chain member and feel they are required to respond to the firm out of allegiance.

Expert Power: It is referred to the dealer’s perception that the supplier has some special knowledge or expertise, information and skills that are valuable to the target, which will lead them to take proper action. The supplier is perceived to have expert power if the supplier holds good knowledge about its products or services or provides valuable information such as providing salesmen’s training, business advice, inventory management assistance, product demonstration, and store layout advice.

Question 44
SAFTA (South Asian Free Trade Agreement) categorises member nations as Non-Least Developed Contracting States (NLDCS) and Least Developed Contracting States (LDCS). Identify the NLDSC states from the following.a. Bangladeshb. Pakistanc. Bhutand. Indiae. Sri LankaChoose the correct answer from the options given below.
  • A.a, b and d only
  • B.a, c and e only
  • C.e, a and b only
  • D.e, d and b only
Correct Answer: e, d and b only

The South Asian Free Trade Area (SAFTA) is the free trade arrangement of the South Asian Association for Regional Cooperation (SAARC). The agreement came into force in 2006, succeeding the 1993 SAARC Preferential Trading Arrangement. SAFTA signatory countries are Afghanistan, Bangladesh, Bhutan, India, Maldives, Nepal, Pakistan and Sri Lanka.

SAFTA categorized Bangladesh, Bhutan, Maldives, and Nepal as Least Developed Contracting States (LDCs), and India, Pakistan, and Sri Lanka as Non-Least Developed Contracting States (NLDCs). Based on these categorizations, SAFTA began its phased tariff liberalization program (TPL), wherein all LDCs were expected to bring down their tariffs to 30 percent, and all NLDCs to 20 percent. Both the NDLCs and the LDCs were expected to lower the tariffs to zero to five percent within the next eight and five years, respectively; this was six years for Sri Lanka.

Question 45
Which of the following ratios are critically significant for an investor?a. Debt-Equity ratiob. Price-Earningratioc. Dividend yieldd. Asset turnover ratioe. Debtor turnover ratioChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.d and e only
  • C.b, c and d only
  • D.a, d and e only
Correct Answer: a, b and c only

For an investor, certain financial ratios are particularly important because they provide insights into different aspects of a company's financial health and performance.

 

Let's analyze each ratio to determine its significance for an investor:

a. Debt-Equity Ratio: This ratio measures a company's financial leverage by comparing its total liabilities to its shareholders' equity. It's significant for investors as it indicates the level of risk associated with the company's debt levels.

b. Price-Earning Ratio (P/E Ratio): This ratio compares a company's current share price to its earnings per share (EPS). It's critical for investors as it helps in assessing whether a stock is overvalued or undervalued and provides insights into the company's future growth prospects.

c. Dividend Yield: This ratio shows how much a company pays out in dividends each year relative to its share price. It is important for investors, especially those looking for income through dividends, as it reflects the return on investment from dividends.

d. Asset Turnover Ratio: This ratio measures the efficiency of a company's use of its assets in generating sales revenue. While useful, it is more critical for operational efficiency assessment rather than direct investment decisions.

e. Debtor Turnover Ratio: This ratio measures how quickly a company collects cash from its credit sales. It is more relevant for understanding the company's credit policies and cash flow management rather than direct investment decisions.

Based on this analysis, the ratios that are critically significant for an investor are Debt-Equity Ratio, Price-Earning Ratio and Dividend Yield.

Therefore, the correct answer is option A.

Question 46
By reducing the sales price fromRs. 80 per unit toRs. 78 per unit, the sales manager has succeeded in selling 1000 units more of a product. Which of the following decisive conclusions can be drawn from this?a. Sales price variance is unfavourableb. Sales volume variance is favourablec. Total sales variance is unfavourabled. Sales activity variance isRs. 80000 (favourable)e. Sales price variance isRs. 2000 (unfavourable)Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.A, B and D Only
  • D.B, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, B and D Only

Sales price variance is unfavourable because Actual Selling Price is less than Standard Selling Price.

Sales volume variance is favourable because Actual Quantity is more than Standard Quantity.

Sales activity variance is same as Sales volume variance. It is given by:

= Standard Selling Price × Actual Quantity - Standard Selling Price × Standard Quantity

= Standard Selling Price (Actual Quantity - Standard Quantity)

= Rs 80 (1000)

= Rs 80000

Therefore Correct answer is (C) A, B and D Only.

Question 47
Which of the following are considered as the limitations of Cost-Volume-Profit analysis?a. Constant selling price regardless of sales volumeb. Firm efficiency and productivity are constant and the costs are linearc. Margin of safety is constant at varied levels of salesd. Sales mix and the inventory levels are constante. Profit is constant at varied levels of sales priceChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C only
  • B.B, C and D only
  • C.C, D and E only
  • D.A, B and D only
Correct Answer: A, B and D only

Cost-Volume-Profit (CVP) analysis is a valuable tool for profit planning and decision-making, yet it comes with several limitations that need to be acknowledged for its effective application.

 

Here are some key limitations:

Linear Relationship Assumption: CVP analysis assumes a linear relationship between costs and volume, overlooking factors like economies of scale, learning curves, and discounts that can alter unit costs with varying volumes. This oversight may lead to inaccurate cost and profit estimations.

Constant Sales Mix Assumption: The analysis assumes a constant sales mix, disregarding potential changes in product proportions due to market demand, competition, or pricing strategies. This can result in misleading overall profit and break-even point calculations.

Constant Selling Price Assumption: CVP analysis assumes a constant selling price, neglecting the impact of price fluctuations, discounts, and promotions on product revenues. This may result in overstated or understated profit estimations.

Constant Inventory Levels Assumption: It assumes constant inventory levels, overlooking fluctuations caused by production capacity, demand, or seasonality. Fluctuations in inventory levels can affect costs and profits, leading to misleading results.

Therefore Correct answer is (D) A, B and D only.

Question 48
Which of the following are relevant in technological innovations?a. Most innovations are incrementalb. Most innovations involve the commercial utilization of ideasc. Innovations cannot be explained with isoquantsd. Introduction of innovations is not stimulated by strong domestic rivalry and geographic concentrationse. The risk in introducing innovations is usually highChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.b, d and e only
  • B.a, c and e only
  • C.a, b and e only
  • D.a, b and c only
Correct Answer: a, b and e only

In the context of technological innovations, several factors are typically relevant.

 

Let's analyze each statement to determine its relevance:

a. Most innovations are incremental: This is true. Many technological innovations involve small, continuous improvements rather than radical changes.

b. Most innovations involve the commercial utilization of ideas: This is true. Innovation often requires taking an idea and turning it into a marketable product or service.

c. Innovations cannot be explained with isoquants: This is false. Isoquants are used in economics to show combinations of inputs that produce the same output, and they can be used to explain the impacts of innovations on production processes.

d. Introduction of innovations is not stimulated by strong domestic rivalry and geographic concentrations: This is false. Strong domestic rivalry and geographic concentrations (clusters) often stimulate innovation due to competitive pressures and knowledge spillovers.

e. The risk in introducing innovations is usually high: This is true. Innovations often involve uncertainty and significant risk, particularly in terms of market acceptance and technical feasibility.

Therefore, the correct answer is option (C), i.e., a, b and e only.

Question 49
Which of the following are relevant in deciding among different courses of action, the manager needs to consider the differential revenue and costs of alternatives?a. Opportunity costs and economic profitsb. Fixed and Sunk Costsc. Marginal Revenue and Marginal Costd. Incremental and marginal costse. Economies and dis-economies of scaleChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and D Only
  • B.B and C Only
  • C.D and E Only
  • D.A and B Only
Correct Answer: A and D Only

In deciding among different courses of action, the manager must consider the relevant factors to make informed decisions. Among the options provided, the following are relevant:

 

a. Opportunity costs and economic profits: Opportunity costs refer to the value of the next best alternative forgone when a decision is made. Economic profits consider both explicit costs (such as monetary expenses) and implicit costs (such as opportunity costs). Differential revenue and costs help in assessing the economic profitability of alternatives.

d. Incremental and marginal costs: Incremental costs are the additional costs incurred by choosing one alternative over another, while marginal costs refer to the change in total costs resulting from producing one additional unit. Understanding these costs aids in evaluating the financial implications of different courses of action.

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) A and D Only.

Question 50
Which of the following are the reasons for substitution between domestic and MNC goods?a. Increased knowledge of foreign products due to international information revolutionb. No need to conduct advertising campaignsc. Transportation costs having fallen to very low levels for most productsd. Restricted international travele. Tastes are consistent at the global levelChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A and C Only
  • B.D and E Only
  • C.C and D Only
  • D.A and B Only
Correct Answer: A and C Only

The reasons for substitution between domestic and multinational corporation (MNC) goods can vary based on various factors. Among the options provided, the following are plausible reasons:

 

a. Increased knowledge of foreign products due to international information revolution: The accessibility of information about foreign products through the international information revolution enables consumers to compare and consider foreign alternatives, leading to potential substitution.

c. Transportation costs having fallen to very low levels for most products: Reduced transportation costs make it more feasible for consumers to access and purchase foreign goods, potentially leading to substitution of domestic products with MNC goods.

Therefore, the correct answer is (A) A and C Only.

Question 51
Which of the following are constituents of thetrilemmaof international finance?a. Fixed exchange rateb. Independent monetary policyc. Free mobility of capitald. Global recessionary tendencye. Rising inflationary conditionsChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.B, C and E Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, B and C Only

The trilemma of international finance refers to the idea that it is impossible to achieve all three of the following objectives simultaneously:

a. Fixed exchange rate: This refers to a system where the value of a country's currency is fixed or pegged to the value of another currency or a basket of currencies. It limits the flexibility of monetary policy.

b. Independent monetary policy: This implies that a country has the ability to control its monetary policy, including interest rates and money supply, independently of other countries. It allows for domestic policy adjustments to address economic conditions.

c. Free mobility of capital: This suggests that capital can flow freely across borders without restrictions. It enables efficient allocation of resources but may limit a country's ability to control its exchange rate or monetary policy.

Question 52
Which of the following factors are attributed to the weakening of Indian rupee?a. Rupee payment for international tradeb. Rising cost of importsc. Widening trade deficitd. Opening of Rupeevostroaccountse. Rupee UPI payments for overseas transactionsChoose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.A, D and E Only
  • D.B, C and D Only
Correct Answer: B, C and D Only

The weakening of the Indian rupee can be attributed to several economic factors. Let's evaluate each factor listed in the question:

 

a. Rupee payment for international trade: This generally would strengthen the rupee as it increases demand for the currency. Therefore, this is not a factor that weakens the rupee.

b. Rising cost of imports: When the cost of imports rises, more rupees are needed to purchase the same amount of foreign goods. This increases demand for foreign currency and puts downward pressure on the rupee, contributing to its weakening.

c. Widening trade deficit: A trade deficit occurs when a country imports more than it exports. This requires the country to exchange more of its currency for foreign currencies to pay for the imports, thereby weakening the domestic currency.

d. Opening of Rupee vostro accounts: Vostro accounts are accounts held by a foreign bank in a domestic bank in domestic currency. These are not directly linked to the weakening of the rupee. They facilitate trade but do not inherently weaken the currency.

e. Rupee UPI payments for overseas transactions: This might have an impact on the currency, but it is not a direct or primary factor that would significantly weaken the rupee. It might increase the usability of the rupee but doesn't inherently affect its value in the same way rising imports or a trade deficit would.

 

Given these explanations, the factors that significantly contribute to the weakening of the Indian rupee are rising costs of imports and a widening trade deficit.

Thus, the most appropriate answer is option (A) - B, C and D Only.

Question 53
Whenis a country’s currencyaccepted as a reserve currency the potential conflict may arise between which of following policy objectives?a. Domestic monetary policyb. Domestic fiscal policyc. External currency policyd. Foreign trade policye. Inland trade policyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.A, C and D Only
  • C.B, D and E Only
  • D.C, D and E Only
Correct Answer: A, C and D Only

When a country's currency is accepted as a reserve currency, it can lead to potential conflicts between various policy objectives. Among the options provided, the following policy objectives may be in conflict:

a. Domestic monetary policy: The management of a country's money supply, interest rates, and exchange rates to achieve macroeconomic goals such as price stability and economic growth.

c. External currency policy: Policies related to the exchange rate and management of the country's currency in international markets, including interventions to influence its value.

d. Foreign trade policy: Strategies and regulations governing a country's trade relations with other nations, including tariffs, quotas, and trade agreements.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) A, C, and D Only.

Question 54
In order to conduct exploratory data analysis, which of following are used by a researcher in the five number summary?a. Medianb. First quartilec. Meand. Third quartilee. Smallest and largest valuesChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, C, D and E Only
  • B.A, B, D and E Only
  • C.B, C, D and E Only
  • D.A, B, C and E Only
Correct Answer: A, B, D and E Only

In exploratory data analysis, the five-number summary is a descriptive statistic that provides a concise summary of the distribution of a dataset. It includes the following five values:

a. Median: The middle value of the dataset when arranged in ascending order.

b. First quartile (Q1): The median of the lower half of the dataset.

d. Third quartile (Q3): The median of the upper half of the dataset.

e. Smallest and largest values: The minimum and maximum values of the dataset, respectively.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) A, B, D, and E Only.

Question 55
Which of the following are considered while avoiding conflict?a. Conflict based on interpersonal relationshipsb. All conflicts are not bad and can be taken positivelyc. Conflict over content and goals of the workd. Conflicts do not support a group's goal and improve its performancee. Conflict over how work gets doneChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.a, b and e only
  • C.a, c and e only
  • D.b, c and d only
Correct Answer: a, c and e only

To address conflict and understand its implications, it's important to recognize the nature and types of conflict as well as the potential benefits and drawbacks.

 

Let's consider each statement:

a. Conflict based on interpersonal relationships: This type of conflict, often referred to as "relationship conflict," involves personal disagreements and can be detrimental to a group's harmony and productivity. It is usually something to be avoided or carefully managed.

b. All conflicts are not bad and can be taken positively: This acknowledges that some conflicts, particularly "task conflicts" related to content and goals, can be beneficial by fostering discussion, innovation, and improvement.

c. Conflict over content and goals of the work: Task conflicts can be positive when they involve disagreements about the work's objectives and content, as they can lead to better decision-making and problem-solving.

d. Conflicts do not support a group's goal and improve its performance: This is generally false, as some conflicts (particularly task conflicts) can actually support a group's goals and improve performance by encouraging diverse viewpoints and critical thinking.

e. Conflict over how work gets done: Procedural conflicts, which involve disagreements over the methods and processes for completing work, can sometimes be constructive by improving efficiency and clarity in processes.

Considering these points, the correct answer is option (C) i.e., a, c and e only.

Question 56
Which of following are pre-experimental designs?a. One-grouppre test-post testb. Pre-test post-test control groupc. Quasi-experimentsd. Static group comparisone. After-only studyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.D, B, C Only
  • B.A, D, E Only
  • C.A, C, E Only
  • D.E, B, D Only
Correct Answer: A, D, E Only

Pre-experimental designs lack the rigor and control of true experimental designs. They include:

a. One-group pre test-post test: This design involves measuring a single group both before and after an intervention but lacks a control group for comparison.

d. Static group comparison: In this design, two groups are compared, but one group has already been exposed to the experimental treatment, making it less rigorous than true experimental designs.

e. After-only study: This design involves measuring outcomes only after the experimental treatment has been applied, without a pre-test to establish baseline data or a control group for comparison.

Therefore, the correct answer is (B) A, D, E Only.

Question 57
Which of the following managerial actions are followed to reduce resistance to change?a. Education and communication are strong tools for resistance to changeb. Allows participation to those who oppose a change to participate in decision makingc. Negotiation may become vital when resistance comes from a powerful sourced. Employeecounselingdoes not serve the purposee. Coercion can be used to get support easilyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.A, B and C Only
  • B.B, C and D Only
  • C.B, C and E Only
  • D.A, C and D Only
Correct Answer: A, B and C Only

Let us consider each option one by one.

 

a. Education and communication are strong tools for resistance to change: This is true. Providing education about the reasons for change and communicating effectively can help employees understand the need for change and reduce resistance.

b. Allows participation to those who oppose a change to participate in decision making: This is also true. Allowing participation gives employees a sense of involvement and ownership in the change process, reducing resistance.

c. Negotiation may become vital when resistance comes from a powerful source: This is true as well. Negotiation can help address concerns and find compromises, especially when resistance comes from influential individuals or groups.

d. Employee counseling does not serve the purpose: This statement is false. Employee counseling can be helpful in addressing individual concerns and fears related to change, thereby reducing resistance.

e. Coercion can be used to get support easily: This statement is false. Coercion may lead to compliance in the short term, but it does not necessarily reduce resistance and can lead to long-term negative consequences such as resentment and decreased morale.

Therefore, the correct answer is option A.

Question 58
Which of the following are objectives of Immediate Payment Service (IMPS)?a. To enable bank clients to use mobile instruments as a channel for accessing their bank accounts and remit fundsb. To build the foundation for a full range of mobile based banking servicesc. To sub-serve the goal of Reserve Bank of India (RBI) in digital payments.d. To make payments simpler with the mobile number of the beneficiarye. To restrain a nation-wide payment system facilitating one-to-one funds transferChoose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.a, c, d and e only
  • B.a, b, c and d only
  • C.b, c, d and e only
  • D.b, a, e and d only
Correct Answer: a, b, c and d only

The correct objectives of IMPS are mentioned in option (B), i.e., a, b, c, and d.

a. To enable bank clients to use mobile instruments as a channel for accessing their bank accounts and remit funds: This is a correct objective of IMPS, as it allows users to access their bank accounts and transfer funds using mobile devices.

b. To build the foundation for a full range of mobile-based banking services: This is also a correct objective. IMPS lays the groundwork for various mobile-based banking services beyond just fund transfer.

c. To sub-serve the goal of Reserve Bank of India (RBI) in digital payments: This is true. IMPS aligns with RBI's objective of promoting digital payments and financial inclusion.

d. To make payments simpler with the mobile number of the beneficiary: This is another correct objective. IMPS simplifies the process of making payments by using the beneficiary's mobile number as an identifier.

e. To restrain a nation-wide payment system facilitating one-to-one funds transfer: This statement is contradictory to the purpose of IMPS, which aims to facilitate one-to-one fund transfers. Therefore, it's incorrect.

Question 59
Which of the following are functions of the Reserve Bank of India?a. Bank of issueb. Banker's bank and lender of the last resortc. Regulator of fiscal policyd. Controller of credite. Custodian of foreign exchange reservesChoose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.a, b, c and d only
  • B.a, b, d and e only
  • C.b, c, d and e only
  • D.a, b and d only
Correct Answer: a, b, d and e only

Among the options given, the functions of RBI include:

a. Bank of issue: This is a function of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). It has the authority to issue currency notes on behalf of the Government of India.

b. Banker's bank and lender of the last resort: This is also a function of the RBI. It acts as a banker to the commercial banks and provides them with various banking services. Additionally, it serves as the lender of last resort, providing liquidity support to banks in times of financial crisis.

d. Controller of credit: This is a function of the RBI. It controls the credit policy in the economy through various monetary tools to achieve desired economic objectives.

e. Custodian of foreign exchange reserves: This is also a function of the RBI. It manages and maintains the foreign exchange reserves of the country to ensure stability in the foreign exchange market and support external trade and payments.

 

The option which is not included among RBI’s function:

c. Regulator of fiscal policy: This statement is incorrect. The Reserve Bank of India primarily focuses on monetary policy, not fiscal policy. Fiscal policy is typically the domain of the government's finance ministry.

Question 60
The concept of Product Life Cycle is based on which of the following key assumptions?a. Profits remain stable at different stages of product life cycleb. Products have an unlimited lifec. Product sales pass through distinct stages, each posing different challenges, opportunities and problems to the sellerd. Products require different marketing, financial, manufacturing, purchasing and human resource strategies in each of the life cycle stagese. Products have a limited lifeChoose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.b, c and d only
  • B.a, b and c only
  • C.a, c and d only
  • D.c, d and e only
Correct Answer: c, d and e only

The concept of the Product Life Cycle (PLC) is based on several key assumptions about how products evolve over time. Let’s evaluate each statement:

a. Profits remain stable at different stages of the product life cycle: This is not accurate. Profits typically fluctuate at different stages of the PLC, often being negative or low during the introduction stage, peaking during the growth stage, and declining during the maturity and decline stages.

b. Products have an unlimited life: This is not true. One of the fundamental assumptions of the PLC is that products have a limited life, as they eventually reach the decline stage where they may be phased out or replaced.

c. Product sales pass through distinct stages, each posing different challenges, opportunities, and problems to the seller: This is a key assumption of the PLC. The stages (introduction, growth, maturity, and decline) each present unique challenges and opportunities that require different strategic approaches.

d. Products require different marketing, financial, manufacturing, purchasing, and human resource strategies in each of the life cycle stages: This is also a key assumption. As products move through the PLC stages, they require different strategies to effectively manage their changing circumstances.

e. Products have a limited life: This is a fundamental assumption of the PLC. It recognizes that products will not remain in the market indefinitely and will eventually face decline.

Question 61
Emotional appeal is one of the types of advertising appeals, based on three ideas, namelya. Rational appeals generally go unnoticedb. Consumers watch all adsc. It can capture attention and foster an attachmentd. Consumers ignore most adse. Rational appeal generally gets noticedChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.c, e and d only
  • B.c, e and b only
  • C.c, a and d only
  • D.c, a and b only
Correct Answer: c, a and d only

The correct answer is option C.

Emotional appeal in advertising focuses on evoking emotions to capture the audience's attention and create a connection with the product or brand. Let's evaluate each statement:

a. Rational appeals generally go unnoticed: This suggests that emotional appeals are needed because rational appeals are less effective in capturing attention. This aligns with the idea that emotional appeals can stand out more and engage viewers on a different level.

b. Consumers watch all ads: This is generally not true. Consumers do not watch all ads, which is why capturing their attention is crucial.

c. It can capture attention and foster an attachment: This is a core idea behind emotional appeals. Emotional content can be more engaging and memorable, leading to a stronger attachment to the brand.

d. Consumers ignore most ads: This is true and aligns with the rationale for using emotional appeals. Because consumers ignore many ads, using an emotional appeal can help break through the clutter and capture attention.

e. Rational appeal generally gets noticed: This statement does not align with the premise that emotional appeals are used because rational appeals are less effective at capturing attention.

Question 62
Which are the states where every supplier of goods and/or services is required to obtain registration if his aggregate turnover exceeds the threshold limit ofRs. 20 lakh for supply of goods and/or services?a. Arunachal Pradeshb. Meghalayac. Gujaratd. Bihare. SikkimChoose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.B, C and A Only
  • B.C, D and E Only
  • C.E, B and A Only
  • D.A, B and D Only
Correct Answer: E, B and A Only

Registration is the first step towards becoming GST compliant. Without registration, a person can neither collect tax from his customers nor claim any credit of tax paid by him.

 

Under GST, a supplier is normally required to obtain single registration in a State/ UT. However, where he has multiple places of business in a State/ UT, he has the option either to get a single registration for said State / UT [wherein it can declare one place as principal place of business (PPoB) and other branches as additional place(s) of business (APoB)] or to get separate registrations for each place of business in such State/ UT.

 

Further, Registration under GST is not tax specific, which means that there is single registration for all the taxes, i.e., CGST, STGST/ UTGST, IGST and GST compensation cess.

 

Every supplier of goods and/ or services is required to obtain registration in the State/UT from where he makes the taxable supply, if his aggregate turnover exceeds the threshold limit during a financial year.

 

Different threshold limits have been prescribed for various States and Union Territories depending upon the fact whether the supplier is engaged exclusively in supply of goods, or exclusively in supply of services or in supply of both goods and services.

 

The threshold limit of aggregate turnover prescribed for various States/UTs are as follows.

 

However, in certain specified cases mandatory registration is required under GST irrespective of the quantum of aggregate turnover.

 

Note, that UGC has dropped this question and accordingly, the question has been changed here.

Question 63
Which of the following can become the member of an LLP?a. Resident Indiansb. Limited Liability Partnershipc. Corporation Soled. Co-operative societye. Companies (including foreign companies)Choose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.a, b and c only
  • B.a, c and d only
  • C.a, b and d only
  • D.a, e and b only
Correct Answer: a, e and b only

An LLP has partners but no directors or shareholders. The major constituents of an LLP are its partners who are the ultimate owners.

 

Any individual or body corporate may be a partner in an LLP.

 

However, an individual shall not be capable of becoming a partner of a LLP, if:

(a) he has been found to be of unsound mind by a Court;

(b) he is an undischarged insolvent; or

(c) he has applied to be adjudicated as an insolvent and his application is pending.

 

Meaning of Body Corporate

 

As per LLP Act 2008, a body corporate means a company defined under Companies Act and includes:

an LLP registered under this Act

an LLP incorporated outside India, and

a Company incorporated outside India

but does not include:

corporation sole;

a co-operative society registered under any law for the time being in force; or

any other body corporate or LLP which the CG may specify in this behalf.

Therefore, the correct answer is option D.

Question 64
The trademarks can be broadly classified into which of the following categories?a. Descriptiveb. Normativec. Genericd. Explanatorye. InventedChoose the most appropriate answer from the option given below:
  • A.a, b and d only
  • B.d, e and c only
  • C.b, c and e only
  • D.c, a and e only
Correct Answer: c, a and e only

The spectrum of distinctiveness for trademarks ranges from generic to fanciful (invented):

Generic Trademark: These are common names for products or services that cannot be trademarked because they represent the product or service itself. Examples include "Ice Cream" for ice cream products or "Fitness Trainer" for fitness training services.

Descriptive Trademark: These marks describe a feature or characteristic of the product or service but are not as generic as generic marks. Examples include "National Car Rental" and "Payless Shoes."

Suggestive Trademark: Suggestive marks allude to features or characteristics of the product or service in a subtle way, allowing for trademark protection. Examples include "Bed, Bath & Beyond" and "Photoshop."

Arbitrary Trademark: Arbitrary marks are dictionary words used for products or services that have no connection to the actual product or service. Examples include "Apple" for technology products and "Canon" for cameras.

Fanciful Trademark (Invented Trademerk): Fanciful marks are invented words that have no meaning other than to identify specific products or services. Examples include "Kodak," "Twitter," "Exxon," and "Walmart."

Question 65
Which of the following are deemed to be dividend for the purpose of computing income chargeable under the head, Income from other sources, as per the Income Tax Act, 1961?a. Payment on buy-back of sharesb. Payment to shareholders on reduction of capitalc. Distribution of debentures to shareholdersd. Loan granted to shareholders in the ordinary course of businesse. Loan granted to shareholders by a closely held companyChoose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.B and C Only
  • B.B, C and E Only
  • C.A, B and C Only
  • D.A and C Only
Correct Answer: B, C and E Only

‘Dividend’ usually refers to the distribution of profits by a company to its shareholders.

However, in view of Sec. 2(22) of the Income-tax Act, the dividend shall include the following:

(a) Distribution of accumulated profits to shareholders entailing release of the company's assets;

(b) Distribution of debentures or deposit certificates to shareholders out of the accumulated profits of the company and issue of bonus shares to preference shareholders out of accumulated profits;

(c) Distribution made to shareholders of the company on its liquidation out of accumulated profits;

(d) Distribution to shareholders out of accumulated profits on the reduction of capital by the company; and

(e) Loan or advance made by a closely held company to its shareholder out of accumulated profits.

Therefore, the correct answer is option B.

Question 66
Which of the following will be clubbed into the income ofMr.QwhoseIncome from Profession isRs. 85,000?a. Income from Mrs Q's profession,Rs. 45,000b.Mrs.Q's salary as a clerk,Rs. 66,000c. Minor son's earned interest on deposits of money gifted to him by his uncle,Rs. 15,000d. Minor daughter's earnings from sports,Rs85,000e. Minor son's winnings from lottery,Rs1,05,000Choose the correct answer from the options given below:
  • A.a, c, d and e only
  • B.c, d and e only
  • C.c and d only
  • D.c and e only
Correct Answer: c and e only

The clubbing provisions are applicable in following cases:

 

1. In the case of transfer of income without transfer of asset

It is the case, where the taxpayer, owns the asset and retains its ownership, but decides to transfer its income to any person, by doing an agreement or any other way. In such case, the income from the asset, would be taxable in the hands of the transferor.

 

2. In the case of revocable transfer of asset

If an asset is transferred under a ‘revocable transfer’, income from such asset, is taxable in the hands of transferor. ‘Revocable transfer’ is, generally, a transfer in which the transferor directly or indirectly exercises control/right over the asset transferred or over the income from the asset.

 

3. In respect of remuneration of spouse

It is the case where the taxpayer is an individual and he/she has a substantial interest in a concern. In addition, spouse of the taxpayer (i.e. husband /wife) is employed in such concern without any technical or professional knowledge or experience. An individual has a ‘substantial interest’ in any of the following two situations:

In the case of a company – If an individual beneficially holds (individually or along with his relatives), 20% or more of equity shares, in the company, at any time during the previous year.

In the case of a concern (other than company) – If an individual is entitled to 20% or more share in profit in the concern (individually or along with his relatives), at any time, during the previous year.

 

‘Relative’ in relation to an ‘individual’ means the husband, wife, brother or sister or any lineal ascendant/ descendant of that individual. If such conditions are satisfied, then salary income of the spouse will be taxable in the hands of the taxpayer.

 

4. In respect of income from assets transferred to spouse

It is the case where, taxpayer is an individual and he/she has transferred an asset (other than house property), directly or indirectly to his/ her spouse. In addition, the asset is transferred, otherwise, than (a) for adequate consideration, or (b) in connection with an agreement to live apart. The asset may be held by the transferee-spouse in the same or in a different form. If the above conditions are satisfied, any income from such asset, shall be deemed to be the income of the taxpayer, who has transferred the asset.

 

5. In respect of income from assets transferred to son’s wife

It is the case, where the taxpayer, is an individual and he/she has transferred an asset after May 31,1973 to his/her son’s wife. The asset is transferred either directly or indirectly, otherwise, than for adequate consideration. The asset may be held by the transferee in the same form or in a different form. If the above conditions are satisfied, then income from the asset is included in the income of the taxpayer, who has transferred the asset. Further, the relationship of father-in-law (or mother-in-law) and daughter-in-law should subsist both at the time of transfer of asset and at the time of accrual of income.

 

6. In respect of income from assets transferred to a person for the benefit of spouse

It is the case, where the taxpayer is an individual and he/she has transferred an asset, directly or indirectly, to a person or an association of persons, for the immediate or deferred benefit of his/her spouse without adequate consideration. If the aforesaid conditions are satisfied, then income from such asset, to the extent of such benefit, is taxable, in the hands of the taxpayer who has transferred the asset.

 

7. In respect of income from assets transferred to a person for the benefit of son’s wife

It is the case, where, the taxpayer is an individual and he/she has transferred an asset after May 31, 1973, directly or indirectly, to a person or an association of persons, for the immediate or deferred benefit of his/her son’s wife, without adequate consideration. If the aforesaid conditions are satisfied, then income from such asset, to the extent of such benefit, is taxable in the hands of the taxpayer, who has transferred the asset.

 

8. In respect of income of minor child

Some families make fixed deposits in the name of a minor child. Income of a minor is taxable in the hands of the parent whose total income is higher (before including the minor's income). If the parents are divorced, it is clubbed with the person, who is maintaining the child.

 

In the cases given below, clubbing provisions with respect to income of minor child are not applicable:

If the minor has earned an income because of his own manual work.

If the minor has earned an income on account of any activity involving application of his skill, talent or specialized knowledge or experience

Income of minor child suffering from any disability (of the nature specified in Section 80U)

 

When minor child's income is clubbed with parent’s income, exemption is available up to Rs. 1,500 for each such minor child. This means, if clubbed income is more than Rs. 1,500, the maximum exemption is Rs. 1,500, however, if clubbed income is, say, Rs. 800 (less than Rs 1500), then exemption is limited up to such lesser amount, i.e., Rs. 800 in this case.

Question 67
Match List IwithList II:List I (Nature of Business Activity)a. Trading in Transferable Development Rights (TDR)b. Multi-Brand Retail Tradingc. Satellite (Establishment and Operations)d. Petroleum Refining (by PSUs)List II (FDI Permitted under Automatic Route)i. 49%ii. Prohibitediii. 51%iv. 100%Choose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-iv, b-ii, c-iii, d-i
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i
  • C.a-i, b-iii, c-ii, d-iv
  • D.a-iv, b-ii, c-i, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i

The correct match is as follows.

 

List I

List II

(Nature of Business Activity)

(FDI Permitted under Automatic Route)

a. Trading in Transferable Development Rights (TDR)

Prohibited

b. Multi-Brand Retail Trading

51%

c. Satellite (Establishment and Operations)

100%

d. Petroleum Refining (by PSUs)

49%

 

Question 68
Match list IwithList II:List I (Activity Based CostCenters)a. Unit-level activitycenterb. Batch level activitycenterc. Product level activitycenterd. Facility level activitycenterList II (Costs incurred and accounted for)i. Patent, trademark and copyright feesii. Direct material and labour costsiii. Plant depreciation and maintenance expensesiv. Material handling costsChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-ii b-iv, c-i, d-iii
  • B.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
  • C.a-i, b-iii, c-ii, d-iv
  • D.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-ii b-iv, c-i, d-iii

The correct match is as follows.

a. Unit-level activity center: ii. Direct material and labour costs

Unit-level activities are directly related to the production of individual units of a product, so the costs incurred here include direct material and labor costs.

 

b. Batch level activity center: iv. Material handling costs

Batch-level activities involve handling materials in batches, so the costs incurred here include material handling costs.

 

c. Product level activity center: i. Patent, trademark and copyright fees

Product-level activities involve costs associated with patents, trademarks, and copyrights, as these are related to specific products.

 

d. Facility level activity center: iii. Plant depreciation and maintenance expenses

Facility-level activities involve costs associated with maintaining and depreciating the overall facility where production takes place.

 

So, the correct answer is option (A) i.e., a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii.

Question 69
Match List IwithList II:List I (Types of Effect)a. Veblen effectb. Snob effectc. Bandwagon effectd. Substitution effectList II (Description)i. Conspicuous consumptionii. Reduction in relative price of commodityiii. Negative network externalityiv. Positive network externalityChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • C.a-ii, b-iii, c-iv, d-i
  • D.a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-i, b-iii, c-iv, d-ii

The matching of List I with List II is as follows:

a. Veblen effect: Conspicuous consumption (i)

b. Snob effect: Negative network externality (iii)

c. Bandwagon effect: Positive network externality (iv)

d. Substitution effect: Reduction in relative price of commodity (ii)

 

Veblen Effect (a): This refers to the phenomenon where the demand for a product increases as its price increases because owning the product is seen as a status symbol or a display of wealth, leading to conspicuous consumption.

Snob Effect (b): This occurs when the demand for a product decreases as its popularity increases among the mass market. It is associated with negative network externalities, where the value of the product decreases for individuals as more people use it.

Bandwagon Effect (c): This refers to the tendency of individuals to adopt a behavior or purchase a product because it is popular or widely accepted by others. It is associated with positive network externalities, where the value of the product increases for individuals as more people use it.

Substitution Effect (d): This occurs when the relative price of a commodity decreases, leading consumers to substitute it for other goods or services. It is not directly related to network externalities but rather to changes in price relative to other goods or services.

Question 70
Match List IwithList II:List I (Bond rates and risk)a. Coupon rateb. Yield to maturityc. Interest rate riskd. Current (bond) yieldList II (Description)i. The interest rate required in the market on a bondii. It is obtained by dividing annual coupon (stated interest payment) by the bond priceiii. It germinates and originates from fluctuating interest ratesiv. The annual coupon (stated interest payment) divided by the face value of a bondChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii
  • B.a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv
  • C.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • D.a-i, b-iii, c-ii, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-i, c-iii, d-ii

The matching of List I with List II is as follows:

a. Coupon rate: The annual coupon (stated interest payment) divided by the face value of a bond (iv)

b. Yield to maturity: The interest rate required in the market on a bond (i)

c. Interest rate risk: It germinates and originates from fluctuating interest rates (iii)

d. Current (bond) yield: It is obtained by dividing annual coupon (stated interest payment) by the bond price (ii)

 

Coupon Rate (a): It represents the annual interest payment on a bond expressed as a percentage of the bond's face value.

Yield to Maturity (b): This is the total return anticipated on a bond if it is held until it matures. It is the interest rate required by the market on a bond.

Interest Rate Risk (c): This risk arises from changes in interest rates, which can affect the value of a bond. Fluctuating interest rates can lead to changes in bond prices.

Current (Bond) Yield (d): It represents the annual coupon payment of a bond divided by its current market price. It is a measure of the income generated by a bond relative to its current market price.

Question 71
Match List I withtheList II:List I (Description Identifiers)a. The time dimensionb. The purpose of the studyc. The topical scope of the studyd. The degree to which the research question has been crystallizedList II (Research design)i. Exploratory studyii. Statistical studyiii. Descriptive studyiv. Cross-sectional studyChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-iii, b-i, c-iv, d-ii
  • C.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • D.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i

The correct matching of List I with the List II is as follows:

 

a. The time dimension: Cross-sectional study (iv)

b. The purpose of the study: Descriptive study (iii)

c. The topical scope of the study: Statistical study (ii)

d. The degree to which the research question has been crystallized: Exploratory study (i)

 

Cross-sectional Study (a): Focuses on data collected at a single point in time, providing a snapshot view of a population or phenomenon at that specific moment.

Descriptive Study (b): Aims to describe characteristics or attributes of a population or phenomenon. It provides information about the prevalence, distribution, and associations of variables.

Statistical Study (c): Involves the use of statistical methods to analyze data and draw conclusions. It may involve hypothesis testing, correlation analysis, regression analysis, etc.

Exploratory Study (d): Seeks to explore a research problem or phenomenon when there is limited existing knowledge or understanding. It aims to generate insights, ideas, or hypotheses for further investigation.

Question 72
Match List I withtheList II:List I (Management Thinkers)a. KurtLewinb. Fred E Fiedlerc. HenriFayold. David c. McClellandList II (Approach Dimensions)i. Position power, Task structure, Leader member relationsii. Authority and Responsibility, Unity of command, Scalar chainiii. Power, Affiliation, Achievementiv. Unfreezing, Moving, RefreezingChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii
  • C.a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-ii, b-iv, c-iii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-i, c-ii, d-iii

The correct match is as follows.

 

a. Kurt Lewin: ii. Unfreezing, Moving, Refreezing –

Kurt Lewin is known for his three-step change model, which involves unfreezing the current state, moving to a new state, and refreezing to make the change permanent.

 

b. Fred E. Fiedler: iv. Position power, Task structure, Leader member relations

Fred E. Fiedler is associated with the contingency theory of leadership, which emphasizes the importance of situational factors such as leader-member relations, task structure, and position power.

 

c. Henri Fayol: ii. Authority and Responsibility, Unity of command, Scalar chain

Henri Fayol is known for his principles of management, which include unity of command, scalar chain, and authority and responsibility.

 

d. David C. McClelland: i. Power, Affiliation, Achievement

David C. McClelland is known for his work on motivational needs, particularly the need for achievement, affiliation, and power.

Thus, correct answer is option B.

Question 73
Match List IwithList II:List I (Asset classes)a. Asset Class Ab. Asset Class Cc. Asset Class Ed. Asset Class GList II (Type of Investments)i. Equity shares of companies traded in futures and options segmentsii. Government securities and state development loansiii. Alternate Assetsiv. Corporate bonds/debentures which are listed and rated not below AChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-i, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii
  • B.a-iii, b-ii, c-iv, d-i
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-i, b-iii, c-ii, d-iv
Correct Answer: a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii

The question refers to NPS.

 

National Pension System (NPS) is a defined contribution pension. NPS is voluntary for subscription by an individual to make contributions to his/her Individual Pension Account during the working life for creating a pension corpus from which regular income will be generated after retirement / working age. NPS is mandatory for the Central Government recruits w.e.f. 1st Jan 2004 (except armed forces) which replaced the earlier defined benefit pension and has been subsequently adopted by almost all State Governments for their employees.

 

The contributions are invested by Pension Funds according to the investment guidelines prescribed by PFRDA for each asset class.

 

Asset class E – Equity shares of companies traded in Futures and Options segment

Asset Class C – Corporate Bonds / Debentures which are listed and rated not below A

Asset Class G – Government securities and State Development Loans

Asset Class A – Alternate Assets

Thus, correct answer is option C.

Question 74
Match List I withtheList II:List I (Concepts Targeting)a. Target Compatibilityb. Tactical Targetingc. Target Attractivenessd. Strategic TargetingList II (Definition)i. Reflects the ability of a market segment to create superior value for the companyii. A reflection of the company's ability, to create superior customer valueiii. Focuses on customising company's offerings according to the customers' needsiv. Ways in which the company can reach strategically important customersChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • B.a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii
  • C.a-ii, b-iii, c-i, d-iv
  • D.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
Correct Answer: a-ii, b-iv, c-i, d-iii

The correct match is given below.

Target Compatibility - reflects the company's ability to fulfill the needs of its customers better than the competition.

Tactical Targeting - Ways in which the company can reach strategically important customers.

Target Attractiveness – It reflects the ability of a market segment to create superior value for the company.

Strategic Targeting - A key principle of strategic targeting is that the choice of customers should be driven by the company's ability to create an offering that delivers superior value to the customers relative to the competition.

Question 75
Match List I with the List II:List I (Features)a. Breach of promise to marryb. Part performance (as much as earned)c.Absolvationfrom all obligationsd. Mode of securing the specific performance of negative terms of contractList II (Remedies for breach of contract)i. Suit for injunctionii. Rescission of contractiii. Sue for quantummeruitiv. Vindictive damageChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i
  • B.a-i, b-ii, c-iii, d-iv
  • C.a-iii, b-iv, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-ii, b-i, c-iv, d-iii
Correct Answer: a-iv, b-iii, c-ii, d-i

The correct match is as follows.

 

List I – List II

(Features) - (Remedies for breach of contract)

a. Breach of promise to marry - Vindictive damage

When there's a breach of promise to marry, the innocent party may suffer emotional distress or other damages. Vindictive damages, also known as punitive damages, are awarded to punish the party at fault and deter similar conduct in the future.

 

b. Part performance (as much as earned) - Sue for quantum meruit

If one party performs part of the contract but the other party breaches it, the performing party can sue for quantum meruit. Quantum meruit is a legal principle that allows a party to recover the reasonable value of services rendered or work performed.

 

c. Absolvation from all obligations - Rescission of contract

When one party seeks absolution from all obligations under the contract, they may seek rescission of the contract. Rescission of contract cancels the contract, releasing both parties from their obligations and restoring them to their pre-contractual positions.

 

d. Mode of securing the specific performance of negative terms of contract - Suit for injuction

When one party wants to secure the specific performance of negative terms of the contract (such as restraining the other party from doing something they agreed not to do), they can file a suit for injunction. An injunction is a court order that requires a party to do or refrain from doing a specific action.

Question 76
Math List I withtheList II:List I (Assets Transferred)a. Agricultural Landb. Residential Housec. Land or Building or Bothd. Land and Building forming part of an industrial undertakingList II (Exemptions of capital gains Sections 54-54 EC Income Tax Act)i. Section 54 Bii. Section 54 ECiii. Section 54 Div. Section 54Choose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a-iii, b-ii, c-i, d-iv
  • B.a-i, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii
  • C.a-iv, b-iii, c-i, d-ii
  • D.a-iii, b-ic-iv, d-ii
Correct Answer: a-i, b-iv, c-ii, d-iii

The correct match is as follows.

 

List I - List II

(Assets Transferred) - (Exemptions of capital gains)

a. Agricultural Land - Section 54 B

Section 54B gives relief to a taxpayer who sells his agricultural land and from the sale proceeds, he acquires another agricultural land. The benefit of Section 54B is available only to an individual or a HUF.

 

Conditions for Exemption

Following conditions should be satisfied to claim the benefit of Section 54B.

1) The asset transferred should be agricultural land.

2) The land may be a long-term capital asset or short-term capital asset.

3) The agricultural land should be used by the individual or his parents for agricultural purpose, at least for a period of 2 years, immediately preceding the date of transfer. In case of HUF, the land should be used by any member of HUF.

4) Within a period of 2 years, from the date of transfer of old land, the taxpayer should acquire another agricultural land (may be in rural area or urban area).

 

The quantum of exemption is the actual amount invested in new asset or capital gain, whichever is less.

 

b. Residential House - Section 54

The exemption u/s 54 relates to the capital gain arising out of transfer of residential house. The exemption is available to only Individual assessee or HUF. The exemption relates to the capital gains arising on the transfer of a residential house.

 

Exemption is available if:

a) House Property transferred was used for residential purpose.

b) House Property was a long-term capital asset.

c) The assessee has purchased another house property within a period of 1 year before or 2 years after the date of transfer or has constructed another house property within 3 years of date of transfer, i.e., the construction of the new house property should be completed within 3 years. The date of starting of construction is irrelevant.

d) The new residential house should be in India.

e) The amount of exemption for the long-term capital gain shall be lower of the following:

1. Capital gains arising on transfer of residential house, or

2. Investment made in purchase or construction of a new residential house property. Hence, the balance capital gains (if any) will be taxable.

 

However, where the amount of the capital gain does not exceed Rs. 2 crore, the assessee, may at his option, purchase or construct 2 residential houses in India.

 

Further, where during any AY, the assessee has exercised the option of 2 houses referred above, he shall not be subsequently entitled to exercise the option for the same or any other assessment year. Therefore, now the exemption can be claimed for purchase/construction of 2 residential houses instead of one (from the AY 2020-21). The benefit is available only when the capital gain does not exceed Rs. 2 crore. Further, this benefit is available only once in a lifetime. The new house property should not be transferred within 3 years from the date of its acquisition.

 

Quantum of Exemption is the actual amount invested in new asset or capital gain, whichever is less.

 

Amendment

With effect from 1st April 2023 (i.e., A.Y. 2024-25), maximum deduction allowed under Section 54 has been capped to Rs. 10 crore and consequently the cost of the new asset will be limited to Rs. 10 Crore.

 

c. Land or Building or Both - Section 54 EC

When a taxpayer sells long-term immovable property (land or building or both), they have the option to avail capital gain exemption under Section 54EC by investing in certain bonds.

 

Exemption under Section 54EC of the Income Tax Act, 1961 is available to any assessee, in case the long-term capital gain is invested into the long term specified assets. Long term specified assets means any bond redeemable after a period of 5 years from financial year 2018-19. The said bonds should have been issued on or after 1st April, 2000.

 

d. Land and Building forming part of an industrial undertaking - Section 54 D

Exemption under Section 54D is allowed, provided the assessee has Capital Gains on Compulsory Acquisition of Industrial Undertaking. It is available to all assessees.

 

Conditions for Exemption

Following conditions must be satisfied to avail this exemption:

a) The assessee should have invested the amount in Land and Building for the purpose of Industrial Undertaking within a period of 3 years after the date of Payment by Government.

b) The assessee should have been using such Land and Building for the purpose of Industrial Undertaking for a period of at least 2 years, at the time of Acquisition.

c) The Land and Building, so purchased, should not be transferred for a period of at least 3 years.

 

The quantum of exemption is the actual amount invested in new asset or capital gain, whichever is less.

Question 77
Arrange the following rounds for multilateral trade negotiations under GATT/WTO in a chronological order.a. Kennedyb. Dohac. Annecyd. Torquaye. TokyoChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.C, D, A, E, B
  • B.D, C, E, A, B
  • C.B, A, E, C, D
  • D.B, E, A, D, C
Correct Answer: C, D, A, E, B

During the GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade) years, eight rounds of tariff negotiations were held between 1947 and 1994: Geneva (1947), Annecy (1949), Torquay (1950-51), Geneva (1956), Geneva (1960-61) - also known as the Dillon Round, the Kennedy Round (1964-67), the Tokyo Round (1973-79) and the Uruguay Round (1986-94).

Question 78
Arrange the steps in the book building process for public issue of shares in India.a. Determine issue price, market clearing price and price discoveryb. Book runner and syndicate members generate awareness, create demand and run the order bookc. Appointment of the merchant banker and syndicate members (SEBIregisterdintermediaries) as underwritersd. Preparation and filing of red herringpropectuswith the SEBI for approvale. Allotment and listing of shares on stock exchange (s)Choose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.c, d, b, a, e
  • B.d, c, a, b, e
  • C.a, b, c, d, e
  • D.b, c, d, e, a
Correct Answer: c, d, b, a, e

The sequence of steps in the book building process for public issue of shares in India are as follows:

 

c. Appointment of the merchant banker and syndicate members (SEBI registered intermediaries) as underwriters: The process begins with appointment of the merchant banker and syndicate members as underwriters. Underwriters commit to purchasing any unsold shares in the event of undersubscription during the issue.

 

d. Preparation and filing of red herring prospectus with the SEBI for approval: Afterwards, red herring prospectus with the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) is filed for approval. This document provides essential information about the company and the offering to potential investors.

 

b. Book runner and syndicate members generate awareness, create demand, and run the order book: The book runner and syndicate members play a crucial role in generating awareness about the offering, creating demand among investors, and managing the order book during the bidding process.

 

a. Determine issue price, market clearing price, and price discovery: The book-building process begins with determining the issue price through the price discovery mechanism. Investors submit their bids within a specified price range, and the final issue price is determined based on demand and supply dynamics in the market.

 

e. Allotment and listing of shares on stock exchange(s): After the completion of the book-building process and the determination of the final issue price, the shares are allotted to investors based on their bids. Subsequently, the allotted shares are listed on the stock exchange(s) for trading.

Question 79
Arrange the following in a sequence with regard to price leadership sustainability:a. Small firms in the industry are allowed to sell all they want at that priceb. Dominant firm acts as the residual supplier of the commodityc. The dominant firm sets the price for the commodity that maximizes its profitsd. Small firms in the industry behave as price takerse. Dominant firm then comes into fill the marketChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.E, D, C, B, A
  • C.A, C, B, D, E
  • D.C, A, E, B, D
Correct Answer: C, A, E, B, D

The correct sequence regarding price leadership sustainability is as follows:

1. c. The dominant firm sets the price for the commodity that maximizes its profits

2. a. Small firms in the industry are allowed to sell all they want at that price

3. e. Dominant firm then comes into fill the market

4. b. Dominant firm acts as the residual supplier of the commodity

5. d. Small firms in the industry behave as price takers.

So, the correct answer is (D) C, A, E, B, D.

Question 80
Sequentially arrange the following impacts of the evolving global monetary system on the economies.a. Protectionism and nationalismb. Capital flows driving economic developmentc. Increased world trade with limited capital flowsd. Expanded open economiese. Industrial economies increasingly open and emerging nations open slowlyChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.B, D, A, C, E
  • B.C, A, D, E, B
  • C.C, E, D, A, B
  • D.E, B, D, A, C
Correct Answer: C, A, D, E, B

The correct sequential arrangement of the impacts of the evolving global monetary system on the economies is as follows:

1. c. Increased world trade with limited capital flows

2. a. Protectionism and nationalism

3. d. Expanded open economies

4. e. Industrial economies increasingly open and emerging nations open slowly

5. b. Capital flows driving economic development

 

So, the correct answer is (B) C, A, D, E, B

Question 81
Arrange the following steps of a well-planned experiment in the sequential order.a. Specify the treatment levelsb. Assign subject to groups and conduct pilot testc. Choose an experimental design suited to the hypothesesd. Control the environmental and extraneous factorse. Select relevant variables for testingChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.C, D, E, A, B
  • B.A, C, D, E, B
  • C.E, A, D, C, B
  • D.D, C, B, A, E
Correct Answer: E, A, D, C, B

The correct sequential order for the steps of a well-planned experiment is:

1. e. Select relevant variables for testing

2. a. Specify the treatment levels

3. d. Control the environmental and extraneous factors

4. c. Choose an experimental design suited to the hypotheses

5. b. Assign subjects to groups and conduct a pilot test.

So, the correct answer is (C) E, A, D, C, B

Question 82
Arrange the following group member's behaviour outcomes in a sequence as per the successive stages of group building process.a. Eager, Anxious, gather data about similarities and differences among members and keep things simpleb. Upset and Depressedc. Less dissatisfied and a feeling of belongings to the groupd. Confront the differences, feel angry or frustrated, lot of competition and hostilities.e. Inter dependence in personal relations, tendency to get involved in and problem solvingChoose the correct answer from the option given below:Codes
  • A.A, D, C, E, B
  • B.A, B, C, D, E
  • C.E, C, D, B, A
  • D.B, C. E, A, D
Correct Answer: A, D, C, E, B

To match the group member behaviours with the stages of group development according to Tuckman's model (Forming, Storming, Norming, Performing, Adjourning), let's align each behaviour with the corresponding stage:

 

Forming: Members are eager, anxious, gathering data about similarities and differences among members, and keeping things simple.

Behaviour: (a) Eager, anxious, gather data about similarities and differences among members and keep things simple.

 

Storming: Members confront differences, feel angry or frustrated, experience a lot of competition and hostilities.

Behavior: (d) Confront the differences, feel angry or frustrated, a lot of competition and hostilities.

 

Norming: Members are less dissatisfied and develop a feeling of belonging to the group.

Behavior: (c) Less dissatisfied and a feeling of belonging to the group.

 

Performing: Members show interdependence in personal relations and a tendency to get involved in problem-solving.

Behavior: (e) Interdependence in personal relations, tendency to get involved in problem-solving.

 

Adjourning: Members might feel upset and depressed as the group disbands.

Behavior: (b) Upset and depressed.

Question 83
Arrange the following SBI-sponsored RRBs in an increasing order of their existence since formation.a. RajasthanMarudharaGraminBankb. TelanganaGraminBankc.SaurashtraGraminBankd.MadhyanchalGraminBanke. Arunachal Pradesh Rural BankChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.A, D, B, E, C
  • B.C, E, D, A, B
  • C.B, A, C, E, D
  • D.D, E, A, B, C
Correct Answer: C, E, D, A, B

The correct answer is option B.

  • Saurashtra Gramin Bank – 1978
  • Arunachal Pradesh Rural Bank – 1983
  • Madhyanchal Gramin Bank – 2012
  • Rajasthan Marudhara Gramin Bank – 2014 (April)

Telangana Gramin Bank – 2014 (October)

Question 84
Place the following service differentiators in a logical sequence:a. Speed and timing of deliveryb. Maintenance and repairc. Returnsd. Installation, training and consultinge. Ease of orderingChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.E, D, B, C, A
  • B.E, A, D, B, C
  • C.E, D, A, C, B
  • D.E, C, A, B, D
Correct Answer: E, A, D, B, C

The logical sequence for service differentiators is as follows:

1. e. Ease of ordering

2. a. Speed and timing of delivery

3. d. Installation, training, and consulting

4. b. Maintenance and repair

5. c. Returns

So, the correct answer is (B) E, A, D, B, C

Question 85
Arrange the following steps in the investigation process of combinations by the Competition Commission of India in the correct order.a.Call for a report from the Director Generalb. Invite any person, affected parties to file written objectionsc. Direct the parties of combination to publish details of the combinationd. Call for additional information from the parties of the combinatione.Issue a notice for show-cause to the pates of the combinationChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.A, B, C, D, E
  • B.E, A, C, B, D
  • C.B, A, C, D, E
  • D.C, A, D, E, B
Correct Answer: E, A, C, B, D

The steps in the investigation process of combinations by the Competition Commission of India in the correct order are as follows.

1. Issue a notice for show-cause to the pates of the combination

2. Call for a report from the Director General

3. Direct the parties of combination to publish details of the combination

4. Invite any person, affected parties to file written objections

5. Call for additional information from the parties of the combination.

Thus, correct answer is option B

Question 86
Arrange the following in the ascending order of applicable TDS (Tax deducted at source) rates for the Financial Year, 2023-24.a. Payment ofRs. 6,55,000 rent by an individual in a yearb. Payment ofRs20,000 on winnings from horse racesc. Payment ofRs8,000 as dividend by chequed. Payment ofRs. 35,000 to an individual contractor for repair by a universitye. Payment ofRs38,000 as fees for professional and technical services by a callcenterChoose the correct answer from the option given below:
  • A.a, b, c, d, e
  • B.d, e, a, c, b
  • C.e, d, c, b, a
  • D.a, e, c, d, b
Correct Answer: d, e, a, c, b

The TDS rates for transactions given in the question in the ascending order are as follows.

1. Payment of Rs. 35,000 to an individual contractor for repair by a university – 1%

2. Payment of Rs 38,000 as fees for professional and technical services by a call center – 2%

3. Payment of Rs. 6,55,000 rent by an individual in a year – 5%

4. Payment of Rs 8,000 as dividend by cheque – 10%

5. Payment of Rs 20,000 on winnings from horse races – 30%

Question 87
Given below are two statements: one is labelled as Assertion 'A' and the other is labelled as Reason 'R'.Assertion 'A':A promoter, invariably is the one who has been associated with formation of the company.Reason 'R':A promoter is the one who undertakes to form a company with reference to a given object and who takes the necessary steps to accomplish that purpose.In the light of the above statements, choose the most appropriate answer from the options given below:
  • A.Both 'A' and 'R' are correct and 'R' is the correct explanation of 'A'.
  • B.Both 'A' and 'R' are correct but 'R' is NOT the correct explanation of 'A'.
  • C.'A' is correct but 'R' is not correct.
  • D.'A' is not correct but 'R' is correct
Correct Answer: 'A' is not correct but 'R' is correct

Assertion 'A' states that a promoter, invariably, is the one who has been associated with the formation of the company. This assertion is not entirely accurate because while a promoter is often associated with the formation of a company, it's not always the case that the promoter is the one who establishes the company. Sometimes, promoters may initiate the process but not necessarily see it through to the formation of the company.

 

Reason 'R' defines a promoter as someone who undertakes to form a company with reference to a given object and takes the necessary steps to accomplish that purpose.
